After having been closed all Summer because of many loans made to the exhibition of old masters at the World's Fair, the Jules S. Bache collection, 814 Fifth Avenue, will reopen its doors to the public for its third season Wednesday.

The belief that we live in the blackest and most troublous time man has ever known is entirely false, the Rev. Dr. Daniel Russell declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Seventy-third Street and Broadway.

ALBANY, Nov. 5--Inspired by a heavy snowfall, some 200 delegates and members of fifty-five clubs along the Atlantic Seaboard made the eighteenth annual meeting of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association at the DeWitt Clinton Hotel today one of the most interesting and informative in the organization's history.

BERLIN, Nov. 5--The spectacular growth of tax revenue, which, during past years has helped to solve the Reich's financial problems, showed signs of slackening during the second quarter of the present fiscal year--July to September.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 5 (AP)--The effect of the embargo repeal on steel demand has not yet been determined, the magazine Steel said today, although potential export business has figured in the constantly increasing steel operations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--The good arm and got of Slingin' Sammy Baugh today gave the Washington Redskins a 7-to-6 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles and boosted them from second place to a tie with the New York Giants for the Eastern lead in the National Football League.
In noting that this month marks the eighty-third anniversary of Methodist missions in India, the Rev. Dr. Howard McGrath declared...

DETROIT, Nov. 5--The Lions hit the airways and the long Giant unbeaten record in the same motion before a record Detroit crowd of 48,492 in Briggs Stadium today as they won a see-saw thriller from the champions of the National Football League, 18 to 14.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5--Shipping and travel facilities between the United States and South America have been enhanced by "unprecedented improvements" in the last year, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, asserted in a statement today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6--American citizens, except diplomatic and consular agents and army and naval officers on duty, at a prohibited from traveling on belligerent ships in combat zones, unless specially authorized to do so by the Secretary of State, under neutrality regulations issued today by Secretary Hull.
A triplex penthouse apartment in 24 West Fifty-fifth Street has been leased by Oscar Homolka, the actor, through Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., brokers.

PARIS, Nov. 6--French general headquarters today announced a sweeping victory in the most important air fight of the war to date, both as regards the forces engaged and the violence of its character. It was officially stated that nine French airmen had each brought down an opponent above the Rhine-Moselle front today, without loss.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6--A petition by the United States Lines for permission to transfer nine of its vessels to the registry of the Republic of Panama so the ships could enter the combat zone is being held in abeyance.

A.D. Whiteside, president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., won first choice of a hundred paintings and examples of sculpture by contemporary American artists last night at the seventeenth annual Founders Show Drawing at the Grand Central Art Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.

Dr. Heinrich Neumann, one of the world's greatest authorities on diseases of the ear, died last night in his apartment in the Hotel Franconia, 20 West Seventy-second Street, of a gastric ailment with which he was stricken while on a vacation at Lake Placid, N.Y. With him were his wife, Melitta, and son, John Neumann. Two daughters, Liza and Suzanne, are on their way here from Genoa on the Saturnia. He was 66 years old.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 6--The Finnish Cabinet decided today to send new instructions to Dr. Juho Paasikivi, head of the delegation in Moscow. The Cabinet reached complete agreement on the delegates' request for further instructions and the reply will be sent tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6--M.L. Annenberg's two racing news distributing companies won in Federal Court today an extension until Thursday noon of their right to transmit race results over interstate telephone and telegraph wires. Their clients number most of the bookmakers in the country.

BALTIMORE, Nov, 6--Owner W.L. Brann and Trainer Lou Schaefer, who sent Challedon out to win the 3-year-old championship, scored again today when Challephen won the $10,000 added Riggs Handicap with a gallant rush in the closing steps at Pimlico.

The State of Ohio, through its Attorney General, Thomas J. Herbert, and the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a petition requesting that the plan of integration of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, awaiting decision by the SEC, be denied.
LONDON, Nov. 6--The British Prize Court has just held its first session in the war.

Retail cooperative societies in Great Britain did a business totaling $1,316,325,000 in 1938, a gain of $50,000,000 or 3.8 per cent over 1937, according to figures of the Cooperative Union of Great Britain, which were issued here yesterday by the Cooperative League

A hundred students of New York University's downtown center demonstrated yesterday in Washington Square against the proposed plans of Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, for changing the layout of the park.

The Hudson Theatre will definitely house "I know What I Like" on Nov. 24, the real estate firm of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., having formally confirmed the lease of the premises by the Shuberts from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

NEW HAVEN Conn., Nov. 6-- Suiting the action to the word, Coach Ducky Pond emphasized his displeasure over Yale's showing against Dartmouth by sending the first and second varsity teams through a hard scrimmage today for the contest with Brown in the Bowl on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6--The outbreak of war in Europe had little if any effect on the plantings of wheat for harvest in 1940, and accordingly the Department of Agriculture expects a yield next year no larger than the last harvest, according to a survey of prospects which was made public here today.
Talk of forthcoming games and teams to be faced by the football teams of the city on Saturday marked the weekly luncheon of the Football Writers Association at Jack Dempsey's yesterday.

Four recently renovated Harlem tenements have been purchased by a newly formed firm of operators in a deal involving the payment of all cash.

James L. Ashley, secretary and treasurer of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., retired yesterday under the company's retirement system, it was announced by Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president. He had been an executive since the formation of the original International Nickel Company in 1902. Mr. Ashley will continue as a director.

Two WPA workers were thrown sixty feet into the water and drowned yesterday when a cable that was hoisting a girder into place on a bridge from Plum Island to Flatbush Avenue, in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, broke and dropped the seventy-fiveton girder into Plum Island Channel.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 6--Serious preparation for the allimportant Middle Three game with Lafayette at Easton next Saturday started for the Rutgers football team today as Coach Harvey Harman called out the entire squad, foregoing the usual easy Monday sessions.
The Holland-America liner Zaandam arrived yesterday from Europe with 175 passengers, seventyone of whom were United States citizens.

Dr. Frederick Adams Woods, noted American biologist and a scientist who played a leading role in the development of historiometry, died Sunday in Rome, Italy, after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday. His age was 66.

Copyright 1939, by The New York Time WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in France, Nov. 6--Over here the troops in the ne are as completely cut off from all forms of entertainment as though they were living on an ice floe at the North Pole.

The third night of the fifty-fourth annual National Horae Show last night presented a brilliant array of fashions in the ringside boxes and arena seats and a performance glowing with color in the ring during the parade of the international military teams, headed by the smart Essex Troop mounted band.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6--Wheat showed a firm undertone today after a slight dip in prices early. The market, however, failed to gather much momentum on the buying side.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6--The "ham-and-eggs" pension plan, which is declared by its promoters to be aimed primarily at revision of the State's monetary system, and eventually at revision of the monetary system of the United States, goes to California's 3,605,907 registered voters tomorrow after an election campaign which tops any "off-year" effort this State has ever seen before.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 (UP)--German newspapers reported today that "startling documents" taken from a British plane shot down on German soil had revealed that "as early as 1936 detailed preparations had been made by the British Air Force for attacks on Germany."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5--Republican leaders predicted today that the Republican candidate for Mayor, former Judge Robert E. Lamberton, would carry tomorrow's election by a narrow majority and most of the Republican county ticket would squeeze through despite the admitted strength of the fusion opposition.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 6--After recommendation by County Executive J. Russel Sprague, the Nassau County Board of Supervisors unanimously adopted this morning an ordinance authorizing the free distribution of copies of the proposed county budget.
A new attack of illness suffered by Kings County Judge George W. Martin gave rise yesterday to the possibility that the Martin removal proceedings before the State Senate might end this week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6--In an opinion illustrating the philosophy of Justice Frankfurter, the Supreme Court today condemned the action of a Federal bankruptcy court in ordering abandonment of eighty-eight passenger stations of the Old Colony Railroad without the consent of Massachusetts.

Considerable activity in the sale and rental of dwellings in Brooklyn is indicated in reports received yesterday from brokers operating in that borough. Multi-family as well as one and two family structures are involved.

LONDON, Nov. 6--Of 18,500,000 tons of British merchant shipping afloat at the outbreak of the war, German submarines, mines and surface raiders have been able to destroy only about 1 per cent, according to figures released today by the Admiralty.

Affidavits which American exporters must sign in making shipments of goods to belligerent countries under the new Neutrality Act were made public here last night at the United States Customs House. The oath which must be taken by the shipper specifies that all title to the merchandise being shipped has passed from the American supplier to a foreign government or business house buying the goods.

BERLIN, Nov. 6--The Reich Food Ministry announced today increases in the rations per person that may be bought for the month of December of 250 grams of meat, 250 grams of butter, six eggs and 375 grams of rice. For the four months beginning Nov. 20 the purchasable meat ration will he increased by 125 grams monthly, or about 60 grams more a person each week.

Pittsburgh's Pirates, who have not won a National Football League game since Whizzer White and Frank Filchock helped beat the Giants a year ago last October, had the misfortune to run up against Ace Parker and the Red Hot Dodgers under the lights at Ebbets Field last night.

The amplified voice of Michael J. Quill, candidate for re-election, echoed around the corner of Seventh Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street to a noonday crowd of 800 furriers yesterday despite the fact that a permit had been denied to the owner of a sound truck from which Mr. Quill spoke.

Pleased with the play of Columbia last Saturday, even though unbeaten Cornell finally triumphed by one touchdown, Coach Lou Little yesterday granted his regulars a day of rest. But the second team and scrubs went through a rigorous scrimmage at Baker Field. The first-string players will begin their workouts today for the Navy game Saturday at Annapolis.

A recommendation that the Florida East Coast Railway reorganize through issuance of $25,000,000 of new first-mortgage bonds bearing fixed interest of 2 per cent was issued yesterday by a committee for the company's $45,000,000 of Series A first and refunding 5 per cent bonds. The group is headed by A. M. Anderson, partner in J.F. Morgan Co. The company has $12,000,000 of first 4 outstanding.

Mrs. Lloyd Richards and Mrs. Rudkin Vanderbilt will give a supper dance on Dec. 2 at the Pierre to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Joan Patricia Richards and Miss Mimi Vanderbilt.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 6-- A nine-car Chicago-to-Boston express train was derailed today in a deep cut near the Westfield-Springfield line. Five persons were injured and a dozen others were bruised.

Tha plan designed to allow a resumption of Hollywood financing of Broadway plays, representing nearly three years of negotiations between the playwrights and motion-picture concerns, was unanimously adopted yesterday afternoon by members of the Dramatists Guild at their annual meeting in the Hotel Lincoln.

Deposits in Christmas clubs of mutual savings banks in seventeen States reached $61,384,914 and were made by 1,438,732 depositors, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks announced yesterday.

The deadlock of two and one-half months in new corporate bond financing will be broken next week, according to present plans of underwriters. Offering to the public is expected to be made on Nov. 16 by an underwriting group of fiftyseven members of $42,225,000 of bonds and notes of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 6-- Captain Torbert Macdonald worked with the Harvard varsity today and there is every reason to expect that he will play against West Point here on Saturday.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 (AP)--Orders creating "offices of trusteeship" in Poland were issued today by Field Marshal Hermann Goering, as chairman of the Council for National Defense, indicating that some form of government for German-occupied Polish territories was being organized.

BERLIN Nov. 6--Political and military quarters here attach significance to the fact that the press of Berlin is turning its attention more and more to the Mediterranean, the historic basin that may become the scene of the next dramatic developments in this strange war.

It was Tennessee against the country today as, for the third week in succession, the unbeaten, untied and unscored-on Volunteers held first place in The Associated Press national football ranking poll.

Emile Pfizer's Farndale and Thomas Hitchcock's Rioter probably will be the choices for the Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steeplechase, which will be the feature of the annual meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association at Belmont Park today.
Several farms in the Holmdel section of New Jersey were reported yesterday as having been sold through Paul R. Stryker, broker.

Shipments of rayon yarn in October totaled 34,100,000 pounds, compared with 32,900,000 pounds in September and 25,100,000 pounds in October, 1938, an increase of 35.8 per cent over a year ago, according to data issued yesterday by the Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

With the approach of the two Thanksgiving holidays, advertising campaigns by food manufacturers are being intensified and in most instances are running somewhat ahead of last year, agency executives reported yesterday. Typical holiday items, such as walnuts, cranberry sauce, puddings, etc., will be promoted heavily in the coming weeks.

The Maginot Line, in front of which German troops were again reported massing last week for an attack that has been long expected, is thought to be the strongest system of fortifications in the world, possibly even stronger than the famed German Westwall.
This seems to be open season for two-piano teams; within a week three combinations have appeared here. The third, Ida Deck and Andrew Haigh, played at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

TRENTON, Nov 6--Except for attacks on Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State Democratic leader, for his support of a $21,000,000 bond issue for relief and his opposition to a compromise settlement of unpaid railroad taxes, New Jersey's general election campaign ended quietly tonight.

The fate of the proposed constitutional amendment to legalize parimutuel betting on horse races and the composition of the new City Council were the major issues at stake as New York City voters prepared to go to the polls today in what is expected to be one of the quietest elections in many years.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 6-- For the first time since the competition was inaugurated in 1935 foreign-born professionals captured the Edward J. Gaffney Old Oaken Bucket, symbol of victory in the annual team match against Americanborn pros, seven matches to six, at the Crestmont Golf Club today.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 6 (AP)--Defeat of the Bigelow pension plan, drafted to make old Ohio couples of 60 $24,000 rich, was predicted tonight by one of its sponsors.

With contests heavily draped in tradition holding the center of the stage, an attractive program of eighteen battles is listed for schoolboy football teams throughout the metropolitan area today. Five games will be staged on New York City gridirons, five on Long Island and eight in New Jersey.

The Herman Knapp Memorial Eye Hospital, 500 West Fiftyseventh Street, a 70-year-old institution devoted to education and research as well as medical treatment, will pass out of existence on Jan. 1 and its work will be carried on by the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and Columbia University, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP)--Senator Carter Glass has told Vice President Garner that "no man in public service has had more of my confidence and affection than you."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Tuesday, Nov. 7--King Leopold of the Belgians and the Belgian Foreign Minister, Henri Spaak, arrived here unexpectedly late last night and discussed the international situation with Queen Wilhelmina at the Palace.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 6--Neither the American Legion nor the United States Government is paying any ground rental on the eight official, permanent burial grounds for the A.E.F., World War dead in France, England and Belgium.

An increase of one-fourth cent a quart in the price of milk was announced yesterday by William H. Marcussen, president of Borden's Farm Products. The increase, effective with home deliveries tomorrow morning, will bring the price of Grade B milk to 15 cents a quart, but probably will not affect the cost of milk sold in stores.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 6--Burgomaster Adolphe Max, known to all in Brussels as "Our Max," who won fame in the World War for his defiance of the German Army chiefs during their occupation of Brussels, died in his home today. He would have been 70 years old on New Year's Eve.

During the first two weeks of the sixty-first annual United Hospital Campaign, 4,000 volunteers workers have raised a total of $413,704, according to a report issued last night by Walter E. Hope, general chairman.
LONDON, Nov. 6--Cheered by the repeal of the United States arms embargo, most sections in the stock markets strengthened today although business still was of small dimensions.
BOSTON, Nov. 6--Admiral Byrd estimated tonight that twenty penguins had delayed his departure for Antarctica by about a day.

The Italian Pavilion, one of the most elaborate at the 1939 World's Fair, will be operated again next year, Admiral Giuseppe Cantu, Italian Commissioner General to the Fair, announced yesterday. A cable from his government authorized him to accept President Roosevelt's invitation, he said.

The first culinary congress organized in the United States came into existence yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, and before the first day of its existence was ended it became evident that the 200 "chefs and culinarians" from all parts of the country were determined to effect startling changes in their craft.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP)-- Four Federal agencies tonight prepared to spend as much as $33,500,000 in an effort to provide relief to 115,000 farm families suffering from drought and flood conditions in thirty-four States.
Fordham's football team, which successfully stood off the aerial barrage laid down by Rice last Saturday, is due to experience another when Indiana's Hoosiers invade the Polo Grounds this week-end.

Their 30-27 victory last Sunday over the Green Bay Packers enabled the Chicago Bears to regain the ground-gaining leadership and increase their scoring total to 200 points as the National Football League offensive averages continued ahead of last year's record-breaking figures.

GROTON, Mass., Nov. 6--Larry Noble apparently is too conscientious a football coach as far as his own welfare is concerned. That's the reason he was hobbling around on crutches today while his allconquering Groton School squad spruced up for the traditional St. Mark's game at Southboro Wednesday.

WEST NEW YORK, N. J., Nov. 6 --Harry Helmke, who won $31,000 on a sweepstake ticket in 1934, vowed to salt it away, and settled down to a conservative surburban existence, died today at the age of 42 in the Hudson County Hospital for Mental Diseases in Secaucus, described by officials and his relatives as "penniless."

TOKYO, Nov. 6--The Foreign Office Spokesman today confirmed the impression that the next phase of Japanese foreign policy would turn on the results expected to follow the advent of Wang Chingwei's Japanese-sponsored government in China.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 6--November storms today again brought warfare nearer to Denmark. The big German minefield south of the Oresund, time after time enlarged and now said to number tens of thousands of anchored mines, was obviously laid out in great haste.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn, by a four-to-one decision, granted yesterday an injunction restraining Westchester County from collecting a ten-cent toll levied on all motor vehicles traveling the Hutchinson River Parkway.

There is the story of an old bay duck guide ho believed in coaxing nature to follow his suggestion by making a votive offering. If it happened to be a windless, sunny day he would flip a dime into the water, look heavenward (to the north) and say: "Come on, ten cents' worth of wind and rain, please. We need some duck weather."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 6--The policy of Chile at the coming conference at Washington on intercontinental shipping and trade will be guided by information expected tonight from Carlos Davila of the Chilean delegation.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 6--The spiritual and material welfare of the American Negro presents an opportunity and a challenge to the Catholic Church that can be effectively answered through the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine, speakers emphasized tonight at a session of the National Catechetical Congress.
A number of one and two family dwellings as well as a building plot were among the properties in the Bronx reported yesterday as having changed hands.

The first American exhibition of paintings by the Spanish artist, Luis Quintanilla, opened with a preview yesterday afternoon in the Associatad American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. BERLIN, Nov. 6--Repeal of the arms embargo by the United States is being deprecated or soft-pedaled today by the press, which publishes comments showing such a strong similarity of outline that the purpose of the comment by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels on Saturday is clearly evident.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 6-- President Roosevelt will cast his vote in the State election tomorrow in the Town Hall, accompanied by his wife, who will return from a lecture tour in the morning. The President has never failed to return to his home for an election since he entered public life.

New York University's football squad, facing one of its major tests of the season Saturday against Missouri at the Yankee Stadium, went through a strenuous two-hour workout at Ohio Field yesterday. The second hour of practice was spent under floodlights.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., made a net profit in the first nine months of this year of $456,841 after depreciation and obsolescence, $160,000 estimated Federal income tax and other charges, Captain E.V. Rickenbacker announced yesterday in a report to stockholders.

John N. Harman, County Clerk of Kings County, whose term would have expired on Dec. 31, died last night of a heart attack at his home, 122 Ocean Promenade, Rockaway Park, Queens, after an illness of several weeks. He was born in Oswego, N.Y., sixty-eight years ago.

Calling the public's attention to the humanitarian work done by the American Red Cross each year, Mayor La Guardia asked all citizens yesterday to support the organization's annual drive for membership which runs from Saturday to Nov. 30.

Bonds drifted irregularly within narrow limits yesterday in typical pre-holiday trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnover in all bonds amounted to only $5,212,500, the smallest since Oct. 16 for a full five-hour session, and compared with $8,009,200 last Friday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6-- "The Life and Death of John Doe," by Richard Connell and Robert Presnell will be the first production venture by Frank Capra and Robert Riskin as an independent concern.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 6--The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States postal authorities started an investigation today into the receipt in several communities in Northern New Jersey of war propaganda mailed from Berlin, Germany, it was learned here.

The Manhattan football team, happy over its 26-0 defeat of Boston University, yesterday turned toward the sterner reality of clashing with the rugged University of West Virginia eleven at Morgantown next Saturday. Coach Herb Kopf sent the Jaspers through a two-hour practice session which ranged from running exercises to signal drill.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6--Two provisions of New Deal laws were unanimously upheld by the Supreme Court when it handed down the first opinions of the present term today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6--The Princeton football team today began preparations for its Ivy League battle against undefeated Dartmouth in Palmer Stadium Saturday, encouraged by the fact that it had come through the Harvard game without an injury of note.

Football came up with its surprise package of the season in the defeat of Michigan by Illinois, and anything that happens from here in will be taken without the flicker of an eyelid as just a plain, everyday upset, unless Tennessee lets down a whole tree-load of hosannachirping experts.

Clear chilly weather brought November back to normal yesterday after a severe blow reminiscent of the hurricane of 1938, had passed up and off the Atlantic Coast leavling heavy rain over a widespread area and snow in mountain sections.

The application of the United States Lines for the transfer of the registry of some of its ships to the flag of Panama because of the ban on American shipping to the ports of European nations at war, drew sharp criticism in marine labor circles yesterday and caused surprise among the operators of other shipping lines.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 6-- Westchester County officials listed Yonkers today as a tax-delinquent community for not having paid $950,328 due the county on Oct. 15.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6--Following is a summary with textual excerpts of the address today of PremierForeign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff as made public by Tass, Soviet news agency. Speaking before a meeting to celebrate the twenty-second anniversary of the October Revolution, he said:
Ralph Flanagan, middle-distance and distance free-style ace, was selected for four places on the 1939 All-America swimming team announced yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union.

CLEVELAND Wednesday, Nov. 8--Ohio voters killed the Bigelow $50-a-month-at-60 pension proposal yesterday. They rejected the plan by 3 to 1 in one of the heaviest offyear election votes in the State's history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP)--The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company of Winston-Salem, N.C., one of eight major tobacco concerns cited by the Federal Trade Commission for violation of the Robinson-Patman act, has filed an answer to the changes in preparation for a hearing on Friday.

It is probable that motorists in many parts of the nation will benefit by the decision of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn restraining, by injunction, Westchester County from the collection of a ten-cent toll on the Hutchinson River Parkway.

Following is the text of an address entitled "Our Cause, Now and After," by Viscount Halifax, British Foreign Secretary, as recorded yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES from a short-wave broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation:
PARIS, Nov. 7--Neither its personnel nor its material seems to justify, in the French view, the claim of Marshal Hermann Goering for the German air force that it holds the mastery of the air.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 7--The Finnish Cabinet sent new instructions today enabling its delegation in Moscow to resume the talks interrupted for the last few days. The government summoned the Speaker of Parliament and party leaders for a final consultation and they fully endorsed the instructions to the delegates.

The De Witt Clinton High School football team registered a 6-to-0 triumph over Stuyvesant yesterday at Randalls Island. A gathering of 8,000 fans watched the rivals in the thirty-first renewal of the annual Election Day series.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--A third application for license for an air transport service across the Atlantic was made to the Civil Aeronautics Authority today by the American Export Airlines, when hearings were resumed on the line's proposal to fly the ocean.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 7--Governor Keen Johnson was elected Governor for the four-year term beginning Dec. 12 and the entire Democratic State ticket won over the Republican nominees, election returns indicated tonight.
The Mataroa, a 12,390-ton British freighter, sent out a wireless message at 1:30 P.M. yesterday that she was being chased by a submarine about 700 miles east of Bermuda, according to Mackay Radio.

Apparel and textile firms figured largely in the commercial leasing activity reported yesterday when new space was taken and a number of renewals were listed.
PRINCETION, N.J., Nov. 7-- Princeton, expecting a hard game with Dartmouth here Saturday, staged a stiff drill today. Coach Tad Wieman seemed pleased with the blocking and plunging.

In a finish that would have called for a camera if there had been one in operation, Saluda from the Groton Stable of Mrs. Robert L. Winthrop won the Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steeplechase Handicap before a fashionable gathering of 10,000 at Belmont Park ...

Andrew S. Roscoe has been elected to the board of the Woodside National Bank. He has been its executive vice president since December, 1938, when he resigned as manager of the Astoria branch of the National City Bank.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7--On the basis of incomplete but representative returns from today's election, California has declined "ham and eggs."
Boys High is still among the city's unbeaten schoolboy football elevens as a result of a 21-0 triumph yesterday in the traditional contest with Alexander Hamilton.
"The Three Cornered Hat," Leonide Massine's ballet to the music of de Falla, had its first performance of the season by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.
The urge of Bernard McSorley, 22 years old, early yesterday morning for a "joy ride" in a stolen automobile led hours later to his arraignment in the Felony Court on a grand larceny charge.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Wisconsin-Michigan Power Company had made application for issuance and sale of 40,000 shares of $100-par ...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--A new cotton loan program for the 1939 crop which established for the first time a policy of location differentials was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

Most major importers and distillers pledged yesterday that they would strive to retain fair-trade protection for their products during the holiday season despite the pricewar threat, which has disrupted trade in past years, or any other eventuality.

A former laborer, policeman, city magistrate and county judge, William O'Dwyer, successful Democratic candidate for Kings County District Attorney represents the traditional "career man" in the American political set-up.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--Those familiar with the Congressional sentiment which produced cash-and-carry did not require twenty-four hours of reflection--as some government officials did--to realize that the Panama transfer plan of the United States Lines was full of high explosives.

A questionnaire seeking to establish the commercial practice with respect to containers now in use by the cosmetic industry was addressed to members yesterday by the board of standards of the Toilet Goods Association, Inc., after a warning that the Federal Food and Drug Administration has begun a campaign against "misleading or deceptive containers."
The return to form of Les Stanczyk and Bob Stoltz, who took part in regular practice at Baker Field yesterday, put Columbia's football team at full strength for the first time in three weeks.

LONDON, Nov. 7--The British Government has offered 100,000 to help Polish refugees, it was announced in the House of Lords tonight by Viscount Halifax, Foreign Secretary.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7--Reports that King Leopold of Belgium and Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands had issued an appeal for peace in Europe halted today fairly active buy ing of wheat that had resulted in a moderate upturn in prices, December coming within cent a bushel of the season's top.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 7--One of the most unusual of field trials was held today on the property of Charles L. Lawrance, who is dedicated to the proposition, "Why use two dogs when one will do as well."

Representatives of maritime labor in New York were divided yesterday on the proposed transfer of American passenger and freight vessels to foreign registry in order to avoid the limitations of American neutrality.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 7--The Republican party retained control of the Rockland County Board of Supervisors today by winning in three of the five county townships. With the voting the lightest in recent years, the Republicans also gained control of the four county offices contested today.

Chilean Army representatives continued their success last night in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, taking a commanding lead in the International low-score competition for the trophy presented by former President Arturo Alessandri of Chile.
For the first time since the Fusion movement dealt it a stunning body blow in 1933, Tammany Hall radiated election cheer last night.

Miss Virginia Penfield gave a tea yesterday at her home, 1,165 Fifth Avenue, for Miss Jane Gray, who will leave later this month with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Eugene Gray Jr., for Honolulu, Hawaii.

Improvement of Pan-American relations and understanding through an exchange of students and teachers at public expense was urged yesterday by Robert L. Stearns, newly-appointed president of the University of Colorado.
LONDON, Nov. 7--The House of Commons unanimously approved today a series of resolutions conferring borrowing powers on the Treasury upon which the National Loans Bill will be founded.

With the four morning papers all showing gains and the four evening papers registering losses, advertising linage in this group of eight New York dailies had an increase of .03 per cent for the first ten months of this year, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7-- George Raft will be teamed with James Cagney in "City of Conquest" at Warners, the studio announced today. The Aben Kandel yarn has been moved up on Cagney's schedule and will be his next picture.

BOSTON, Nov. 7--With an indirect criticism of President Roosevelt's proclamation designating Nov. 23 as a day of general Thanksgiving, Governor Saltonstall today proclaimed Nov. 30 as Thanskiving Day in Massachusetts.

OTTAWA, Nov. 7--The project of training 25,000 empire aviators every year in Canada is proving difficult to arrange. The trouble lies in the financing of the plan and to resolve this the services of soothsayers as well as auditors would seem to be necessary.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The current negotiations for a reciprocal trade agreement with Argentina were defended today by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, in a letter ...

Both California and Ohio have rejected the fantastic pension plans which were submitted yesterday to the voters of those States. Either proposal, if an attempt were made to put it into practice, would seriously have injured business and employment and made bankrupt the State government.

Chinatown was gala last night, for a serious purpose. Throngs swarmed through Mott and Pell Streets, at the juncture of which a program of music and speaking was staged during the evening, to help raise funds at the "Bowl of Rice Party" for war victims in the homeland.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The Maritime Commission, acting on instructions from President Roosevelt, postponed today approval of the transfer of eight United States ...

TRENTON, Nov. 7.--Highway construction expenditures totaling $11,814,632 for 1940 were requested today by State Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner from estimated revenues of $46,169,000 next year, in a report submitted to Governor A. Harry Moore.
In the office of the Skywriting Corporation at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday we sat with Andy Stinis, chief writer, and Dave De Blasio, his partner. Stinis called the sponsor on the telephone.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--Topflight government officials and all but two of the Representatives and Senators invited were absent tonight as the Soviet Embassy gave its annual party celebrating the 1917 Russian Revolution.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 7--The Democrats were swept into office in the city of Glen Cove in the only major upset of today's election in Nassau County. Thus, for the first time in six years, the Democrats find themselves in control of all but one of the major offices.
Several large apartments were involved in the leases for residential space reported yesterday by brokers throughout the city.

For more than three periods the N.Y.U. freshmen stayed close enough to demand a recount in their annual election day football struggle with the Fordham yearlings at Ohio Field yesterday. From a slight plurality, however, ...
The eight-story apartment house at 251 Fort Washington Avenue, in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, has been resold by A. Ruth Sons, operators, after an ownership of about a month.
The problem of the indifferent voter was illustrated yesterday, as it always is in "off-year" elections. Some 2,061,751 men and women in this city were registered and entitled to vote.
WITH THE BRITISH FORCES in France, Nov. 7--Years have slipped away since I spoke to a Commander in Chief of British troops in France.
Mrs. Wales Latham, chairman of the junior committee for this season's two Yorkville dinner dances, will give a tea today for members of her committee at her home, 122 East Eighty-second Street.

THE football players had better hurry along. "The North Wind doth blow and we shall have snow." Further than that, to the north and the west there already have been hockey games. It must be getting late.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 7 (AP)-- Cotton futures advanced approximately 50 cents a bale here today in quiet trading under small outside buying orders and covering by local shorts. Final quotations were steady, 9 to 10 points net higher.
LONDON, Nov. 7--After a promising start, the stock markets today became irregular near the close as activity declined. Earlier gains, however, in several sections generally were maintained.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP)-- The extent to which European war orders and natural economic trends forecast increased Treasury revenues probably will determine whether the administration proposes a new tax bill to Congress next session, Democratic leaders said tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 7-- County Attorney William A. Davidson of Westchester drafted an appeal to the Court of Appeals today from the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday which declared Westchester County's 10-cent toll on the Hutchinson River Parkway to be illegal.

"Life With Father," the Howard Lindsay-Russel Crouse play based on the late Clarence Day's novel of the same name, opens at the Empire tonight under Oscar Serlin's auspices. Mr. Lindsay and Mr. Crouse also have drawn on essays from two other of Mr. Day's books.

The election of Jonah J. Goldstein as judge of the Court of General Sessions marks a personal victory for the successful candidate over Tammany Hall and closes a bitter three-year fight between Mr. Goldstein and the Tammany leadership for the judgeship.

OTTAWA, Nov. 7 (Canadian Press) --Some forty commercial vessels have been called up for service in the Royal Canadian Navy since the start of the war, a spokesman for the Department of National Defense said tonight in the third of a series of talks on work of the department in wartime.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 7--The Dixie Clipper took off this morning for Lisbon via Bermuda and the Azores with twenty passengers and 1,721 pounds of mail. Eleven travelers were bound for Bermuda.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7--Government counsel said today that Moses L. Annenberg's racing news services took $7,724,531 in profits from 659 bookmakers in the Chicago area between 1933 and 1936.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The Civil Aeronautics Authority today designated the Newark Airport and the North Beach Airport as co-terminals for the New York-Northeastern New Jersey metropolitan area. The needs of the district, the CAA found, require the facilities of more than one airport.

PARIS, Nov. 7--"No statement will be given this evening by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs regarding the letter addressed to the heads of States of the belligerent countries by the Queen of the Netherlands and the King of the Belgians," the French Commissariat for Information announced tonight.
MOSCOW, Nov. 7--The biggest military show yet put on--according to veteran onlookers--marked today's Red Square celebrations of the twenty-second anniversary of the October revolution.

The other day a friend of ours sent his shotgun to the gunsmith for what he called a "routine overhaul." It had been seven years since it had received the attention of a gunsmith and he thought it was time.

Work against the forward pass, tackling and blocking for the linemen and a thorough signal drill marked yesterday's morning drill of the Fordham football team in preparation for the game with Indiana at the Polo Grounds Saturday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7-- Malcolm Farmer, Yale's athletic director, disclosed tonight that Head Football Coach Raymond W. (Ducky) Pond and his staff "will be retained" next season, squelching rumors of a probable change.
BERGEN, Norway, Nov. 7 (UP)-- Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, United States Minister to Norway, an-- nounced tonight after conferences with Captain Joseph A. Gainard of ...

BERLIN, Nov. 7--A semi-official news agency tonight issued an obviously inspired statement reviewing the first two months of the war. It summed up the German war potential and proclaimed the conviction of "German political circles" that the Reich was invincible.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 7-- The possibility of Federal action against Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party in the United States, on charges of conspiracy against the government was hinted in temporary White House circles here today.
Several changes in the New York Giants backfield are being planned by Coach Steve Owen for the game with the Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

PARIS, Nov. 7 (UP)--Military dispatches reported tonight that Germany's big guns of the Westwall, after six days of shelling of the French-held Forbach salient, appeared to have abandoned attempts to drive the French from the strategic position in the Saar Valley.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The city of Atlanta lost in the Supreme Court today an opportunity, for the present at least, to test the constitutionality of the National Bituminous Coal Act of 1937.

Up-State districts contributed enough to the passage of the Pari-Mutuel Amendment to forestall the charge that this legalization of race-track betting is the work of the sinful City of New York putting something over on the virtuous country districts.
Pari-mutuel betting on horse-racing won the sweeping approval of the voters of New York State at yesterday's election.

WITH BRITISH FORCES IN FRANCE, Nov. 7--The British troops of today are keeping cheerful, not with songs of their own homeland, as did their fathers in 1914, but with a sentimental ballad hammered out in New York's Tin Pan Alley. It begins, "South of the border down Mexico way."

Taking advantage of a firstquarter break for a score and then adding another touchdown in the second chapter on a 51-yard march, Erasmus Hall High downed its old Brookyn rival, Manual Training, 13 to 6, in the thirty-second struggle between the schools at Ebbets Field yesterday.

The centenary of Cezanne's birth is being observed this year, and the Marie Harriman Gallery (61 East Fifty-seventh Street) contributes in significant fashion with an admirable Cezanne show that opened to the public yesterday. It will be current until Dec. 2.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 7 --Yugoslavia's Minister to Turkey, M. Shumenkovitch, who returned last night, is understood to have brought details of an Anglo-Turkish plan to form a neutral Balkan bloc including Bulgaria.

With the Western Hemisphere a refuge of hope for a sick world, the press of the Americas must do its full share to promote understanding and cultural ties among the nations of the two continents, Mayor La Guardia and Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said yesterday.

After five fires of suspicious origin had been discovered in as many automobiles early yesterday morning in the vicinity of West End Avenue and Eightieth Street, the police arrested a middle-aged private chauffeur and charged him with arson.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Nov 7--The Republican party retained control of the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors in today's election. County Clerk Frank Markvart was elected to a third term of three years.
Three men and a woman were arrested early yesterday and were charged, with two other men already in the Tombs, with complicity in $500,000 in jewel robberies during the past four years.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 7-- Jasper McLevy, Socialist Mayor, was re-elected for his fourth twoyear term at today's election.

The second New York program of the season by the Philadelphia Orchestra. Eugene Ormandy conductor, given last night in Carnegie Hall, contained one work which in itself would have made the concert worth the journey.

Simon (Si) Goodfriend, one of New York's greatest baseball fans, who had been following the game since the Civil War, died Monday at his home, 210 West Ninetieth Street, after a week's illness, in his eighty-fifth year.

Chet Smolenski, Manhattan's sophomore end, returned to the first team yesterday as Coach Herb Kopf launched heavy preparations for Saturday's game with West Virginia University at Morgantown. Smolenski, who stands 6 feet 3, replaced Ellwood Varner, in an hour's scrimmage.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 7-- The East Orange and Nutley High School elevens battled to a 6-6 tie today before a record stadium crowd of more than 12,000. Contenders for the State Group 4 crown, neither team had been beaten, tied or scored upon before today.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 7 (AP)--William Edwin Chilton Sr., former Senator from West Virginia, publisher of The Charleston Gazette and for many years a Democratic leader in the State, died today at the age of 81.

The completion of a tree-planting program in Rockefeller Center "before dawn" yesterday marks a fi nal step in the plan to provide "a natural setting" for this vast building area, containing fourteen units valued at $100,000,000. The total number of trees, within and around the center, is 147.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 8 (UP) --The Japanese Foreign Office spokesman, commenting on American naval expansion plans, said today that "if such a plan is passed, we, as Japanese cannot remain indifferent."

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 7-- President Roosevelt stepped inside a green-curtained voting booth here today and selected his candidates in the State and county elections. The President was one of 851 other reg istered voters who passed through the village Town Hall. He voted as a "farmer."

LONDON, Nov.7--The war has robbed London of the Lord Mayor's show, an annual feast of pageantry ranking with the opening of Parliament and the trooping of the colors on the King's birthday as a great public attraction.

For nearly three hours on Ohio Field yesterday morning New York University's football forces devoted their attention to perfecting an airtight aerial defense in preparation for the game with Missouri at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The Association of American Railroads an nounced today that steps had been taken to prevent congestion at North Atlantic ports as the result of a possible large increase in traffic resulting from European orders, now that the new Neutrality Act was in force.

Martin of Worthington Valley was represented by the winner when Slow Motion, a 3-to-1 shot in the field of six, registered by a head.

Materially assisted by the sharp, cold weather, retail trade here spurted sharply yesterday and many stores made heavy percentage gains over the relatively poor showing of the 1938 election day volume.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--Exports by the United States in September showed a definite tendency toward higher volumes compared with the corresponding period in 1938, according to a new analysis issued today by the Department of Commerce.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 7-- Forty-four dinghy sailors elected to go out for the racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. In a good west-northwest breeze they completed seven contests.

WILLIAM ALLEN WHITE'S West begins at Buffalo and Pittsburgh and runs straight across the Mississippi and the Rockies to the Pacific.

Jamaica and John Adams, Queens high school rivals, battled to a scoreless deadlock in the eighth annual clash between the schools at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday. A crowd of 5,000 saw the battle. Adams won the seven contests against Jamaica prior to yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 7--Mayor Richard W. Reading, who was swept into office two years ago on a wave of anti-C.I.O. sentiment provoked by the 1937 sit-down strikes, went down to defeat today in Detroit's nonpartisan municipal election.

LONDON, Nov. 14--Increased allowances for dependents of soldiers, sailors and airmen were announced today by War Secretary Leslie Hore-Belisha following criticism that high rents and the increased cost of living had outstripped existing grants.

Following the general line of the recommendations of the recent Public Examining Board headed by Roswell Magill, the New York Stock Exchange committee on member firms ruled yesterday that Stock Exchange houses must send up-to-date financial statements to customers who request them and must notify customers of the availability of such reports.

There was ill-concealed resentment in Stock Exchange circles yesterday at SEC criticism of the new rules for remuneration of registered representatives of member firms. In the first place, members underlined the commission's statement that it was none of its business.

ALBANY, Nov. 14--The State law of 1937, levying a personal income tax on the salaries of State officials, was upheld today in a test case brought by former Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black of New York City. The decision, in effect, held that the act was constitutional.

A financing program involving issuance and sale of $32,125,250 of first-mortgage bonds and new common stock by the Consumers Power Company, largest operating unit of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation in the North, has been approved by the Michigan Public Utilities Commission, it was announced here yesterday by Wendell L. Willkie, president of Commonwealth and Southern.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--Senator Borah of Idaho said today that he has no intention of bolting the Republican party, although some circles so interpreted a statement in which he told of the importance of independent voting.

After weeks of whispered rumors and reports going the rounds practically since the close of the world series, the Giants broke down and confessed yesterday at a luncheon in the New York A.C. that they would give night baseball a whirl in 1940 at the Polo Grounds.
A decided improvement in investment sentiment was reflected yesterday in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
LONDON, Nov. 14--Today's session in the stock market was quiet. Although the tone continued firm there were few noteworthy movements.
The Columbian Carbon Company and its subsidiaries showed a net profit of $2,380,330 in a report for the first nine months of this year issued for publication today.

Election of three Democrats and one Republican as the four Queens members of the new City Council was indicated last night as the count of proportional representation Council ballots in that borough drew toward a close. The Queens count will be finished this afternoon.

Being anything but a hack, Robert Ardrey sets his newest play in a lighthouse in Lake Michigan and bids the world cheer up. "Thunder Rock" is what he calls it, and the Group Theatre put it on at the Mansfield last evening as the first item in its ninth season.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it had ordered 64,000 tons of rail and accessories for delivery in 1940 at a cost of $5,700,000, bringing total disbursements for equipment and heavy material in the last four months to $17,200,000.

The World's Fair continued to sign exhibitors for the 1940 season yesterday. The Borden company, one of the large exhibitors this year, will participate again. Occupying 80,000 square feet, the Borden exhibit attracted 7,743,000 visitors.

Police Commissioner Valentine was directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Thomas F. Noonan to issue taxi licenses to a newly formed partnership which bought two used cabs from the Diamond ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 15 (AP)--The Langston (Okla.) Lions moved alone along an undefeated and untied trail today, heading the nation's Negro football parade because three field goals eliminated a competitor.
Frank Hanson of the Columbia University Club, second in the seeding, advanced through the second round of the Princeton Club's annual squash tennis tournament yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 15-- Dr. H.H. Kung, Chinese Premier and Finance Minister, conferred for three hours Monday night with the Soviet Ambassador, Alexander Panaouchine. They were said to have discussed means for improving Chinese-Soviet trade and other issues. The talk followed a dinner at which Mr. Panaouchine, formerly the Russian Commercial Attache in Chungking, was the host.

ROME, Nov. 15 (UP)--In connection with Premier Mussolini's striving for peace in the Balkans, authoritative quarters today denied reports from Bucharest that Italy would sound out Hungary and Bulgaria in an effort to draw them into a six-power Balkan peace conference.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 15-- With the University of Delaware as the next home rival, Coach Glen Harmeson of Lehigh gave the Engineers a light workout today, although there are few injuries on the squad. Delaware is the last game before the Lafayette contest in Bethlehem.

The two five-story fire-retarded tenements at 17 and 19 East 117th Street, containing fifteen suites each, have been sold by Dotton Holdings, Inc., to Harold Freeman for cash above a first mortgage of $25,000. The Dunwol Realty Company acted as brokers and John Blumenthal was attorney for the purchaser.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Nov. 15-- New York hunters have been unusually fortunate in the weather conditions on their various opening days this year, and the opening of deer season in the Catskill area this morning was no exception.

City College's basketball team will play sixteen games during the 1939 40 season, it was announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics. A pre-season game with the Evening Session quintet, to be played at the Downtown gym Nov. 25, is also slated.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject tto final adjustments.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 15--Captain Whit Miller of the Dartmouth football team returned to active work today as he took part in one of the longest scrimmage sessions of the year.
Money market continued quiet and quotations for all sections remained unchanged.

Fourteen sections of department stores recorded gains in advertising linage for October in New York City newspapers, as compared with 1938, while twenty-three had losses, according to a study of figures issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc. Total volume for the month was 3,293,849 lines, against 3,341,796 lines a year previous.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--Spokesmen for thirty-nine Governors of States attending today the National Conference on Labor Legislation offered their services to promote a reconciliation between the warring factions of labor.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15--Ed Allen, sophomore from Batavia, N.Y., was in the wing back position on the Pennsylvania varsity today in place of Bob Stephens. At the close of the long offensive drill Head Coach George Munger said Allen would start against Michigan here Saturday.

Today's events: PhilharmonicSymphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P.M.; Sheila Tara, soprano, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; Marion Rous, lecturer, Carnegie Hall Art Gallery, morning; Vladimir Brenner, pianist, Academy of Allied Arts, afternoon; American Recorder Society, Studios of Music Education, 8:30 P.M.

More than 100 men attended yesterday the semi-annual New York City luncheon of the Alumni Association of the Lawrenceville School, held at the Downtown Athletic Club. Dr. Allen V. Heely, headmaster of the school, spoke of the progress of the alumni fund which provides scholarships at Lawrenceville. John Langhorne of Morristown, N.J., president of the association, presided.

Maurice Brill said it was strange, when you looked back down the years, how little you remembered. He said here he was in his seventyfirst year when memory's ledger should be fairly full; yet most of the crises of youth that had seemed soul-searing when they happened had completely faded.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday by P.B. Sawyer, president, shows a net income after all expenses and charges of $7,676,822.

An anti-La Guardia City Council, able, in spite of a possible lack of Democratic votes, to override the Mayor's veto of Councilmanic acts, was indicated yesterday as the count of the proportional representation ballots for Council membership was brought to a close in every city borough but Brooklyn.

Many readers of this newspaper must have been particularly interested in the dispatches we have received and published during the last few days from Germany.

Although the local offices of the Work Projects Administration received authorization yesterday for the absorption of 3,200 unemployed seamen in the Port of New York there was no indication as to how the seamen would be selected or how they may be employed.
With close to 300 in attendance, the Rod and Gun Editors Association held its annual dinner in the private dining room of the Jacob Ruppert Brewery last night.
CHICAGO, Nov, 15--The Professional Golfers Association, in a surprisingly speedy and harmonious session, dealt itself a "new deal" today.

Michael J. Madigan, editor of The Catholic News, weekly newspaper of the Archdiocese of New York, since 1894, died in his sleep Tuesday night at his home, 211 Maple Avenue, Rockville Centre, L.I., in his seventy-third year.
Frederick J. Griffiths, who last month was made executive vice president of the Copperweld Steel Company and head of a new steel division, has been elected a director of the company.
The battleship Texas, one of the first large men-of-war to visit New York City since the European war started, is scheduled to steam into port today for a five-day visit.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 15--Peiping reports that are received in Shanghai with reserve declare Chinese Communist troops under General Peng Teh-hua exchanged fire with central government troops under General Chu Shao-liang in Eastern Kansu Province.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)--The Erie Railroad told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that sharp improvement in earnings recently had justified fully its own proposal for reorganization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP)--The Association of American Railroads reported today that ninety Class I railroads had estimated operating revenues of $339,895,107 in October, compared with $289,279,715 in October ...

PAWTUCKET, P.L., Nov. 15 (AP) --Five O Five, Providence-owned 15-to-1 shot entry that had not been doing much lately, closed fast today to score an upset victory in the feature race at Narragansett Park. Eighth the last time out, the Ben F. Lister colorbearer, making her first start under Trainer C. Murphy, covered the six furlongs in 1:12 2-5.

The two aides in the longshoremen's strike conferred yesterday afternoon for the first time since the strike began thirteen days ago. They were drawn together by Tom M. Finn of the conciliation service of the United States Department of Labor.
"No Code to Guide Her" will not arrive at the Playhouse on Saturday evening, having postponed its premiere to a later date, as yet undetermined.

Two Lockheed-14 bombers arrived from Atlanta, Ga., at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. They will be crated in Hangar 8 and lightened to Staten Island to await shipment to England. A total of twenty-six such planes have arrived at the Brooklyn airport to date.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP)--St. Mary's Gaels of California stopped here today to practice, but Coach Edward (Slip) Madigan was not around. Madigan, bothered by a cold, remained on the train and the drill was directed by Assistant Coach Red Strader.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Nov. 16--Pierce Butler, 73-year-old Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, died today.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of Nov. 14. 1939, upon the eligible list of holders of license as teacher of accounting and business practice in day secondary schools other than junior high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted licenses, as indicated.
DETROIT, Nov. 15 (UP)--Governor Dickinson interceded today for an ousted student editor at the University of Detroit who wrote an editorial criticizing the Governor's "puritanical attitude."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 (AP)-- Inspector Jerry Desmond said today that a check of fingerprints established that an apparent amnesia victim was Frank Marquis, a stamp collector of 1 Ann Street, New York, who disappeared from his home Aug. 15.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 15--Kayak II, the pride of the pampas, ended his 1939 racing campaign in a blaze of glory today by winning the $12,850 Bowie Handicap at Pimlico in record time.

The nineteen passes completed by Davey O'Brien of the Eagles against the Packers last Sunday for a new National Football League record, was the outstanding individual achievement of the week, according to the statistics released yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 15--Oscar Straus, famous composer of Viennese waltzes and operettas, has been naturalized as a French citizen, it was announced today. He has lived in Paris for many years.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 15 --(AP)--The Atlantic City Sea Gulls opened their hockey season tonight by chalking up a 24-0 victory over the New York All-Stars in a charity game. The Sea Gulls shattered the United States amateur scoring record, eclipsing their own mark of twenty-two goals. Norm Tustin made six goals.

The service of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities to families on the economic borderline was praised by Mrs. George E. Brower, chairman, at a luncheon of the agency's family service committee yesterday in the Candlelight Restaurant, Brooklyn. The bureau seeks $125,000 to complete its budget of $383,992 for 1940.
Contracts for quarters in buildings along Broadway in the downtown and Times Square areas were among a large volume of business leases reported yesterday.
Hamilton D. Schwarz has joined the New York office of Lazard Freres Co.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (UP)--Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's weekly "war bulletin" will be read in the House of Commons tomorrow by Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, it was announced tonight. Mr. Chamberlain is confined to his home by gout.
The net income of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad in October ap proximated $1,700,000, it was disclosed at the company's offices yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP)--Princess Stefanie Hohenlohe-Waldenburg, former political representative of Viscount Rothermere to Adolf Hitler, lost a breach of contract suit today against the British publisher. Lord Rothermere had testified he paid her around $250,000 for less than six years' service.

Seven past presidents of the National Association of Credit Men will be honored at a testimonial dinner to be given in the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 4 by the New York Credit Men's Association, affiliated with the national group, it was announced yesterday.
Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company common stock, $50 par value, and 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $50 par value, have been suspended from dealings in the New York Stock Exchange.

Pressure from steel consumers for delivery provides strong evidence that much of the production of the steel industry is quickly passing into finished products and that inventories of most consumers still are far below normal, according to The Iron Age.

Lou Little of Columbia and Jimmy Crowley of Fordham were deep in conversation. There was not a smile on either face, an extremely unusual thing in itself, for whenever the pair meet wit crackles and laughter explodes. But this was serious.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 (AP)--Minette de Lozier, World War nurse, who was decorated several times by the American and French Governments for outstanding service, died today.
Pledges of $13,125 were received by the Italian Welfare League at a dinner last night at the Hotel Plaza, which opened a drive for $50,000 to cover a two-year period.
Several figures of international note were listed among the new apartment tenancies reported yesterday.

Time can't be arrested for speeding, but it is something of a surprise to find that the Rev. Samuel Atkins Eliot of Boston, formerly of Denver and Brooklyn, is a bit over 77. He has just ended his fiftieth year in the ministry.

An accountant for Fritz Kuhn, German American Bund leader, who is on trial in General Sessions charged with theft of bund funds, yesterday examined the books of the bund in preparation for Kuhn's defense, scheduled to open this morning.

A son was born last Thursday to Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Niles Doumaux of Bayside, Queens, at Parsons Hospital, Flushing, Queens. Mrs. Doumaux is the former Miss Anita R. Cardozo, daughter of Ernest A. Cardozo of this city and the late Mrs. Cardozo. The child, the couple's second, will be named for his father.

A large apartment house, a two-story business building near the Parkchester housing development of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and a taxpayer were among the Bronx properties figuring in deals reported yesterday.

A recommendation that the name of the Colorado Southern Railway be changed to the Fort Worth Denver Railway is contained in a letter sent to C. S. stockholders yesterday by Ralph Budd, president. An application for the approval of a unification of the railways is before the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Two garage buildings, comprising the entire blockfront on the east side of Morgan Avenue, between Lombardy and Anthony Streets, Brooklyn, have been sold by Ida Goldberg to Alfred Ambrogi.

The opening gun in the sports world's war on infantile paralysis will be fired tonight at an informal beefsteak dinner given by the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday in the north ball room of the Hotel New Yorker.

Two burlap steamers, each carrying more than $1,000,000 worth of goods consigned to American importers, had not arrived yesterday, ten days after they were due, and burlap traders were growing increasingly concerned for their safety.
President Roosevelt has let it be known that he is not in favor of deputizing volunteers to help the authorities run down spies, conspirators, saboteurs, loose talkers and other unpleasant people.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (UP)--The International Rubber Regulation Committee today increased permissible export quotas for the first three months of 1940 to 80 per cent of standard tonnages, compared with the present level of 75 per cent.
NEW GLOUCESTER, Me., Nov. 15 (AP)--The Maine Fish and Game Department was trying today to drown hundreds of fish.

With fourteen players on a side, an intra-club match was contested at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. Frank J. Marshall, former United States champion, led one team, and Raoul Echeverria captained the other.

An enrollment of an additional 6,000 nurses in the first reserve section of the Red Cross is needed for an expansion of service in home care, disaster relief, rural public health and military duty, Mrs. August Belmont, member of the board of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, reported yesterday.

The Fordham football team was sent through a stiff three-hour drill yesterday in preparation for the traditional encounter with St. Mary's at the Polo Grounds Saturday. One of the developments of the session was that the Maroon will adhere to the practice of the last two games by alternating two sets of halfbacks.

The volume of business of the International Paper and Power Company during the three moths ended on Sept. 30, last, was at the highest level for any quarter since 1937, Richard J. Cullen, president, stated in the financial report announced yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Rumania today accepted the invitation of Grover Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, to exhibit again at the New York World's Fair next Summer. Mr. Whalen officially extended the invitation today.

Net sales of McKesson Robbins, Inc., amounted to $13,461,332 for October, according to the preliminary report announced yester day. This is a gain of $284,071, or 2.16 per cent, over sales of $13,177,261 in October a year ago.

To aid the charitable activities of All Souls Unitarian Church, a twoday Autumn Festival will be held today and tomorrow in the church's Fellowship Hall at Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue. PARIS, Nov. 15--What little activity is reported from the RhineMoselle front is now occuring mostly in the Haardt sector, that thickly wooded and rugged plateau extending from the Ohrenthal salient to the Rhine Valley. TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 16--With the approach of the year-end the Japanese and Soviet Governments are beginning preliminary talks for fishery lease agreements. Those talks usually finish in mid-April at the last minutes before the fishing commences.
The New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad started yesterday court action to prevent the Erie Railroad from placing the Erie Terminals Railroad Company in bankruptcy.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 15-- After what happened up at Cambridge Saturday (Harvard 15, Army 0) one naturally expected to find Head Coach Bill Wood to be in anything but a benign mood.

An injury suffered by a seaman aboard the steamship West Calumb during a storm at sea in August, 1938, was the basis for an award of $48,000 to the seaman yesterday by Federal Judge John W. Clancy. The recipient is Edmund Shelton, 38 years old, who was permanently disabled by the injury. The ship was owned and operated by the United States Maritime Commission.

Copies of Federal Judge John C. Knox's opinion in the disbarment of Louis S. Levy from Federal court practice have been sent to the grievance committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, which prosecutes disbarment from the State courts, it became known yesterday.
After advancing steadily more than cent a pound in five trading sessions, prices on the Cotton Exchange reacted yesterday and ended with losses of 5 to 17 points from the previous close.

PEMBERTON, N.J., Nov. 15-- Abraham Hornor, assistant general manager of the Hudson River Day Line of New York, died last night at his home near here at the age of 74. He had been ill three months. Sale of a New York Curb Exchange seat for $10,000, unchanged from a deal on the day before, was reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 15--Support of the "more than 4,000,000 members of the Congress of Industrial Organizations" was pledged to the United Automobile workers of America--C.I.O., in its dispute with the Chrysler Corporation at a mass meeting held in Cadillac Square this afternoon.

TRENTON, Nov. 15--New Jersey will have about $8,200,000 at most for educational purposes for the year 1940-41, whereas budget requests totaling $10,000,000 already have been received, it was disclosed today at a hearing before Budget Commissioner Audley H.F. Stephan.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 15--Five "Flying Fortresses" of the United States Army Air Force arrived here today to take part in the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of Brazil's republican governmen. Despite rain, a large crowd gathered at Campo dos Affonsos, the military air field, to cheer their landing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15-- Princeton went through a spirited practice on pass offense and defense today. Coach Tad Wieman seemed pleased with the squad, which was stimulated quite a little by the cold weather that descended on University Field.

The Brooklyn College football team went through a long workout yesterday afternoon. While the backs and ends practiced passing, the linemen went through a blocking drill. The varsity then ran through plays in dummy scrimmage against the scrubs.

THE new China rising out of the old, the China of the Dowager Empress Tzu Hsi evolving into that of Marshal Chiang Kai-shek, is the theme of Lin Yutang's rich and satisfying novel published today. He calls it "Moment in Peking," but the moment is in fact an era--a matter of nearly forty years of births, marriages, deaths, social and political revolution.
The fiftieth anniversary celebration at Barnard College culminated yesterday in a virtual commencement program, starting the institution on its second half century of service.

TOLEDO, Nov. 15 (UP)--Because of lack of funds, Toledo's public schools will be closed for six weeks beginning Nov. 23, and will reopen sometime after Jan. 1, the Board of Education said after a meeting last night.

Dave Reggel, 62 years old, a musician, was found dead of gas poisoning late last night in the apartment in which he lived at 360 Central Park West. The body was found by his wife, Ada. Buyers for stores were reported to be expecting an average increase in Christmas trade of 8 to 12 per cent over 1938, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary. A warning against smugness at this Thanksgiving season was given yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw, preaching at the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Broadway at 174th Street. He wondered whether we deserve all our boons.

A field of twelve teams will respond to the starter's gun tonight at Madison Square Garden and the bike race will be on. The pedallers, who will set out on their circular safari at 9 o'clock, will ride continuously, save for interruptions forced by accidents, until 11 o'clock Saturday night.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 19--It was officially announced that a German Heinkel plane had fired at a Netherland patrol plane this afternoon above the Netherland coast 100 yards off Schiermonnikoog. The German plane sped away to the northeast.

PARIS, Nov. 19--The general price rise continues on the Bourse here. There was a slight reaction, but recovery occurred at the opening on Friday and went through the session. The whole list without exception finished with substantial gains over the previous week.

Nine families formerly engaged in the diamond industry in the Netherlands and Belgium were reported yesterday as having taken up residence in this city through the Apartment Renting Company, Inc., broker.

Unmindful of the biting cold, 19year-old Leslie MacMitchell, New York University sophomore, strode majestically to a brilliant victory in the thirty-first annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

The recital given by Albert Spalding last night in Carnegie Hall revealed a violinist who is an exceptional musician as well as virtuoso at his best, and introduced Mr. Spalding's unaccompanied sonata for the violin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)-- Representative May of Kentucky said in a statement tonight that "Leftist" officials of the Administration were preparing a new attack against private electric utilities.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20--Counsel for the Republic Steel Corporation sought the aid of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals here today in defense of a Republic Subsidiary, the Union Drawn Steel Company, Beaver Falls, accused by the National Labor Relations Board of having violated the Wagner Act.
Although Millen Brand's novel, "The Outward Room," may not seem like ideal stage material, Sidney Kingsley has made a deeply moving play out of it. "The World We Make" he calls it.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 20-- The Westchester County Park Commission's request for a $70,000 appropriation to avoid a deficit in its 1939 budget was granted today by the Board of Supervisors by a vote of 27 to 8.
A flat issue of veracity between a German-American Bund member named Willy Leudtke and Daniel Kirchman, a lawyer associated with James D.C. Murray, was raised at the trial of Fritz Kuhn, bund leader.
