DETROIT, Nov. 20--A session here of the full committee to investigate un-American activities is warranted by the extent of subversive activities in Detroit by foreign agents, Chairman Martin Dies said here today.

Unable to tell a coherent story after seven hours of questioning, Detective Louis Quinn, 31 years old, was arrested yesterday accused of shooting his wife, Mrs. Regina Quinn, 28, in their apartment on the top floor of 432 West Fortieth Street.
CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 20-- Agitation for more assistance to wheat growers continues to harass the government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, a C.I.O. affiliate, was accused today of carrying on "a campaign of misrepresentation" against the Maritime Commission in opposing the plan of the government body to give training with pay in its schools to seamen left jobless by the withdrawal of United States ships from service under the Neutrality Act.

The New York A.C. racquetwielders took undisputed possession of first place in Class B of the Metropolitan League squash tennis play by turning back the Crescent A.C., 4 to 1, on the Winged Foot courts last night.
Mail orders received in the wholesale markets here yesterday were numerous, but the size of the average commitment was fairly small. Merchants ware reported filling in on seasonal stocks.
Hampered by a big injury list, the Manhattan football team yesterday began work for Saturday's game with Villanova at the Polo Grounds, which will close the Jaspers' 1939 campaign.

Ivy League and Big Ten championships will be settled and the race for national, Rose Bowl and Sugar Bowl awards will be clarified this week as the curtain falls on the football season for most of the teams of the East and the Middle West.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 20 (AP)--State and Federal officials joined with friends and relatives in final tribute at funeral services today for Pierce Butler of St. Paul, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, who died on Thursday in Washington.

Earl Browder, Communist leader, admitted yesterday that, like "the most aristocratic society," he often had "traveled under pseudonyms." He made the statement to reporters after he had pleaded not guilty to Federal charges of having violated the passport laws.

POSEN, German Poland, Nov. 20--A special court in Posen today passed a sentence of death on Henry Pawlowski, 21-year-old Polish youth charged with complicity in the lynching of two German nationals on Sept. 3, before German troops captured the city.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20-- "The Count of Luxembourg," Franz Lehar's musical, has been purchased by Paramount as a starring vehicle for Allan Jones.
The Fordham football team came through its fourth successive major victory at the expense of St. Mary's on Saturday without incurring any injuries, it was learned yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 20 (AP)-- Baron Hilmar von dem BusscheHaddenhausen, former German Minister to Argentina and, in 1903, first secretary of the German Embassy in Washington, died here last night at the age of 72.

LONDON, Nov. 20--A definite statement as to the date when the rationing of bacon and butter will be introduced will be made as soon as possible after next Thursday when it is hoped that the registration of all the people on these islands for rationing will be finished.

Directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. declared yesterday a year-end dividend of $3.25 a share on the common stock, bringing payments for the year to $7 a share, compared with a final dividend of $1.50 and $3.25 total payments in 1938.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--Declaring that the way collections of Federal taxes have been coming in "gladdens our hearts," Senator Harrison, chairman of the Finance Committee, said today, after luncheon with President Roosevelt, that "we may be able to get along without a tax bill" at the next session of Congress.
Preparations for Thanksgiving feasts to mark Thursday's holiday were begun yesterday in shelters for the homeless and philanthropic agencies, as well as in private homes.

Another step toward consummation of the plan of reorganization of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company and associated concerns was made yesterday when the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals dismissed an appeal from Judge Alfred C. Coxe's order approving the plan.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20--The official statement here that a common ground has been reached in the effort to promote a Soviet-Japanese trade agreement, though no surprise, indicates more positive progress than does the simultaneous announcement of the establishment of a mixed commission to settle the Manchu-Mongol border dispute.
The New York Social Register for 1940 disclosed yesterday a few changes in the listing of names of prominent New York families, mostly as the result of marriage and divorce in the last year.

American Jewish women must band together as the guardians of Jewish children who have been left without homes by war and racial persecution, speakers declared yesterday at the first annual meeting of the National Youth Aliyah (Immigration) Committee of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.
If the people of Golden, Col., elect Coach Johnny Mason mayor, they will have to erect a statue to his ablest pupil, Lloyd Madden.

MONTREAL, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press)--Three good reasons why the Toronto Maple Leafs are leading the National Hockey League were revealed tonight in the league's first official scoring list of the season, which shows tie Leafs' ace line of Gordon Drillon, Syl Apps and Bob Davidson holding the first three places.

QUEBEC, Nov. 20--Publishers in the United States who buy newsprint from Canadian mills will not be called on to pay higher prices for the commodity in the first quarter of 1940, newsprint men here said this afternoon.

DALLAS, Nov. 20 (AP)--Corinne Maddox took two pistols from her handbag today in Main Street and shot down Brooks C. Coffman, a lawyer of 40, accused of stabbing her last Spring because she refused to accompany him to California.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 20--Cheap production of a protein constituent essential to the maintenance of human and animal life was announced by Professor Henry B. Hass, head of the department of chemistry of Purdue University, at a meeting of the Rochester Section of the American Chemical Society here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)-- Ways of increasing to Latin-American countries maritime services which have been curtailed by the European war were discussed by the Inter-American Economic Committee at a plenary meeting today.
Louis S. Levy, veteran New York City attorney, announced yesterday that he would appeal from the decision of Federal Judge John C. Knox directing his disbarment from practice in the Federal courts.

HAVANA, Nov. 20--Delegates accredited to the American nations which are members of the International Labor Organization at Geneva were in Havana tonight preparatory to the opening of the Second Inter-American Labor Conference, scheduled for tomorrow, at which they will study labor problems peculiar to the Americas.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 20-- Karim Bakadan Fozol, deputy shipping master of Calcutta, India, has flown to Australia to endeavor to persuade the fifty Lascars who deserted from a British freighter last week to take the vessel to India.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 20-- William D. Murray, New York lawyer, a founder and leader of the Boy Scouts of America and for nearly half a century internationally prominent in the Young Men's Christian Association, died this morning at his home here after a brief illness. His age was 81.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 20--Samuel Nesbitt Evins Sr., prominent Atlanta lawyer and civic leader, died here today at the age of 68. He had been a resident of Atlanta since 1893 and was a former City Councilman and a former member of the Board of Education.
Plans calling for a new $400,000 apartment house in Brooklyn, and two costing a total of $640,000 in Forest Hills, Queens, were filed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20--Wheat futures fluctuated today in an erratic manner within a range of about 1 cent a bushel, averaging higher on buying induced by the failure of rain to materialize over the dry area in the Winter Wheat Belt west of the Missouri River.

Representatives of the nineteen commercial banks comprising the New York Clearing House Association will attend at noon today a special meeting in the Clearing House to vote on a plan to end the periodic bank examinations of members made by the association's own staff of examiners.

After a spirited debate on the proposed merger of the Lincoln and Horace Mann Schools, with the whole broad question of experimental education under discussion, 250 members of the Lincoln School Parent-Teacher Association decided last night to defer formal action on the report of Dr. Luther H. Gulick, director of the Institute of Public Administration, recommending the merger.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--Over the protest of the American Federation of Labor, the right to become the sole bargaining agency for workers in a factory with a $1,000,000 annual payroll was awarded to the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) by a two-to-one decision in the District of Columbia Court of Appeals today.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 20-- Civil and military power was further concentrated in the hands of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek by the action of the Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] today, naming General Chiang the president of the Executive Yuan, the chief executive organ of the civil government.

PARIS, Nov. 20--Oscar Straus, Viennese "waltz king," disclosed today that he is composing a series of songs for Allied soldiers to sing as they fight against the nation that absorbed his native Austria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--How stockholders of some management investment companies were "sold down the river" in certain cases where the management, faced by economic reverses, sought to "get out" without bankruptcy is related in a report sent to Congress today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BERLIN, Nov. 20--Chancellor Hitler was reported unofficially tonight to have sent Heinrich Himmler, chief of the Gestapo--the secret police--and high-ranking Storm Troop leaders to Prague to take charge of the "restoration of order" in the former Czech capital.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 20--This week Denmark starts trade negotiations with both Germany and Britain.

The New York Life Insurance Company sold to William Bruckner the four-family building at 1,567-73 Maple Avenue, Hillside, N.J., through Max Tieger Co., brokers, who also sold for the Ursino Realty Company to John Schade the apartment house at 1 Cedar Street, Garwood.

Harry A. Kahler, former chairman of the executive committee of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, interrupted his mail fraud and conspiracy trial in Federal Court yesterday to plead guilty to the fourteen-count indictment.

"Aries Is Rising," a comedy in which an astrologer settles the complications of a varied assortment of people, opens this evening at the Golden Theatre under the banner of a new producing firm, Harry R. Irving and Michael Dolan.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20--At the annual meeting today of stockholders of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, Daniel Willard, president, referred to the improvement in the company's business in the last four months.

La Guardia Field in Queens yesterday became the center of training for airplane pilots.

A 34-year-old former boxer, on parole from Sing Sing, yielded meekly at 1:30 P.M. yesterday to two detectives who arrested him for robbery, in front of the La Salle Residence Club, 465 Central Park West, where he had occupied a fourth floor room for a week.

SWAKOPMUND, Southwest Africa, Nov. 20--The German liner Windhuk, of 16,662 tons, which Friday slipped out of Lobito, Angola, where she was moored since the outbreak of the war, has begun a wartime career, for which she was especially built in 1936, according to members of the German community there.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20--In connection with the twentieth anniversary of the Communist International of Youth, a round-up story reporting the anti-war activities of youth in many countries is published today in Pravda, Communist party organ.

Politics sang low at Hyde Park on Sunday. Only for a moment, when Mr. Roosevelt broke away from his prepared speech, did the reporters dream of eight-column headlines over their Monday morning stories.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--The International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, with 250,000 members, may rejoin the American Federatio of Labor next Spring if peace has not been declared by that time between the A.F. of L. and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

CAMBRIDGE,, Mass., Nov. 20-- Harvard today set sail for Saturday's game here against Yale with the first and second varsities in first-class physical trim.

LONDON, Nov. 20.--Firmly convinced that Nazi Germany has embarked on an unrestrained campaign of ruthless mine warfare directed against neutral as well as Allied shipping, Great Britain turned tonight to consideration not only of improved methods of defense but also reprisals against the enemy.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 20-- While the Finnish press for the last few days has scarcely referred to the possibilities of resuming Finnish-Soviet negotiations, much attention is being paid to various measures contemplated to strengthen the country's financial position if it becomes necessary to maintain a state of efficient military preparedness over a long period.
Mrs. Henrietta Lohman, 80 years old, of 2,147 Starling Avenue, the Bronx, was found strangled to death last night on the living room floor of the small apartment where she lied alone.

Looking to his twelfth championship engagement of the year, Henry Armstrong yesterday began training at Billy Grupp's gymnasium in Harlem for his fifteen-round bout with Lou Ambers, world lightweight champion, in Madison Square Garden, Dec. 1. Armstrong's welterweight title will be at stake.

Murry Guggenheim, financier and philanthropist, who died last Wednesday at the age of 81, left $5,000,000 to the Murry and Leonie Guggenheim Foundation, it was revealed yesterday when his will was filed for probate.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20 (AP)--Alexander Armstrong, former Attorney General of Maryland, was found dead in bed at his Ruxton home today. He was 62 years old. Associates said Mr. Armstrong died of a heart ailment which he had had for several years.
Quarters have been leased in Rockefeller Center for New York headquarters by the Continental Oil Company, thus enlarging the group of concerns in that industry already occupying offices there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20--Growing German uneasiness about Soviet designs in the Baltic and Balkan regions, including the Black Sea, is among the factors deterring a Nazi drive in the West, according to diplomatic information here.

Two hundred and fifty workers in the diamond industry--cutters, polishers and sawers--organized in the Diamond Workers Protective Union of America, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, went on strike yesterday for hourly and piece-work wage increases.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Friday, Dec. 1--The destruction caused yesterday by three Russian bombing raids on Helsinki and the scenes of terror and tragedy that followed are graphically described in reports telephoned from the Finnish capital.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)-- The South won today an important freight-rate victory when the Interstate Commerce Commission ruled that rates on certain manufactured and processed goods from the South...

WASHINGTON, Friday, Dec. 1-- President Roosevelt addressed urgent appeals today to the governments of Russia and Finland to refrain from bombing civilians and unfortified cities. He requested immediate replies.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 30-- The loss of Nanning is the most serious reverse the Chinese have suffered since the fall of Hankow, as far as the immediate effects are concerned.

No sharp expansion in retail sales staffs to meet holiday selling needs has yet developed, it was reported here yesterday. There has been some gain in retail employment, but retail executives have not found it necessary yet to call upon additional employes because of increased volume. WITH THE FRENCH ARMIES, in the Field, Nov. 28 (Delayed)--On completion of my first visit to the front, it may not be out of place to speak of the war correspondents.

Supplies of most classes were above normal in local markets yesterday. Trading in beef was fair to good; other classes very slow. Beef sold steady; veal and calf weak; lamb and pork weak to lower. Offerings to the public of bonds and stocks in this market in November were the largest since the start of the war in Europe, but lower than for November of last year and considerably smaller than in the three months preceding September this year.

The world-wide "moral rearmament week-end" of the Oxford Group was formally opened yesterday by the Earl of Athlone, uncle of King George VI, who said in a broadcast from London that the moral rearmament movement was "a cure for that deep disease of the spirit from which civilization is suffering."

In an executive order establishing for the first time a new night court in Brooklyn, Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. said yesterday in an accompanying letter to Brooklyn city magistrates that "among the abuses which it is hoped that the night court will overcome is the recurrent bail bond evil."

In the broad vernacular adopted in previous reincarnations of the old tear-jerking plays on the wages of sin, Harry Bannister has set on the boards of Uncle Sam's Music Hall his version of "Little Lost Sister" under the title "She Gave Him All She Had."

The post of City Clerk and Clerk of the Council, a $10,000 job with a six-year term which is filled by the Council, will be open Jan. 1 when the new Council holds its first meeting. The term of Michael J. Cruise, who has been City Clerk since 1921, expires Dec. 31, and it is expected he will not be re-elected.

Reversing the trend of the last several days, the stock market managed a recovery yesterday and closed from fractions to 2 points higher than on Thursday. The volume on the Stock Exchange remained small, at only 606,480...
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 1 (AP)--Dr. Charles Skeele Palmer, inventor of a gasoline-cracking process that separated oil into gasoline, fuel oil and gas, died last night at the age of 81.
Influence of the war in Europe on business in the United States diminished further in November, the National City Bank reports in its Dec. 1 review of economic, business and financial conditions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 1 (AP)--More than 2,000 Swedes, led by white-capped students, crowded before the Finnish legation tonight to sing and cheer in the first demonstration of Swedish sentiment since Russia invaded Finland. Members of the legation staff stood on a balcony to watch.

Programs of music arranged to herald the approach of Christmas will be heard in many churches of the city tomorrow. Sermons will also be preached in which the birth of Christ will be the leading theme, tomorrow being the first Sunday in Advent.
A refreshing note of common sense was sounded in the presidential address of Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Health Commissioner for New York, before the American Public Health Association.

LONDON, Dec. 1--Telephone talks with Helsinki tonight disclosed that half the Finnish capital's population of 300,000 was in helter-skelter flight and that nearly all those remaining in the, city were engaged in fire-fighting, first-aid work or other government service.

Nate Gross, who earned $3,000 over all expenses for three rapidfire trips abroad to facilitate the movement of narcotics, told in Federal court yesterday how he had gone to Louis (Lepke) Buchalter to complain that a relative was being double-crossed aut of his share of the profits.
The upper West Side and Harlem were centers of realty activity yesterday. Apartment houses formed the bulk of the parcels conveyed.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 1--Cleveland's unemployed have accepted, more or less philosophically to date, a situation in which the city's business is humming at 1929 levels but relief allowances for the unemployed have been cut below recognized subsistence levels.

The city of Philadelphia, Pa., school district awarded yesterday to the Pennsylvania School Employees Retirement Board an issue of $5,000,000 of serial taxable bonds at a price of 100.62 for 2 s. The bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1939, are to mature on Dec. 1, 1944 to 1964.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that title had been taken to all of the land needed for the East River Houses, low-rent apartment project planned for the three blocks bounded by 102d and 105th Streets, First Avenue and the East River Drive.
DAYTON, Ohio Dec. 1--Lorin Wright, only surviving brother of Orville Wright, who with another brother, Wilbur, invented the airplane, died tonight at his home here at the age of 77.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Total round-lot volume of the New York Stock Exchange in the five-day week ended on Nov. 11 was 5,445,100 shares compared with 7,523,680 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
ROME, Dec. 1--Italian popular and press opinion today showed even more hostility than yesterday toward Russia for her invasion of Finland, but the official attitude remains aloof.

Soviet Russia has withdrawn from the 1940 New York World's Fair, and its pavilion, which was both a magnet for visitors and a center of stormy controversy at the 1939 exposition, must be razed within ninety days, Fair officials announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1--Wheat resumed its upward course for the fourth straight day after a brief period of hesitation early when there was some selling on showers in parts of Eastern Nebraska, Kansas and Oklahoma. December wheat acted tight and led the advance with a net gain of 1 cent.

Frederick J. McDermott, 35 years old, a son of Leo J. McDermott, who was budget director at the start of the La Guardia administration, was arrested late yesterday afternoon in District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office for the alleged looting of an investment ...

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 1-- Charles F. Kingsley, New York lawyer and former Buffalo newspaper publisher, died today at his farm home in Roanoke, L.I., five miles north of here, at the age of 74. He had suffered a heart attack two weeks ago.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 1--A new Finnish Government headed by Risto Ryti, a 50-year-old international banker, was set up tonight. Mr. Ryti was summoned to take the Premiership from Aimo Cajander after serving since 1923 as Governor of the Bank of Finland.

Under the sturdy little fists of Petey Scalzo, West Side featherweight, the championship rush of Allie Stolz of Newark was halted last night in Madison Square Garden as the doughty little fighter from across the Hudson went down in his first knockout defeat.

With cotton prices in Liverpool, Alexandria and Bombay continuing their advance into new high grounds, prices on the Cotton. Exchange made further gains. The list closed hare also 8 to 16 points higher and December contracts sold above 10 cents a pound for the first time this season.

ROBERT E. LEE liked to recall the somewhat exasperated commander who said to one of his rebellious subordinates: "Captain, I know you can prove that you are right, and that my order was wrong, in fact you gentlemen always are right--but for God's sake, do wrong sometimes!"
West Side buildings drew many of the apartment tenancies listed yesterday, with a good proportion going to houses on West End Avenue and in Washington Heights.

Net profits of 399 industrial and mercantile companies in the first nine months of 1939 were 71 per cent higher than in the corresponding period in 1938, according to the monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month dropped to the lowest level since Last August, prior to the outbreak of the European war, and was the smallest for any November since 1921.

Streamlined, lightweight trains which will provide fast daily service between New York and Florida at the coach rate of fare were put in use by the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad and the Seaboard Air Line Railway in the Pennsylvania Station yesterday.

A single rate standard on northbound steamship services from Brazilian ports and a partial elimination of similar tariffs on south bound cargo from Atlantic ports to Brazil and the River Plate were announced last night by George Foley, chairman cf the conferences covering the trade.

A rivalry that started half a century ago in comparative privacy will be renewed before some 65,000 spectators at the Yankee Stadium this afternoon when Fordham and N.Y.U. meet in the twenty-first Battle of the Bronx. The Rams are favored by the unjustifiable odds of 3 to 1.

German seamen formerly employed on tankers of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey who were stranded in United States, Central American and South American ports after the outbreak of the European war, apparently are reaching Germany by way, of Portugal, it became known last night.
Modeste Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff" was presented in a rather curious version and a manner generally quite inadequate last night in the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Appointment of Harold D. Jacobs as WageHour Administrator, with the idea that he will serve until Congress removes a statutory ban preventing the nomination of Lieut. Col. Philip B. Fleming, as army officer, was announced late today by the White House.

Like their compatriots at home, the Finns of the United States were mobilizing men, women, money and materials yesterday to help their fatherland. Their first contingent of fighting men was scheduled to sail for Finland on the Swedish liner Gripsholm next Saturday.

A skit on the selective type of examination now given by the Municipal Civil Service Commission, circulated surreptitiously among a comparatively few city employes yesterday, suddenly became so much in demand that it was reportedly mimeographed in various departments and distributed by the thousands.

The Rev. Dr. Maurice Ambrose Levy, corresponding secretary of the Northern Baptist Convention, died suddenly Thursday night while at dinner in a restaurant in Altoona, Pa., according to word received here yesterday. He was 65 years old.

TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP)--Boston University's husky Terriers scored touchdowns in the third and fourth quarters tonight to defeat the University of Tampa Spartans, 12 to 0. The game was played in ideal weather before 4,000 fans.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 1 (AP)-- Frederic Cushing Stevens, an executive of the Chilton Company, New York publishers of trade periodicals, died today in University Hospital at the age of 61. He underwent an operation yesterday.

The rights of conscientious objectors to war will be one of the foremost problems to be discussed at the next biennial conference of presidents of the thirty-one synods of the United Lutheran Church in America and other officers next Tuesday and Wednesday in Harrisburg, Pa.

VINITHA, Okla., Dec. 1 (AP)--Oklahoma's troubles over two Federallyfinanced dam projects flared anew today with the resignation of the man whom Secretary Ickes picked to manage the $20,000,000 Grand River power unit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--Dismissal of C.I.O. seamen by the Colmar Steamship Company in 1937, when there were sit-down strikes on two of its vessels and a general strike order against its fleet, was upheld today by the National Labor Relations Board.

The State Council of Parks has opened a drive for the recapture of Bear Mountain Bridge, Robert Moses, chairman of the council, announced yesterday. PARIS, Dec. 1--Among donations to the French national defense of more than 1,000,000 francs that Premier Edouard Daladier received this week were two remittances from the United States, one for $11,000 and the second for 100,000 francs. The opening of the Sixth Avenue subway next Summer will add two new lines to the city's Independent Subway System and result in a general rerouting of trains to relieve existing congestion and provide greatly enlarged passenger capacity, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The American Red Cross is prepared to extend relief to Finland if and when necessary, Chairman Norman H. Davis announced today.

Ambassador Grew gave Japan a better understanding of American opinion in his blunt talk before the AmericanJapan Society in Tokyo in October. Now a veteran correspondent of the liberal Tokyo Asahi is apparently carrying on the work from Washington.

BOSTON COLLEGE VS. HOLY CROSS-- Games are so scarce now that trying to guess the results is too much like getting personal. When there are dozens of games afoot even the most aimless and inexpert prophet has to be right here and there, probably by accident. Bad guesses are forgotten or forgiven in the general excitement. That is, most of them are forgotten or forgiven or condoned.

Despite the sentiment among most Broadway producers that their organization, the League of New York Theatres, would lose no time in ratifying the amended basic agreement submitted by the Dramatists Guild to permit Hollywood money to back legitimate shows once more, the league failed to take action yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1--Army and Navy come up to their fortieth meeting on the football field tomorrow with records for the season they would rather forget, but this service battle is still the crowdand-money game of the year, with 101,500 witnesses at $4.40 a head to prove it.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 1-- Ralph Henry Graves, former city editor and Sunday editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died early today at his home here, 16 Nassau Bouleward, at the age of 61.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The thirdterm subject, which is always hanging around President Roosevelt's press conferences in some disguise or other, turned up again today, masquerading first as a inquiry on interior decorating and second as a question on Santo Domingo.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 1--A "modern, streamlined version" of the processing tax on farm commodities, nullified by the United States Supreme Court in its decision on the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, was suggested today by Secretary Wallace as a possible "continuing source of revenue" for farmers' benefits.

OTTAWA, Dec. 1--Canada has decided to be represented in the air under her own name in this war and a separate Canadian fighting squadron has been formed from Canadian personnel already serving in the Royal Air Force.

By the will of the people, indignant at the criminal policy of the contemptible Government of Cajander, Erkko and Tanner, a new government of our country-- the People's Provisional Government--was formed today in Eastern Finland.

LONDON, Dec. 1--Two freighters and a tanker were the newest victims of the war at sea, according to reports here today. Two of the ships belonged to neutrals--Finland and Norway--while the third was British.

Disappointment with the results of proportional representation in the recent City Council election seems to be felt mainly by those who either expected too much of a mere electoral device or have forgotten what the result of the election would have been under the old system.

This compares with offerings of $20,069,250 last week and $59,862,500 during this week a year ago.

Gliding out of the cloud-banked sky over the new $40,000,000 municipal airport at North Beach, Queens, an airliner from Chicago landed on the rainswept runway below at 12:01 A.M. today, officially opening La Guardia Field as the Eastern terminus of four of the major airlines of the nation.

A milk price war that started two weeks ago in two East Side stores has spread to the Bronx and Brooklyn and yesterday milk was sold as low as 6 cents a quart, 3 cents less than is charged at the relief depots.

According to word from Washington where Joe Cook currently is appearing in a vaudeville unit show, the comedian will go into rehearsal within thirty days in "Buggy Ride," a musical show which he is writing in collaboration with Don Herold.

With the adoption yesterday of a rule forbidding two ring champions to engage in a bout under its jurisdiction unless the lighter boxer voluntarily surrenders his title, the State Athletic Commission practically put an end to the day of the double and triple champion in boxing.

Now that the New York deer season is over for 1939, the mail brings a number of letters from hunters who had strange, ana in some cases humorous, experiences. There are, of course, the usual number of letters from men who want an open season on does next year.
Morris Koenig, judge of the Court of General Sessions for the last seventeen years, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 25 East Eightysixth Street, after a brief illness. His age was 56.

Electric power production increased last week, but the daily average declined contraseasonally, and the adjusted index dropped to 103.5 from 105.4. It was 96.8 for the week ended Dec. 3, 1938.

Milton Berle, stage and radio comedian, has leased a four-room apartment in Essex House, 160 Central Park South.

VILNA, Lithuania, Dec. 6--The former Polish University of Vilna will be closed on Dec. 15 to reopen on Jan. 15 as the new Lithuanian University. Polish students will have the opportunity to complete their studies, but most of the personnel of 700 will be released.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Early arrivals for the meeting of the executive committee of the Republican National Committee scheduled for tomorrow indicated today that they favor holding the party's national convention in the middle of June, irrespective of when the Democrats meet.

The first non-profit, medical and surgical insurance system to be set up in New York City since the enabling legislation went into effect last June has just received a permit from the State Insurance Department to do business here, it was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Insurance Superintendent.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 6-- Hugh Dillman entertained today with cocktails to celebrate the opening of the newly enlarged and redecorated golf clubhouse of the Everglades Club, of which he is president.

LONDON, Dec. 6--The Council of the Yacht Racing Association today upheld the disqualification of Harold S. Vanderbilt's twelve-meter yacht Vim in a race against T.O. M. Sopwith's Tomahawk at Cowes last July 31 in the London Yacht Club regatta.

Four refugees from lands now under the domination of Germany, three from Poland and one from Czecho-Slovakia, arrived here last night on the Italian liner Vulcania, after immigration authorities at Lisbon, Portugal, for which they had visas, refused to allow them to land.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6--Charles Dalmores, formerly famous as an operatic tenor in the United States and Europe, died today in the Hollywood Hospital after a stroke.

PARIS, Dec. 6--France's expenditures, including extra war expenses, from Sept. 1 to Nov. 11 amount to 78,485,000,000 francs, or almost the equivalent of the total civil budget for 1940, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--American Gas and Electric Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Holding Company Act a declaration covering the proposed issuance and sale of $30,000,000 of sinking fund debentures, a temporary bank loan of not more than $20,000,000, and 355,623 shares of $100 cumulative preferred stock.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6 (AP)--Frank Dobson, who recently resigned as football coach at the University of Maryland, said today he had been "definitely signed to coach a college eleven in 1940 and formal announcement will be made Dec. 13." He declined to reveal where he would coach, but added: "I can, however, say that my new job will be at a near-by college."

LONDON, Dec. 6--Despite the lack of business today, the stock markets continued firm and several good features developed. Gilt-edge securities were idly maintained but interest in foreign bonds provided rises in Brazilian, Japanese and Chinese issues.
Columbia varsity athletes in ten sports who won major letters in the past year will be honored tonight at the annual Varsity C Club dinner at the Columbia University Club.

The Joint Legislative Committee on Labor and Industrial Relations conferred yesterday with Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, and the members and executive officers of the State Mediation Board and the State Labor Relations Board.

Fritz Kreisler, violinist, will make his first appearance with the Philharmonic-Symphony this evening at Carnegie Hall. He will play the first American performance of his version of the Tchaikovsky concerto.

A capacity audience attended the auction sale last night of the modern art collection of the late Mrs. Cornelius J. Sullivan at the ParkeBernet Galleries, and paid $76,850 for ninety-nine lots. The remaining paintings, drawings and examples of sculpture will be sold tonight.
BELFAST, Dec. 6 (Canadian Press)--Linfield won the Irish Gold Cup today, defeating Belfast Celtic, 1--0, in the final of the soccer competition.

PEIPING, China, Dec. 6 (AP)--The death of Marshal Wu Pei-fu was preceded by fantastic Oriental intrigue in which the retired war lord drove a Japanese general to the threat of hara-kiri by stubbornly refusing to help form a Japanese controlled government for China, a highly reliable source declared today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 6--Ten thousand pennies have been contributed by school children here to buy a Christmas tree and ornaments for the children of La Rochelle, France, mother city of this community, school officials announced today.

Illness, unemployment, heartbreak, want, have piled trouble on trouble for the Hundred Neediest. Take the case of the hat laborer whose health began to fail four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)--The Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway, which had a net loss of $200,215 in 1938, told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that it expected to have a net income of $490,808 after all charges in 1939.

The decision of most retail stores to defer purchases of light color and white shoes until the January showing in Chicago curtailed the amount of business placed at the four-day showing of volume shoe manufacturers at the Hotel New Yorker and Hotel Pennsylvania, according to exhibitors yesterday. The showings closed last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Akron, with the neighboring cities of Barberton and Cuyahoga Falls, will be added to the list of communities where the government's food stamp plan of distributing surplus farm commodities will be tried. About 60,000 persons, represented by about 19,750 relief cases, will be eligible to participate in the plan.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6--Prices of wheat rose again today for the ninth consecutive day. The market was erratic at times but a good class of commission-house buying developed on the dips.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Dec. 6 (Canadian Press)--Oxford defeated Cambridge, 15--3, today in the first intervarsity Rugby match played outside of London since 1872. Five thousand spectators watched a keen contest in which Oxford led, 6--0, at half-time. Oxford won by a goal, a dropped goal and two tries to one try.

GEORGETOWN, Del., Dec. 6 (AP) --Mrs. William Russell Clark, known as Princess Madacanna of the Nanticoke Indian Association, died yesterday after a year's illness at the age of 80. She Was the mother of Charles G. Clark (Chief Little Owl), head of the tribe.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (U.P.)-- Henry J. (Heine) Miller today announced his resignation as football coach of St. Joseph's College to become co-coach of the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 6 (AP) --The Duke Power Company, Charlotte's largest taxpayer, sent to the city $60,428.06 for taxes. The city sent back to the utility a one-cent rebate, the smallest paid. The refund was mailed in a two-cent envelope.

Messrs. Olsen, Johnson et al definitely have decided to open their "New Hellzapoppin" at the Winter Garden next Monday night. By this Saturday night the old version will have given 541 performances; Edward Duryea Dowling is staging the new one.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 6-- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and other Chungking Government leaders sent telegrams of condolence to the family of Marshal Wu Pei-fu in Peiping today.

NUTLEY, N.J., Dec. 6 (AP)-- Nutley High School's undefeated football team has accepted an invitation to meet Live Oak (Fla.) High School's unbeaten eleven in an intersectional game in the University of Florida Stadium at Gainesville the night of Dec. 15.

ALBANY, Dec. 6--A new procedure, designed to effect a cut in the relief load by bridging the gap between employers and employables on relief, was announced today by David C. Adie, Commissioner of Social Welfare.

New York University's football team will play a nine-game schedule in 1940 it was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics. The New Yorkers will play four games at the Yankee Stadium, three at Ohio Field and two on the road.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 6Daniel E. Baker, former minstrel and musical comedy player, died at the Englewood Hospital today after a brief illness. His age was 78 years. He had been a resident at the Actors Fund Home in Englewood since June, 1934.

United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery, Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha and Dr. Afranio de Mello Franco, former Minister of the Exterior, were among the officials present.

The scholarship fund of the Graham Alumnae Association was augmented by the proceeds from a card party and tea given yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. King Smith, 563 Park Avenue. Mrs. William W. Brainard is president of the organization.

Federal Judge Edward A. Conger deferred yesterday until Dec. 13 the sentencing of Lucian A. Eddy, Edward E. Embree, Ernest K. Schwartz and Samuel Sobel of 170 Broadway. The four men wet a convicted last week of conspiring to siphon assets of $1,000,000 from a group of investment trusts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The proposed grid system of electric transmission lines suggested by President Roosevelt yesterday as a possible joint undertaking of the government and privately owned utilities as a measure of national defense received today the cold shoulder from Wendell L. Willkie, ...

TRENTON, Dec. 6--The number of State employes and the payroll for them reached a record high in the fiscal year ended June 30, the New Jersey Civil Service Commission reported today to Governor Moore.

A Flatbush property that had been held in one family for a century passed to new control yesterday when a builder purchased the block front on the south side of Quentin Road, between Ocean and East Nineteenth Street. It consists of twenty lots and has a combined frontage of more than 500 feet.
Names of four men who will assist in the style show of the International Association of Clothing Designers at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Jan. 10 were announced yesterday by that group.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6--A consolidation of the Motor and Equipment Wholesalers Association and the wholesaler members of the National Standard Parts Association was under consideration by the executive committee of the former organization at a meeting here today.
CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 6 (AP)--Royalty had its inning today, Royal Business capturing the feature race and Royal Teddy flashing a stretch sprint to place second in a photo finish.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The government lost several hundred thousand dollars of tariff duties on Cuban sugar through a clerical mishap, it was learned today at the Treasury.

Pleas of not guilty were entered yesterday in Federal court by fourteen individuals and thirty-four corporate defendants who were indicted on charges of conspiracy to control the Kraft paper industry. Judge Murray Hulbert put the case down for Feb. 5 and fixed the bail of each individual at $1,000.

Archer Milton Huntington, author and art collector, and son of the late Collis P. Huntington, one of America's great railroad builders, received the 1939 Medal of Merit of the St. Nicholas Society of the City of New York at its 105th anniversary dinner at the Hotel Plaza last night.

A committee headed by President Emeritus William Allan Neilson of Smith College, with Ernest Hemingway as co-chairman, plans a conference in Washington to devote "serious and immediate attention to the elimination of certain tendencies in American life which threaten our concept of equality regardless of race, color, creed, nationality or place of birth."

The possibility of a bus line to connect La Guardia Field at North Beach, Queens, with the New York World's Fair next season was discussed yesterday at the field at the suggestion of Leo Casey, public relations officer at the Fair.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 6--The New Jersey Women's Golf Association elected four officers at its annual meeting today at the Montclair Golf Club and awarded the 1940 three-day medal-play tournament for the association championship to the Baltusrol course. The tournament probably will be held in May.

Directors of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company authorized yesterday the payment on Dec. 15 of one-half month's salary to each officer, not a director of the company, and to each employe as extra ...

Completely subdued and with all their fire gone, the New York Giants practiced quietly yesterday for their game with the Green Bay Packers for the world championship. News of the sudden death early yesterday morning of the mother of Coach Steve Owen came as a complete shock to the team.

Francis J. Sinnott, who has been Brooklyn postmaster since 1933, was appointed yesterday as the Kings County Clerk by the Appellate Division, Second Department. Mr. Sinnott, who takes office Jan. 1, succeeds the late John N. Harman, the last elected County Clerk under the terms of the city charter.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6--American industry was told tonight by Professor Alexander G. Christie, in his presidential address to the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, that it had to develop "an objective training program for young mechanical engineers" if it was to survive and prosper in international trade.

The Wagner College basketball team won its second straight game last night at the Wagner gymnasium on Staten Island, downing the Webb Naval Institute quintet in a nip-and-tuck battle, 39--30.

New securities in an aggregate amount of $48,000,000 comprising 4 per cent Series A first mortgage bonds and 3 7/8 per cent serial debentures of the Public Service Company of Indiana will be offered today by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and an associated nation-wide group of investment dealers.

KYOTO, Japan, Thursday, Dec. 7 (UP)--The Rev. Luther Tucker of Mount Kisco, N.Y., 29-year-old American missionary detained by Japanese police since Oct. 12, was released from jail Saturday, but is incomunicado in a hotel, awaiting trial. The charge against Mr. Tucker was understood to be distributing "undesirable literature and circulating groundless rumors."
Nile Kinnick Jr., the boy who made good in such a big way for Iowa this Fall, came to town yesterday to receive one of the prized football awards--the Johh W. Heisman Memorial Trophy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--Mrs. Roosevelt gave today the first luncheon of the season at the White House, entertaining in honor of the wives of the Justices of the Supreme Court.

Roy Albright, 44 years old, of 1,577 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, a cashier for the John F. Trommer Brewing Company of Brooklyn, 1,367 Bushwick Avenue, was arrested at the plant yesterday on a charge of having stolen $25,220 from the company since June 19, 1938.

So far as Colonel Matt Winn, promoter of the Kentucky Derby, is concerned, the offer of a $50,000 bonus for any triple down winner still stands.

Five artists have been chosen for presentation in recital at the MacDowell Club auditorium as a result of the eighth annual young artists contest held by the club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)--Senator Borah, an opponent of the Administration's trade agreement program, urged today that it be made a clean-cut issue in the coming Presidential and Congressional elections.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The question of establishing some kind of inter-American financial organization occupied the attention of the Inter-American Financial and Economic Advisory Committee today at its plenary session.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 (AP)--Joe E. Brown, motion-picture comedian, was injured in an automobile accident today.

MADRID, Dec. 6--The Finnish Legation was swamped with flowers and telegrams today as Spaniards took the occasion of the anniversary of the little country's independence to express their sympathy with its desperate fight.

The annual dinner of the Lenox School Alumnae will be given tonight in the new building of the school at 170 East Seventieth Street. Miss Betty Gordon, president of the alumnae, will preside. Other young women active on committees of the organization include Mrs. Benjamin Fairchild 3d, the Misses Marian Sulzberger, Sheila Curtin, Barbara Bisch, Yvonne Frank and Barbara Peck.
Three neutral merchant ships were reported sunk by mines yesterday and a British freighter, reported missing, may or may not have been the victim of a submarine's attack.

FRANCE FIELD, C.Z., Dec. 6 (UP)--Several persons, one of them a sentry, were injured slightly today when a forty-mile-an-hour gale struck France Field, blowing the roofs off four United States Army hangars and uprooting trees. Several buildings were damaged by the storm, which lasted only a short time. The guard was hurt when a sentry-box was swept away.

James J. Christiano, 44 years old, who stole $5,193 from Local 780 of the United Cement Masons Union when he was its secretary a year ago, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Donnellan in Central Sessions.

PARIS, Dec. 6--Dr. Alexis Carrel, French scientist, speaking on the radio tonight, told the French that each citizen must first do his own work and, second, take part in the national effort to win the war.

Fritz Kuhn began yesterday his two and one-half to five-year sentence in Sing Sing under protective custody in a segregated cell block where are confined only prison trouble-makers and persons whose lives might be menaced by other prisoners.

WINDSOR, Ont., Dec. 6 (AP)--The Windsor recruiting depot said today that fifteen United States aviators had applied in two days for enlistment in the Royal Canadian Air Force. Officers said most of the applications were from the Southern States and from experienced pilots seeking positions as instructors.

Marshall Field Co. have received permission to list 325,000 additional shares of common stock on the New York Stock Exchange on official notice of issuance in exchange for 6 per cent cumulative preferred shares under the company's plan of reorganization and recapitalization.
The use of code or cipher in cablegrams to or from Sweden will be prohibited, beginning today, according to an announcement yesterday by the International Telegram Office in Berne, Switzerland.

PARIS, Dec. 6--All reports received here regarding the attitude of the various countries that will be represented at the Council and Assembly meetings of the League of Nations confirm that the proposal of Argentina that Soviet Russia should be excluded from the League will have at least a large majority.

A slightly better feeling with regard to Christmas trade developed yesterday as several stores reported sales gains over a year ago for the first two days of this week. The increases followed extremely poor sales volume last week, when declines ranged to 20 per cent under a year ago.

LANCASTER, Pa., Dec. 6 (AP)--A Bishop of the Mennonite Church was chosen by lot today in an ancient ceremony which ended with kissing among the men in the congregation.
Pig iron output last month, according to The Iron Age, fell a little short of the daily record of 125,745 tons in May, 1929. Last month's daily average was 124,015 tons.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 6--Colgate's football schedules for 1940 and 1941 were released today by William A. Reid, director of athletics, with the homecoming game against Duke here on Oct. 19 featuring next Fall's celebration of fifty years of football at Colgate.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 6--Miami completed arrangements today, as expected, for the University of Missouri to meet Georgia Tech in the Orange Bowl football game New Year's Day.

Andre Maurois, who once served as assistant to Jean Giraudoux in the French wartime General Commissariat of Information, has been transferred to his old wartime post as interpreter with the English armies in France.

Keeping up the same pace that made it champion last year, the New York Athletic Club five kept its grip on first place in the Metropolitan Class A squash tennis championship by whitewashing the Harvard Club, 5 to 0, on the latter's courts last night.

Contrasting views on the effect of the new world war on American commerce and industry were expressed last night by speakers at a dinner of the Economic Club of New York at the Hotel Astor. The speakers were men eminent in their particular fields.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)--The National Youth Administration informed Senator Mead today that it was advancing an additional $50,000 for out-of-school projects in New York State outside New York City. The NYA estimated that the additional funds would provide parttime jobs for 400 more youths.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 6--Rutgers opened its 1939-40 basketball season with a 56-to-27 victory over Newark University tonight in the Rutgers gymnasium before 500 fans.
Thomas E. Dewey's opening speech in his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination must have met the best expectations of his wellwishers.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Dec. 6-- Mrs. Mary Beatty Brazo, widow of Paul A. Brazo and mother of Frank A. Brazo, Public Safety Commissioner, died suddenly today at the home of her daughter, Mrs. James A. Crean, in West End. Her age was 72.
Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky died suddenly last night of a heart attack in his new home at 2,336 Gunther Avenue, the Bronx, soon after dining with his wife and two small children.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 6-- The Travelers Insurance Company estimated today that there were 30,968,000 motor vehicles registered in the United States this year, the highest total in history.

Daniel V. Arthur, veteran theatrical manager and producer, who managed several musical comedy shows in which his wife, the late Marie Cahill, appeared, died of a stroke of apoplexy yesterday morning at his residence, the Hotel Orleans, Seventy-ninth Street and Columbus Avenue. He was 73 years old.

The lightweight battle in which Billy Marquart faces Lew Jenkins, Texan, in Madison Square Garden Dec. 22, will be an official lightweight title elimination event if plans of Promoter Mike Jacobs materialize.

To the unprecedented number of fourteen team records broken this season, individual performers in the National Fotball League added thirteen more yesterday when the final statistics for the campaign were released.

LONDON, Dec. 6--One of several German mine-sowing planes, which flew over the Thames estuary early this morning, was brought down under such mysterious circumstances that some air-minded members of Parliament jubilantly asserted that Britain was now using an effective new anti-aircraft weapon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--The Labor Department reported today that the average union wage rate in the building trades increased less than 1 per cent during the year ended June 1.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 6--England is somewhat puzzled by the stand of the United States in the war, according to Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, who arrived this afternoon from Lisbon on the Dixie Clipper to consult with the President and the State Department and for the Christmas holidays.

A major modernization project which has attracted the attention of many realty men has been carried out in the Bronx blockfront at 141-53 Lincoln Avenue, where seven tenements without modern improvements have been made over as a unit.

OSSINING, Dec. 6--Faced with death in the electric chair twelve years ago, Harry Vichnitzer became insane with fear. Cured recently of his insanity, he faced again the prospect of the same death, but Governor Lehman intervened today to commute his sentence to life imprisonment.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 6--Former President Arturo Alessandri reached Santiago today, completing his trip from New York by motoring from Valparaiso under protection of guards and numerous cars carrying friends.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 6--With most of the major league owners and managers still fearful of letting go, it remained for the Boston Bees to break the ice in the trading mart today as the baseball convention completed its third day.

Warburg, also of New York, in the apartment of Conde Nast at 1,040 Park Avenue. Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman performed the ceremony.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 6--Governor James said at a press conference today that a move reportedly was under way to make him keynoter of the Republican National Convention next year. "I appreciate the gesture," he said, "but I think I ought to be a little mouse in the convention." Mr. James has been mentioned as a possible candidate for the Presidential nomination.

Led by Stanley Waxman, who netted 17 points, the James Madison High School basketball team yesterday won its twenty-eighth consecutive victory by defeating New Utrecht, 44--23, on the home court. Madison led throughout, holding a half-time edge of 18--10.

The opening date of the New York World's Fair for 1940 has been advanced two weeks from the date originally announced. The Fair will open Saturday, May 11, Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the board announced yesterday.

Reardon terminated yesterday morning the reopened hearings which the Federal Trade Commission has been holding in the Albert Lane case on the ground that Mr. Lane, acting as his own counsel, had disregarded numerous warnings to stop making "speeches" which did not conform to proper procedure.

After wearing out a few slapsticks during their first year on Broadway, Olsen and Johnson have put some new ones into their illustrious rumpus at the Winter Garden. "The New Hellzapoppin" they call it now.

A one-man show of oils by Irwin D. Hoffman, who had not previously exhibited in New York since 1935, opened with a private view yesterday afternoon at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. There his work may be seen by the public through Dec. 23.

Assuming personal command of the war relief drive of the Finnish Relief Fund, Inc., former President Herbert Hoover said yesterday he hoped to have an experienced relief administrator in Finland within twenty-four hours.

Samuel E. Leith, a special advertising representative of Printers' Ink, 185 Madison Avenue, a publication for advertisers, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after a week's illness. Mr. Leith, who was born in London seventy-one years ago, lived at 601 West 112th Street.
Magnus Larsen, for many years a power in Queens politics, died late yesterday at his home, 40-26 Eightyfirst Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, after an illness of ten days, at the age of 84.

Pettijohn, general counsel for the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, declared yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 14--Traffic on the River Danube has been officially closed, it was learned today. This means that the most important transport route to Germany for Southern European produce is cut off. It is announced that any boats navigating the Danube henceforth do so at their own risk.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 14--Eight golfers, among them the national open champion, Byron Nelson, scored 68s, two under par, today to share the first-round lead in the $10,000 Miami open tournament.

ROME, Dec. 14--Premier Mussolini today received Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, Chief of Staff of the Army, who reported to him on a "detailed inspection of the Western frontier."

A real estate auction group which is credited with having handled the sales of properties "worth billions" celebrated its eightieth birthday yesterday, and observance of the anniversary recalled the earlier sales under the hammer of New York realty in days prior to the Civil War.

BERLIN, Dec. 14--At just about the same time Russia was excluded from the League of Nations, ratification of the documents fixing the Russo-German frontier and of the amity treaty of Sept. 28 were exchanged in Berlin today. This step, in the German view, places the stamp of international legality on the division of Poland.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 14 --Police were stoned by Communist demonstrators this evening. Many demonstrators were injured, two seriously, and sixty were arrested and summarily sentenced to thirty days in jail.

An investor has purchased from the Prudential Insurance Company of America through the Morgenthau-Seixas Company, Inc., for cash above a first mortgage of $46,800 the nineteen-family apartment house at 315 Park Avenue, Paterson ...

Following a reaction of about $4 a bale from the high records made on Wednesday, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and a brisk recovery left the list one point lower to 20 points higher...

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 15 (UP)--A saga of the first major naval battle of the European war was told tonight from a hospital bed by a wounded German sailor who said he wanted only to return to the high seas with his ship.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15-- Kay Francis was signed today by Universal for the leading aduit role, that of Deanna Durbin's mother, in "It's a Date." The part is described as being of greater importance than the usual mother role in Durbin films.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15--A decline of $30,000,000, or about 11 per cent, in United States exports in November, compared with October, was described as "more than seasonal" by the Department of Commerce and gave the first indication...

CHICAGO, Dec. 15--Wallace Rice, author and lecturer, who had been a resident of Chicago since 1861, died tonight of uremia in the Grant Hospital after an illness of six months. His age was 80. A contemporary of two generations of Chicago authors, writers and poets, Mr. Rice was the author, co-author, editor or compiler of ninety books or pamphlets.

The city will not need to sell longterm bonds for at least six months because of the large cash balance on hand now, Joseph D. McGoldrick, Controller, said last night in an address at the dinner given by the executive committee of the Citizens Union at the Town Hall.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 15 (UP)--The bodies of the thirty-six German navy men killed in the battle off Uruguay, Wednesday, were taken today to a common grave in the North Cemetery amid the graves of Germans and Britons who had died here in times of peace.

With Mayor La Guardia sharing honors with their parents, the students of the High School of Music and Art gave their eighth semiannual concert last night at the school auditorium, 135th Street and Convent Avenue, before a capacity house of 1,300 persons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15--Finland paid its semi-annual installment of $234,693 on its war debt to the United States today in a ceremony in which a check was handed to Secretary Morgenthau by Hjalmar J. Procope, the Finnish Minister.

A Christmas list of 100 books approved by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee was made public yesterday at the headquarters of the committee at 23 East Fiftyfirst Street. The list covers a wide range of recently published volumes, including biography, fiction, poetry and travel.
One thousand contributions totaling $503,026 have been received by the campaign fund of the Young Men's Christian Association of New York, Richard W. Lawrence, president ...

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Dec. 15-- Supporters of Democratic Presidential candidates were notified by President Roosevelt today that they would look in vain for White House encouragement of arguments for or against specific aspirants. At the same time the President told reporters that they were wasting their time in trying to learn his own political plans for 1940.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15--With dramatic abruptness, a House investigating committee summoned Edwin S. Smith of the National Labor Relations Board to its witness stand today, peppered him with charges that he sought to promote a union boycott of a hosiery mill and received flat and emphatic denials.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 15--Edwin (Rip) Collins of St. Benedict's Preparatory School, who lost a leg as the result of a football injury, was reminded today by a youth who had suffered the same misfortune that he could still do all the things that were important in life.
ALBANY, Dec. 15 (AP)--Governor Lehman proclaimed today the right of State employes to make their own choice of agencies for collective bargaining.
Minetta Street and Minetta Lane, two short but interesting little thoroughfares in the colorful Greenwich Village section of Manhattan, figured in the real estate news yesterday.

A hearing on the application of the United States Lines to place the liners Manhattan and Washington in the New York-Italy service will be held at 10 A.M. today at the offices of the Maritime Commission in Washington, it was disclosed here yesterday.

The sportsmen of Erie County seem to have espoused the cause of the hunters who are denied permission to follow their sport in the Allegany State Park, and with more than thirty organizations acting as a unit it appears that the Park Commission will have to give them some recognition.

The people of the West and MidWest are showing "great interest" in the candidacy of District Attorney Dewey for President and are eagerly awaiting the start of the primary campaign, according to Governor Harold Stassen of Minnesota.

GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 15-- With marked simplicity, Douglas Fairbanks Sr., famous, gay, dashing hero of the screen for many years, received the final tribute of his family and friends from Hollywood this afternoon.

Television was the principal entertainment and decorative motif of a charity dance given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, where the Television Ball was presented for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center at 599 First Avenue, one of the best known social service settlements in the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15--Passage by Congress of the Equal Rights Amendment was demanded and plans for an intensive campaign in support of its adoption were outlined today by Senator George L. Radcliffe of Maryland, Mrs. Carroll Miller, a sister of Senator Guffey, and others at the opening of the biennial conference of the National Woman's party.
Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio replied yesterday to the criticism of Mayor La Guardia and the Roosevelt Administration of the way the relief problem was handled recently in Ohio.

Mayor La Guardia informed the finance committee of the City Council, which has been inquiring into costs of New York Municipal Airport-La Guardia Field, that he estimated the income from the field next year would total $873,833.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES in France, Dec. 15--Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain arrived by air in the British zone today for a brief visit to the British Expeditionary Force and the Royal Air Force.

The Communist party advised its members yesterday to stop boycotting German goods. William Z. Foster, national chairman of the party, said the boycott policy had been championed by Soviet Russia as a means of preventing war, but that this effort had failed because of "the opposition of the British and French imperialists and their Social Democratic lackeys."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15--American products are much wanted in British Malaya because of war conditions, the Commerce Department reported today. On the list in demand are chemicals, building materials, hardware, paper and paper products, glassware, foodstuffs and textiles.

For more than two months, it became known yesterday, the police and attaches of the Correction Department, under Deputy Commissioner David Marcus, have been aware of a plot of four young Brooklyn gunmen to escape from their cells in the Tombs.
PARIS, Dec. 15--Now that the League of Nations has invited member States to give Finland all the material aid they can the question of French possibilities is being discussed.

Leaders in finance, business and government lost their poise and dignity, at least temporarily, last night in the Hotel Astor and "took it on the chin" at the hands of the New York financial writers. Hardened by the experience of the Last decade, they all proved that they could take it.
J.W.T. Duvel, chief of the Commodity Exchange Administration, visited the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday to investigate the recent sharp fluctuations in cotton futures.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 15-- Harvard's supporters are not any too hopeful in discussing the 1940 Winter sports campaign. The Cantab hockey team, the most popular of the three major Winter sports aggregations, is inexperienced but promising.

PARIS, Dec. 15 (AP)--The lid will be lifted for traditional Parisian gaiety during the Christmas and New Year's holidays. The Prefecture of Police announced today that the 7 P.M. curfew would be rescinded on Christmas Eve and night and New Year's Eve, permitting Paris to celebrate until 2 A.M.

Brisk recoveries, after the sharp dip of Thursday in the principal commodities, overshadowed the laborious movements of the stock market yesterday and a late rally in the air-transportation issues produced a modestly firmer appearance in the general list.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15--Quotations for grains turned upward today after an early dip. All deliveries of wheat and soy beans sold at new high prices for the season and for two years or more.

Postoffice Department inspectors and New York and Chicago detectives found him trying to hide in a clothes closet of his South Side apartment.

As the leading ladies come trooping back to the Metropolitan Opera House their particular vehicles return with them. And such is the popularity of coloratura singing that the largest audience of the week assisted at the return of leading lady and opera.

PARIS, Dec. 13--Many smart Parisiennes are planning to spend their Christmas holidays doing Winter sports, as usual. Improvement in the administration of justice in the city, coupled with a warning that industrial racketeering is on the upgrade, was revealed in the annual report of the Citizens Committee for the Control of Crime, made public yesterday by Harry F. Guggenheim, its president. The report also disclosed an increase in the number of crimes and a drop in the proportionate number of arrests.

Stockholders of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company voted discretionary authority yesterday to their board of directors to sell the historic Metropolitan Opera House, at Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street, to the Metropolitan Opera Association for $1,970,000.

Ways and means of reducing municipal real estate taxation without impairing vital services were discussed yesterday by municipal officials of four States at an all-day conference at the Murray Hill Hotel. WASHINGTON, Dec. 15--Molybdenum and aluminum, needed in aircraft construction, were added by the State Department today to the materials under moral embargo to nations which bomb and machine-gun civilians and open cities and towns from the air.

Price cuts of 80 cents a fifth on three widely advertised price-fixed brands of Scotch and reductions of as much as $1.30 on seven other brands were announced here last night by Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., in a move that store officials said they believed would "bring into the open the 'under-thecounter' price cutting prevailing in many retail stores of the city."

The city of Minneapolis will be in the market on Jan. 16 with a new issue of $2,200,000 of relief, river improvement and refunding bonds, for which bidders are to specify the interest rate. PANAMA CITY (Saturday), Dec. 16 (UP)--President Juan Demostenes Arosemena of the Republic of Panama died last night in the interior town of Penonome where he was visiting, it was announced this morning. His age was 61.

Dr. Frederic Schiller Lee, one of the world's leading physiologists, retired Professor of Physiology at Columbia University and former president of the New York Botanical Garden, died Thursday in Waverly Sanatorium, Columbia, S.C., after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday. He was 80 years old.

The basketball season, which struggled along in its own quiet way until the final football firing was stilled, bursts forth at Madison Square Garden tonight with the first of fifteen collegiate doubleheaders.

As a climax to what was probably the most thrilling night of fighting the new Madison Square Garden has ever held, Al Davis, Brownsville's unbeaten young welterweight, last night knocked out agile Tippy Larkin of Garfield, N.J., in the fifth round of their scheduled tenround feature bout. The program attracted 17,116 fans and the receipts totaled $43,521.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15--Officials of various departments and buraus are gathering data to be used in meeting what they expect may be one of the sternest oppositions expressed in Congress in recent years when the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, fathered by Secretary Hull, comes up for renewal in the next session.

Led by Mrs. Kenneth F. Macdonald and Miss Theresa Bellizzi, who accounted for three victories between them, the Gramatan Hills women's team turned in an impressive performance as it defeated Plainfield, 3 to 2, in a Metropolitan Badminton Association Class A encounter.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 15--Valdina, consistent horse owned by Clyde Troutt of Chicago, won his third straight race to take the Harahan Purse, six-furlong dash that topped the Fair Grounds program, today. LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26 (AP)--Al Jolson was divorced today by his third wife, Ruby Keeler, who said he called her "stupid" and would keep her up all night calling her names.

This is the result of a report from social workers that disease, mental breakdowns and threatened suicides had resulted from undernourishment of 56,000 relief clients.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 26--W. Somerset Maugham's "The Letter," in which the late Jeanne Eagels starred in 1929, has been acquired by Warmers from Paramount as a probable vehicle for Bette Davis. Paramount had announced a remake of the story earlier this year for Isa Miranda.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--An application by American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Corporation with extensive utility holdings in Latin America for exemption ...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26--For two hours today Frank J. Willard, receiver of taxes, and two associates withstood a bombardment of questions fired by nearly 400 business man, who wanted to know the answers in dozens of borderline cases affected by Philadelphia's new municipal tax of 1 per cent on unearned income.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 (AP)-- Basketball champions from two Conferences came to town in blustery weather today to open the Sugar Bowl sports carnival tomorrow night with an interleague test before 6,000 customers at the Municipal Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--British women who heretofore have chosen stockings from about 100 colors and shades will have only ten colors from which to choose in the coming year, under a decree by the British dyeing industry prompted by the war, the Department of Commerce was informed today in a dispatch from Birmingham.
The advance in raw silk prices was resumed yesterday, touching new highs in the Japanese markets, and advancing the full trading limit here.

Franklin D. Roosevelt continues to hold popular support as President today, the American Institute of Public Opinion's December survey of Presidential popularity shows. In it 63.5 per cent of voters signified aproval of him, Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, writes. The survey continues:

"Christmas Eve," a play about an American family's life between late afternoon of Dec. 24 and just after midnight of Dec. 25, by Dr. Gustav Eckstein, is offered this evening by Guthrie McClintic at Henry Miller's. More particularly the play tells of the effect on a young girl of her family's celebration.

Plans for expansion involving the expenditure of $16,000,000 were announced yesterday by Frank R. Phillips, president of the Duquesne Light Company of Pittsburgh. Work on the program throughout the company's territory, which includes Pittsburgh and surrounding ...

CHICAGO, Dec. 26--Old-time fairy tales and fiction books are dropping off the preferred reading lists of school-age children. The younger children prefer stories about horses and dogs, while those beyond the sixth grade are increasing their demands for vocational subjects.
In the December Supplement to The United States Official Postal Guide Mr. Farley shakes hands with the officials and employes of his service:

CHICAGO, Dec. 26--Snowfall which blanketed the dry areas in the West and Southwest led to fairly general selling of wheat futures in the early trading today and prices declined 2 cents a bushel to ...

Preliminary to invasion of the American market, fashions incorporating Greece's challenge to Paris were displayed yesterday afternoon at the Hotel St. Regis at a luncheon preview of costumes brought to this country during the World's Fair.

Fred G. Randall, former vice president of the Queensboro Corporation, who had been active in the development of Queens County real estate for the last thirty-five years, died Monday night in the Flushing Hospital of pneumonia after a week's illness. He was 59 years old.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dee. 26-- Charles A. Munn was host tonight at a dinner at Amado to his house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Ector O. Munn and Reginald Boardman.

BOSTON, Dec. 26--C Lyde Eagle, 54 years old, coach of the freshman baseball team at Yale, former baseball coach at the University of Vermont and former member of the Boston Red Sox and the New York Yankees, died suddenly today from a heart attack in the Hotel Lenox.

BOSTON, Dec. 26--A jubilant, confident band of Boston College football players clicked over the rails in their Cotton Bowl special tonight toward Dallas, Texas, and a rendezvous with South Carolina's Clemson College Tigers on New Year's Day.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26--Henry L. Doherty, a leader in the oil industry, president and founder of the Cities Service Company and philanthropist, died of bronchial pneumonia at 9:41 o'clock tonight in his apartment at Temple University Hospital, where he had been a patient for three and a half years. His age was 69.

The United States Department of Agriculture is beginning a comprehensive survey of weather observations on the North Atlantic Ocean to increase the safety of aircraft operations, it was learned yesterday at La Guardia Field, North Beach, Queens.

RECENTLY one has been hearing no small amount of grumbling about what is or what is not happening in hockey. It isn't anything upon which you can definitely place a finger. But the ice game, which came roaring out of the North more than a decade ago, simply is not packing them in as in days of yore, and when this happens in any sport there is usually a reason.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 26 (UP)--The Appalachian Coal Conference mine shutdown of last Spring was not a strike and the miners involved are therefore entitled to unemployment insurance for the period, Common Pleas Judge Joy Seth Hurd ruled today.
