Mr. and Mrs. Richard Spencer Childs gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for their debutante niece, Miss Mary C. Draper, who was introduced formally at a supper dance on Friday night at the Cosmopolitan Club by her mother, Mrs. M. Charles Draper of Brooklyn.

The ways of Hollywood will receive collegiate recognition next month, when Mrs. Josephine Dillon Gable (first wife of Clark Gable) enters the field of higher education by becoming head of the drama department at Christian College, Columbia, Mo.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 26-- Mr. and Mrs. William Moorhead Vermilye and Mr. and Mrs. Albert D. Beers, all of Plainfield, gave a supper dance tonight at the Plainfield Country Club to introduce Miss Ridgeley Clair Vermilye, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vermilye. and Miss Louise Hoy, daughter of Mrs. Beers.
WYNNEWOOD, Pa., Dec. 26--Mr. and Mrs. Gerold M. Lauck of Inwood, this place, gave a supper dance at their home tonight to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Sidney Carol Lauck.

Preparations for large-scale payments of old-age benefits under the Social Security Act, which will begin at the end of January, were being pushed yesterday by the regional office of the Social Security Board and its thirty-four field branches throughout the State
New York newspaper linage has been so erratic this month that volume for the balance of this week will determine whether a gain or loss is to be shown for December as a whole.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 26-- The Matecumbe Purse was run in two divisions and served as the headline attraction at Tropical Park today.

While it was walking the "last mile" to the stockyard adjoining the slaughter house, a 1,400-pound steer made a desperate break for freedom shortly before dawn yesterday, and with three police radio cars in pursuit, raced for nearly two hours through the West Side before it was recaptured.

Mayor La Guardia was asked yesterday for comment on the statement from the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey that indicated the possibility of "official incompetence or neglect" on the part of higher-ups in connection with the theft of nickels from the city-owned Independent Subway System. The Mayor said:
Unless the unexpected happens and happens in an unexpectedly big way, the New York Stock Exchange's stock volume this year will be about 261,000,000 shares, the lowest since 1923.
Arrival of foreign gold in an amount estimated at approximately $9,000,000 was reported unofficially yesterday. The gold was of Scandinavian, Swiss, Indian, Egyptian and Mexican origin.
United States Attorney John T. Cahill announced yesterday that he would again prosecute Frank Carmine Nardone, who has twice won Supreme Court fights to have previous convictions set aside.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Senator Norris of Nebraska said today that he would retire from public office when his term expires in 1943, when he will have completed forty years in Congress.
Contracts for additional space with firms whose personnel has been expanding in response to greater business activity marked the commercial leasing reported yesterday.

There would be no more budget wars at Albany if the legislative recommendations submitted yesterday to the New York County Republican Committee by an advisory group headed by Harold Riegelman were followed. Even Washington might learn something from them.

PANAMA, Dec. 26--The German freighter Dusseldorf, which passed through the Panama Canal yesterday from the Pacific to the Atlantic a a British prize of war and sailed today from Cristobal, left here a problem in the form of Hans von Appen, a former employe of the Hamburg-American Line in Panama.

The League of New York Theatres, the organization of producers and managers, meets at 2:30 P.M. today to consider action against a majority of members of the Associated Theatre Ticket Agencies who refused yesterday to subscribe to the new code designed to regulate the distribution of tickets and curb speculation.

Sixty patrolmen were assigned to special duty at the motion picture theatres in the Times Square area yesterday to assist ushers and other theatre attendants in handling the record holiday crowds that filled the show houses to capacity and left thousands waiting in line in the streets.

Mr. and Mrs. William Knight Jr. and Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clifford Martin gave a supper dance last night at the River Club to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Marie Barney Knight and Miss Nancy Dykman Martin.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26--Continuance of the present rise in business activity for at least six months of 1940 and probably to the end of the year was predicted tonight by Dr. James Washington Bell, secretary-treasurer of the American Economic Association, as more than ...

The marriage of Miss Harriet Gay Hayden, daughter of Mrs. Nathaniel Wheeler Hayden of 215 East Seventy-third Street and the late Mr. Hayden of Chicago, to Walter Hamer Gahagan of this city, an assistant United States Attorney, son of Mrs. Walter H. Gahagan and the late Mr. Gahagan, took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Dec. 26-- An estimated 1,680 apple trees are being uprooted with tractors in the thirty-five-acre orchard at Jersey Homesteads, the New Deal resettlement project near here, it was disclosed today when the Jersey Homesteads Agricultural Association, which conducts farming operations ...

LONDON, Dec. 26--The British steamer Stanholme of 2,473 tons, outward bound from a west coast port, was torpedoed and sunk without warning within sight of England on Christmas morning. Fourteen men were drowned.

ROME, Dec. 26--The Pope today followed his scathing condemnation of Russia's invasion of Finland last Sunday by announcing he had sent a "substantial" sum to Finnish Catholics. The Vatican announcement said:

Asking the United States to "lead the way toward peace," the Rev. Daniel A. Poling, editor-in-chief of The Christian Herald, in an editorial in its January issue, presents a five-point peace plan, including as its first plank, "a world state for the administration of world affairs."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--The dislocation not only of peoples but of whole populations driven from their homes and now on the move back and forth over a distracted continent was characterized today by Ernest J. Swift, vice chairman of the American Red Cross, as the present major problem of the European war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--Congressmen are talking now about cutting down Federal expenditures, but if past performance is any guide, the economy axe may be gathering rust before the first 19401941 appropriation bill goes to the White House.

Offering will be made to the public today of the unsubscribed portion of $4,059,000 of an issue of $5,910,000 of Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company first mortgage convertible 4 per cent bonds, due in 1952, by an underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., ...
The four-story sixteen-family flat on a plot 43 by 142 feet at 670 Grand Street, Jersey City, N.J., has been sold by the Excelsior Liquidating Corporation to Melvin Shapiro.

The Holiday Dance Festival at the St. James Theatre opened its season of nine performances last night with the first appearance this season of the American Ballet Caravan under the direction of Lincoln Kirstein.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26--Chicago theatres obeyed tonight for the third time in as many days an ultimatum from James C. Petrillo, president of the Chicago Federation of Musicians, demanding the elimination of references in plays to John L. Lewis, head of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

MONTREAL, Dec. 26--While Gordon Drillon of the Toronto Maple Leafs tallied enough points to remain at the top of the National Hockey League scorers, Milt Schmidt of the Boston Bruins gained most of the honors in games of the last eight days and improved his position from nineteenth place to fourth.

Although yesterday was a visiting day at the government's immigration station on Ellis Island, the 576 members of the crew of the scuttled German liner Columbus passed the day without a single visitor except an official of the Hapag-Lloyd Lines who went over to confer with Captain Wilhelm Daehne.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Secretary Hull will welcome a thorough Congressional investigation of the reciprocal trade agreements program, he said today.

BERLIN, Dec. 26--Chancellor Hitler has accepted a Christmas gift of a villa in San Remo, Italy, from Frau Martha Selve, a former resident of Hamburg now living there, and has ordered that it be equipped as a convalescent home for wounded soldiers, it is reported here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--The most surprised people in the world, except perhaps Herr Hitler and his inner circle, would be the President's diplomatic aides if Mr. Roosevelt should in any way join those--of whom Mr. de Valera is the latest--who are calling for European peace now at any price.

The Church Pension Fund is now paying pensions to approximately 2,500 retired clergymen and widows and orphans of clergymen of the Protestant Episcopal Church at the rate of $1,347,000 a year, William Fellowes Morgan Sr., president of the fund, announced in a statement yesterday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26--What effect the situation of the Russian forces in Finland is going to have on Soviet policy is now becoming an important question, especially in view of the arrival tomorrow of the Bulgarian Minister of Finance, Dobri Bojiloff.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 26 (UP)-- Finance Minister Roberto Wachholtz, regarded as the "strong man" of President Pedro Aguirre Cerda's Popular Front government, resigned today because of unspecified "difficulties." The resignation was accepted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Joseph E. Davies, Ambassador to Belgium, is to take over special duties in the State Department as an adviser on international trade and on war emergency matters. He will be assigned as a special assistant to Secretary Hull, the White House announced today.

Public officials and members of the bench and bar will serve as honorary pall bearers at the funeral service for Judge John, F.O.'Brien of the Court of Appeals today at 10:30 A.M. in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 26--Britain's material and moral support for Finland is increasing every day. South Africa, like Britain and France, has agreed to ship airplanes to the Finns. The Allies have been increasing shipments of planes and war material in the past few days.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--The condition statement of the weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 20:

City College, defender of the Harold M. Phillips Trophy, lost its firstround match in the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League at the Manhattan Chess Club, Alamac hotel, yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--The United States Lines today applied to the Maritime Commission for permission to sell the eight vessels it earlier attempted unsuccessfully to transfer to Panama registry to the North Atlantic Transport Company, a Norwegian corporation, which would use them for service between United States and British ports.
The Cottage Suite of Hampshire House was the setting last night for a dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Charles De Wolf Gibson for their debutante daughter, Miss Elizabeth Burdett Gibson.

TRENTON, Dec. 26--Colonel G. Barrett Glover, director of the New Jersey Legislature's relief investigating committee, advocated here today the suspension of the $35,000 monthly payments which the State is making to WPA sewing projects.

MOST people know that C2H5OH is the chemical symbol for ethyl alcohol, a substance attractive to man since the beginning of recorded time. Others are sure that it stands for Booze, the archfiend and destroyer of homes. Still others regard it as a handy way of spelling the 2 plus 5 days between CHristmas and the OH of the morning after New Year's Eve.

The net income of the Southern Railway in 1939 will be "something over $5,500,000," compared with a deficit of $497,772 in 1938, E.E. Morris, president, said yesterday. This would be equal to $1.92 a share on common stock in 1939.

After finishing in the runner-up position for two successive years Johnny Mize, hard-thumping first baseman of the Cardinals, finally realized the ambition of all ball players last Summer when he carried off the individual batting championship of the National League.

Irving Koppelman, 29 years old, known for years as a petty offender in the midtown district, was sentenced by Judge Allen in General Sessions yesterday to a Sing Sing term of two and one-half to five years for the theft of $10,000 in gems on Nov. 30 last in the Jewels of Distinction, Inc., at 149 West Fifty-seventh Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 26--The discovery within the living plant of an immensely complicated, submicroscopic chemical factory, where nature makes cellulose, one of civilization's most important basic materials, was described today at the annual scientific exhibition ...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26--The Rev. Dr. Alpha Gilruth Kynett, a retired Methodist clergyman, who had occupied several administrative positions in the denomination, died late today at the home of his daughter, Miss Eleanor M.G. Kynett, at 4,820 Beaumont Avenue. He was 81 years old.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26--Messages are now coming in by wireless from the icebreaker Joseph Stalin vividly describing her contest with bitter Winter storms on her Arctic voyage to reach the icebreaker Syedoff.

With William Umstaedter of Louisiana State University, the No. 1 seeded player, winning as expected, two rounds were completed in the national junior indoor tennis championship on the courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 26--The Air Ministry announced today that British reconnaissance planes bombed German patrol vessels in the North Sea on Christmas Day, but only after the Nazi ships had opened fire on them. No damage was done during the fight, the British communique said.

Richard Archbold, research associate in mammalogy at the American Museum of Natural History, has equipped an expedition to study animal behavior in the desert area near Gila River, Ariz., it was announced yesterday.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Dec. 26-- James J. Britt, a former Representative and a prominent Republican leader for many years, died here this morning of a heart attack. His age was 78.

Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., operator of cargo and passenger liners to Scandinavia and South America, announced yesterday that a lease had been taken on Pier 32, North River, a modern new terminal owned by New York City and said to be one of the best in the country.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26--Eight officers and employes of S.W. Gongoll Co., bankrupt investment management firm of Minneapolis, nave been indicted by a Federal grand jury in St. Paul on charges of violating the Federal Securities Law and of mail fraud. W. McNeil Kennedy, ...

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP)-- Tennessee's stanch gridiron supporters took private peeps at two important aspects of the approaching Rose Bowl game today and felt none too elated over what they saw.
The Brooklyn Dodgers announced yesterday that they had claimed Louis (Boze) Berger, infielder, via the waiver route from the Boston Red Sox.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pratt gave a dance last night at the Court House, 206 East Sixty-fifth Street, to introduce their daughter, Miss Anne Pratt. The party took place in a Winter setting effected by a blue and silver marquee surrounded by silvered trees and snow men. The debutante wore a gown of white taffeta.

Power politics makes even stranger bed-fellows than the domestic kind. So one can't help thinking when one reads that some of the American volunteers who fought on the side of the Loyalist Government in Spain during the recent civil war have just adopted resolutions defending the activities of the Russian Government in Finland.

Miss Martha Bruce Rutgers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Gouverneur Rutgers Jr. of 141 East Seventy-second Street and Rumson, N.J., has completed plans for her marriage to George Vernon Coe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Coe, also of New York and Rumson, which will take place here on Jan. 12 in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

The failure of the Russian campaign in Finland has been so complete to this point that the question arises whether it is not necessary to revise the theory that Stalin is the real victor over Hitler in the struggle for power in Eastern Europe.

The largest heave public construction boom in a decade was put in operation in the State of New York during 1939, it was announced yesterday in a report made public by Colonel M.E. Gilmore, regional director for the PWA from his office at 2 Lafayette Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)--A confident prediction that President Roosevelt would not be a candidate for a third term was made today by Senator Burke of Nebraska, a Democrat, who sometimes opposes Roosevelt policies.

ST. JOSEPH, Mich. Dec. 26--Michigan's Apple Act, which imposes a tax of 1 cent a bushel on the State's principal fruit, was held invalid today in a ruling by Judge Fremont Evans in the Berrien County Circuit Court.

LONDON, Dec. 26--The Times, London, will print tomorrow a dispatch from its own Moscow corre spondent saying that Russia's failure to break down Finland's resistance before the advent of severe weather may have internal political repercussions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Cordial responses have been received by President Roosevelt from the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders to whom he wrote inviting their cooperation in a world peace move.

The music of one John Smith opened the program of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. This Smith was not a descendant of Pocahontas, but a maa who died as the business agent of George Frederick Handel, in London in 1785.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 26--Sufficient official data has been compiled regarding the naval combat off Punta del Este, Uruguay, Dec. 13 to enable Argentine naval tacticians to construct a complete picture of the battle between the German pocket battleship Admiral Graf Spee and three British light cruisers, the Exeter, Ajax and Achilles.

LONDON, Dec. 26--The first contingent of Australian troops, consisting of a squadron of the Royal Australian Air Force with a full complement of trained pilots, gunners, observers and ground crews, landed at a south coast port today and received a warm welcome from high officials of the government and army.

An 11-point outburst midway in the second half broke a spectacular game wide apart and snapped a Long Island University winning streak last night as a record crowd of 18,245 watched a slick quintet from Southern California topple the Blackbirds, 57 to 49.

The Alleghany Corporation sold 150,000 5 per cent cumulative preferred shares of the Missouri Pacific Railroad for 20.4 cents each at an auction in the rooms of Adrian H. Muller Son, 75 Montgomery Street, Jersey City, yesterday.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 26--Thomas J.S. Landis, formerly an illustrator and artist on Leslie's Weekly and The Toledo Blade, died today at his home here, 294 Roseville ...

WITH THE FINNISH ARMY, on the Karelian Isthmus, Dec. 26--Viborg, the second largest city in Finland, was bombed viciously from the air again today. So far as could be seen, no military objectives were struck, but again there were human casualties--two civilians at the edge of the city were killed.

Due to the holiday, the number of out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the past week was well below the preceding week but was slightly ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Two women who wrote urgent letters requesting that the New York Title and Mortgage Company return the money they had invested in certificates guaranteed by the company were told to stop writing or they might be accused of violating the Federal mail fraud laws, according to evidence introduced yesterday in Federal court.
WATERFORD, N.Y., Dec. 26-- Two hundred pounds of dynamite, cached in a metal-covered trailer and believed exploded by a rifle bullet, blasted five young hunters to bits today.

Eager for action after a lay-off since Sunday, when they dropped a game to the Bruins, Red Dutton's Americans will resume their campaign in the National Hockey League tonight at Madison Square Garden against the Chicago Black Hawks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--The plan by which the United States will aid Latin-American nations in the development of their natural resources, and particularly of roads, railroads, dams, mines and agriculture, through long and short-term loans is rapidly taking shape, officials said today.

An explosion in an over-heated oil stove in a pool room adjoining the Lido Theatre at 267 Court Street, Brooklyn, caused the brick wall between the two buildings to collapse shortly before 6 o'clock last night, resulting in minor injuries to eleven patrons of the movie house and a fireman.
Scarcity of contracts with which to meet year-end price-fixing by domestic mills and foreign buying caused advances of 7 to 17 points on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

Twenty just-completed mural panels by the well-known American artist, Maurice Sterne, will be placed on view today, at an invitation preview, in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 26-- Heavy Russian forces, supported by tanks, airplanes and artillery, were reported tonight to have left 700 dead on the ice of Lake Suvanto when repulsed in a series of fierce assaults against Finnish positions on the Karelian Isthmus.

On the south side of Tenth Street, just west of Fifth Avenue, goldlettered signs on the windows proclaimed The Villager, "A Neighborly Neighborhood Newspaper." Another sign in gold, above the door handle, said "Latch string-- Welcome."

The Police Department yesterday began to make plans for handling the throng of merrymakers which is expected to be on the streets New Year's Eve. There are three main points of congestion for the celebration--Times Square, Harlem and the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn.
PARIS, Dec. 26--In that No Man's Land between the Maginot Line and the Westwall what looked like a Christmas truce but may have been due only to the weather did not last long.

How an automobile license number brought luck to one man but misfortune to another was revealed in General Sessions yesterday when Judge Donnellan imposed a Sing Sing term of one to two years on William Boyd, 31 years old, a Negro, for the theft of the car to which it was attached.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 26--Federal Judge Guy L. Fake today ordered the Central Railroad of New Jersey to pay 60 per cent of the 1939 tax levied by the State of New Jersey. The payment will total $2,049,553.

Net earnings of the Lookheed Aircraft Corporation for the eleven months ended with November, after all charges and taxes, set a new high record of $2,705,682, according to the report of Robert E. Gross, president, issued for publication today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP)-- Colonel G.M. Barnes, ordnance expert of the army, said today that the army had developed three important antidotes to aircraft attack.
Having finished with church politics for the moment, Paul Vincent Carroll is now defending the artist against a scheming world in "Kindred," which was acted at Marine Elliott's last evening.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--A gain of 8.8 per cent in sales by service and limited-function wholesalers during 1939 compared with 1938 was estimated today by the Department of Commerce.

The filing of applications for $2,000 Sanitation Department jobs closed at 7 o'clock last night with 17,000 in the office of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, the largest total for a single day.
BERLIN, Dec. 26--On Christmas Eve Chancellor Hitler set foot on French soil for the first time since 1918, when, as an unknown soldier, he fought on the side of the German Army in France.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)--Taking issue with critics in and outside the Administration, Secretary Wallace defended the certificate plan of processing taxes today as a method of stimulating business activity and thereby helping rather than hurting consumers.

LONDON, Dec. 26--The British Broadcasting Corporation announced tonight that the mystery of the quotation with which King George concluded his Christmas broadcast seemed to have been solved by a telephone call to its offices.
The report from Copenhagen in last week's issue of The Iron Age implying that, despite the war, France and Germany were exchanging iron and coal, was promptly denied in Paris.

In summing up the year's activity, with special emphasis on the fresh-water fishing in near-by lakes and streams, we rated it as less than "fair to middlin'," but for the seven men who won the prizes of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association it was a "successful season."

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 27--An informal meeting of a majority of all political parties in the Japanese House of Representatives held last night, agreed to sink all party differences in criticizing the Cabinet of Premier Nobuyuki Abe, and adopted a resolution inviting that Cabinet "to consider proper steps regarding resignation."

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 26--After one of the quietest Christmases on record, Canada is settling down to the serious business of war preparations. Details of the first war loan will be made public probably next week.

Relief organizations in Finland have begun to spend $200,000 sent from here for food, clothing and shelter for the victims of the Russian invasion, according to a report received yesterday by the Finnish Relief Fund, Inc., which collected the money from American sympathizers.

The red ball is flying over thirtyone small outdoor ice-skating rinks opened free to the public in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx during the last few days by the Department of Parks, it was announced yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 26--The National Geographic Society put on exhibit here today, for the first time in this country, a replica of a pre-Columbian stone monument from Mexico bearing a date equivalent to Nov. 4, 291 B.C., carved in Maya Indian symbols.

Modest improvement extended yesterday throughout the listed bond market in relatively listless trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Year-end tax adjustments again were evident in transactions in individual issues, but the main body of issues maintained a steady to firm undertone, with traders apparently unwilling to make important commitments until after the turn of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--President Roosevelt virtually completed today his preliminary study of the budget for the fiscal year 1940-41 and planned to begin at once the drafting of a message in which he is expected to put squarely up to Congress the choice of cutting expenditures, ...
Except for tin plate, which is in a seasonal decline, steel products are enjoying a better than etpected demand for this time of, the year, Iron Age says this week.

While three directors of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company were taking swift measures to safeguard their own and their friends' investments in the company's mortgage certificates other investors were unable to regain smaller amounts on certificates that were due, according to evidence introduced yesterday in Federal court.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander S. Banks of 128 East Seventy-first Street and Suffern, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjory Banks, to Uri Balcom Grannis Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill., son of Mr. Grannis of Chicago and the late Mrs. Grannis. The announcement was made at a small reception given yesterday afternoon by Mr. and Mrs. Banks at their home here.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 27--The New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce urged today that New Jersey abandon its fight before the Interstate Commerce Commission against continuance of free lighterage in New York Harbor, warning that shipping might be curtailed if existing rates were changed.
LONDON, Dec. 27--The stout resistance of the Finns to the Russian aggression has created an advantageous situation which the Allies' High Command is expected to exploit.
With $18,500,000 worth of war materials in storage at the free port awaiting shipment to England and France, officials of the New York Foreign Trade Zone Operators, Inc., announced last night that

A banking group composed of the William R. Staats Company, Kaiser Co. and O'Melveney, Waggenseller Durst has won the award of a total of $741,000 of school and hospital bonds of San Francisco at a net interest cost basis of 1.40 per cent, the lowest in the history of the city.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 27--England has not given up its plan of making peace with Germany, provided that as the price of peace Germany starts a war with Soviet Russia, Earl Browder, secretary of the Communist party, said in a speech tonight to delegates attending a convention of the American Student Union.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 27--The University of Tennessee football delegation welcomed news today that the battle with Southern California's Trojans in the Rose Bowl probably would be played under ideal conditions. Weather experts predicted that New Year's Day would be clear.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27--Catholic educators and sociologists urged today consideration of Christian ethics as voiced by the encyclicals of Popes Leo XIII and Pius XI in dealing with social and labor problems.
RYE, N.Y., Dec. 27--Boston College routed Cornell by a 24-1 score in the second night of the annual Playland Ice Casino week of American and Canadian intercollegiate hockey.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27--Additional moisture was received over the main Winter wheat belt last night and while the storm is passing Eastward traders placed a bearish construction on the weather conditions and turned to the selling side.

Luis Philip Senarens, creator of the fabulous Frank Reade, a Mechanically minded genius who thrilled small boys forty sad fifty years ago, died Tuesday in Kings County Hospital. He was 76 years old and had suffered from a heart ailment for eight years.

A biting northerly wind, driving gray, snow-laden clouds before it, brought to New York yesterday its coldest day of the Winter. Shortly before 10 A.M. the mercury dropped to 11.9 degrees above zero, and in the early afternoon snow flurries deposited about a quarter inch of dry, powdery snow throughout the metropolitan area.
A grand concert for the benefit of Lotta Svaerd, Finnish women's organization, was presented last night at Carnegie Hall before a large and distinguished audience.

No one concerned with the relief problem in Cleveland can ignore the report on the situation existing between Nov. 15 and Dec. 15 which a responsible group of social workers has just prepared and presented.

The American Philosophical Association opened a three-day session at Columbia University yesterday for the double purpose of hearing the fifth series of the Paul Carus philosophical lectures and of honoring Dr. John Dewey as the foremost living American philosopher, who passed his eightieth birthday last October.

We had the feeling, somehow, that Mr. Dal Lee might be a placid, slow-moving man because his business is with eternal stars and planets; but it turned out he is on the excitable side--speaks in rushes and in the language of the astrologer, which is confusing if you have not been brought up on it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Secretary Woodring said in his War Department report, made public today, that to underestimate the potentialities of air power "might result in the extinguishment of a nation's existence."

With the heaviest Christmas travel in years safely handled, transportation companies are now planning to care for an equally voluminous traffic over the New Year's week-end. Airlines, bus companies and railroads, all profited from the holiday movement in and out of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Two Russian citizens, officers of Bookniga, Inc., a Soviet propaganda agency, were fined in Federal district court here today after pleading guilty to willful omission of material information from a registration statement filed with the State Department under the Foreign Agent Registration Act.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Dec. 28 (UP)--Japanese planes raided Lanchow, the capital of Kansu Province and a key station on the munitions highway to Russia, on Tuesday and destroyed the big Lanchow airdrome, one of the most important in China, a Japanese army spokesman said today.

Unlike Howard Rushmore, former motion picture reviewer of the Communist newspaper, The Daily Worker, James Dugan, film critic of the New Masses, yesterday made it plain that he has no expectation of resigning or being forced from his job for "deviationism" over "Gone With the Wind."

The possibility of dividing the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association into two divisions for the purpose of running elimination races for the Morss Trophy loomed at the special meeting of the organization yesterday at the New York Yacht Club.
Fred Apostoli, California boxer who has forsaken the middleweight for the light-heavyweight ranks, is an improved ringman if this exhibitions in training are any criterion.
WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, In France, Dec. 27--Indian troops are again in France.

ROME, Dec. 27--Italian newspapers reported today that Russia was massing 700,000 or more troops, Cossack cavalry and aviation along the frontier of Afghanistan, and that British, Afghan and Iranian forces also were being moved up to the border region.

Ten disastrous train wrecks in Germany since the beginning of the war, with a total of 368 dead and more than that number seriously injured, point to a situation which is admittedly causing serious concern.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 37--Reissuance of licenses for the export of American arms, ammunition and implements of war to belligerents in the European war put the total of licenses issued in November at a new high. They amounted to $119,841,835, but most of them represented reinstatement of previous export authorizations, State Department officials said in making public the monthly report today.

Marine war-risk insurance policies including protection against seizure and capture by British or French authorities will be made available to importers here on certain trade routes, starting Jan. 1, ...

Dr. Serge Voronoff, noted French gland specialist and surgeon, sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia, terminating his visit here after receiving a call from the French authorities to head a military hospital near Cannes. He was accompanied by his wife, who has been with him on a lecture tour in South America and a visit to Mexico.

Making clean sweeps against Yeshiva in the second round and N.Y.U. in the third, the chess players of Brooklyn College gained 8 points during the second session of the annual Intercollegiate Chess League tournament for the Harold M. Phillips trophy at the Manhattan club yesterday.

The long deadlock between deepsea shipping companies and the National Maritime Union over a new wage and working agreement has been ended by the initialing of a new contract that will be effective until Sept. 30, 1941.

The 1939 pre-Christmas statistics of New York City merchants, most of which indicated a definite increase in retail sales, were verified yesterday in figures relating to the collection of refuse after the long week-end holidays by employes of the Department of Sanitation.

The United States Lines, which will start its new service to Italian ports on Saturday, has been admitted to membership in the West Coast of Italy Conference, it was announced yesterday by C.R. Andrews, secretary of the TransAtlantic Associated Freight Conferences, 80 Broad Street.
Catherine McNelis, who is on trial in Federal Court on charges of mail fraud in connection with the publication of the defunct Tower Magazines, took the stand in her own defense yesterday.

The question of competitive kidding for new issues of corporate securities was brought into the limelight again yesterday when the investment banking firm of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., criticized the contract entered into by the man

After losing twice in earlier rounds to Miss Maria Cerra of Hunter College by 4-0 counts, Miss Helene Mroczkowska of Hofstra won the Women's Intercollegiate Fencing Association invitation tournament at Brooklyn College yesterday, defeating Miss Cerra, 4--3, in a second fence-off.

The month of self-enforced inactivity in the matter of new books that publishers observe every December will end abruptly next Tuesday. On that day the beginning of "Spring" to the book trade, some forty books of the fiction and general classifications will be published.

HILLSIDE, N.J., Dec. 27--Dr. Carl R. Keppler, an orthopedic surgeon and a former associate of Dr. Adolf Lorenz, noted bone specialist of Vienna, died in his sleep last night at his home here. Apparently in good health, he was at his office in Newark yesterday.

Martha Graham, dancing superbly, made her first appearance of the season last night in the Holiday Dance Festival at the St. James Theatre. The program was graced by two new works, a solo called "Columbiad" and a group composition called "Every Soul Is a Circus...".

Moral training was held to be the greatest crime preventive by Judge William O'Dwyer, District Attorney-elect, of Brooklyn, speaking yesterday at the annual meeting of the Middle Atlantic States unit of the National Catholic Educational Association at the Cathedral High School, Lexington Avenue and Fiftieth Street.
The beautiful opera of Montemezzi, "L'Amore dei tre re," was revised last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association. An audience of goodly proportions gave the work a warm and hospitable reception.

CORAL GABLES Fla. Dec. 27-- Bob's Boys, purchased by Mrs. Ed Haughton from the Superior Farm for a reported $5,000 on Christmas Day, made his first start in the new silks at Tropical Park today and promptly drove home a winner of the Fort Myers Purse.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Members of the Dies Committee to Investigate Un-American Activities were reported today to be in disagreement over the report which must be made to Congress Jan. 3.
BOSTON, Dec. 27--Dr. Le Roi Goddard Crandon, former Harvard Medical School instructor and surgeon who was the husband of Margery, Boston's celebrated medium, died today at his home, 10 Lime Street.

Operations of the Newmont Mining Corporation in the first nine months of 1939 resulted in a net profit of $1,313,139 after deducting exploration expenses, Federal income taxes, interest and other charges, and including $479,276 profit on the sale of capital assets, according to a report issued yesterday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 27-- The nineteenth annual College Week of Winter sports at the Lake Placid Club opened today with downhill and slalom skiing competition for college girls and preparatory school boys. Conditions were perfect, with fifteen inches of snow packed on the smooth course at Scott's Cobble.
Michael McMahon, former traffic patrolman who was sentenced yesterday to from Eighteen months to three years imprisonment for killing and killing Frank Sweeney, ...

Quietly, but not so casually that the recital was stripped of its drama, Miss Joy Homer told yesterday of famine in North China so extreme that coolies were reduced to eating the leaves and bark of the trees, although food for a price was obtainable in neighboring villages.

William J. Pattison, who was secretary, treasurer and publisher of The New York Evening Post from 1902 to 1914, during the presidency of Oswald Garrison Villard, died suddenly yesterday afternoon of a heart attack at his home in Clark's Summit, near Scranton, Pa., ac- ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--A plan to balance the Federal budget will be outlined by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, in a speech in Chicago, Jan. 5, before the Chicago Bar Association. The talk will be over a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 28-- Japanese dissatisfaction with Washington's cool response to Ambassador Kensuke Horinouchi's overtures for a new trade treaty finds expression in the Japanese press this morning.

All the seeded players, with the exception of George Collins of Princeton University, No. 8 on the list, came through to the fourth round of the twenty-fifth annual national junior tennis championship on the courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.

Name Dr. Gustav Eckstein a fact of life and he is ready to face it. In a spirit of clinical triumph he faces two or three with some candor in "Christmas Eve," which was acted at Henry Miller's last evening. During most of the play he studies the neurotic symptoms of an Irish girl with a father fixation, if that is the proper descrip- ...

PARIS, Dec. 27--The Balkan Entente--Rumania, Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey--opens a meeting tomorrow at Belgrade, Yugoslavia. It is suffering from the same ill that once affected the Little Entente-- Rumania, Yugoslavia and CzechoSlovakia.

TALLMAN, N.Y., Dec. 27--Miss Jean Girdler of Montclair, N.J., tonight won the Winter circuit grand championship trophy in the senior horsemanship division, which was a leading feature of the second annual horse show of the Ramapo Riding and Polo Club.
Lack of details as to the Government's new program for helping in the development of Latin America obviously precludes any appraisal of the project.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27--The United States was pictured today by Dr. Frank G. Dickinson of the University of Illinois, "a New Dealer before the NRA," as on the verge of "the most revolutionary cultural and social change since the fall of the Roman Empire," with a class war between young and old in the offing and some form of the Townsend plan sure to be enacted within the next decade.

TOKYO, Dec. 27--Yesterday's outburst of anti-government feeling has made a deep impression in political circles, because it was an unorganized and spontaneous movement expressing the sentiments of members fresh from their contact with millions of voters.
Without a dissenting vote, the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday re-elected Dr. Stephen F. Bayne as associate superintendent of the New York City public school system.

MADRIL, Dec. 27--The Spanish Government is expected to give its decision early in January on the application by the American Export Airlines for permission to establish a base at Barcelona on the transatlantic air service between New York and Italy, planned for next Spring.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months to Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $7,522,983. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $l.07 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $8,617,126, or $l.27 a common share, in the twelve months to Nov. 30, 1938.

New York City will go gala on Sunday night as the old year passes into history. With the hotels, restaurants and night clubs preparing for the traditional festivities, and reservations already running high, there is every indication that the welcome to 1940 will be glorified with the gayest revelries in years.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 27-- Germany has protested to the Rumanian Government for allowing Ignace Moscicki, former President of Poland, to leave the country, charging that his illness was only a pretext to escape internment.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 27 (AP)--The Argentine Government announced tonight rejection of a German protest against internment of the crew of the scuttled Nazi pocket battleship Admiral Graf Spee.

Although no hint has been given in the Russian newspapers of the serious reverses with which the Red Armies have met in Finland, our correspondent in Moscow reports that "news of the heavy Russian casualties is beginning to filter through to the general populace." He adds that "of course the pub- ...

The Finnish Relief Fund, Inc., now represented by a special chairman in each of the forty-five States, began yesterday to extend its war relief drive into all fields of endeavor under the general headings of business, civics and religion. Ten such special groups are being formed, it was announced at the fund's national headquarters, 420 Lexington Avenue.

While wintry winds were blowing around New York's skyscrapers, Spring and sun fashions were being shown by two of the city's big department stores and at a specialty store yesterday. In Altman's, the Young Colony Shop illustrated what girls between the ages of 11 and 17 will wear from now on in town and in the resorts.

ROME, Dec. 27--For the first time since 1870, when Italian troops captured Rome, thousands of Italian and Papal flags appeared in the streets today on the eve of Pope Pius's visit to King Victor Emmanuel. Wooden pillars decorated with the Italian and Papal colors were being erected with feverish haste late tonight along the itinerary from the Vatican to the Quirinal Palace.

LONDON, Dec. 27--The British Government announced today that Sweden and the United Kingdom had signed a war-trade agreement designed to adapt the existing British-Swedish trade agreement to wartime conditions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The volume of United States merchandise exports in the first eleven months of this year was slightly higher than in the corresponding period of 1938, with shipments in November $40,000,000 less than those in October, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Leading members of the bench and bar of the State and city attended a low requiem mass in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday for Judge John F. O'Brien of the Court of Appeals, who died Christmas morning.

Kings County Judge William O'Dwyer yesterday discouraged any Mayoralty boom for him when he was interrupted during his sentencing of prisoners by a lawyer who told him of the affection with which members of the bar held him.
Pitted against the co-holders of the Big Six Conference championship, Oklahoma and Missouri, the Fordham and N.Y.U. basketball forces will be seen on the Madison Square Garden floor for the first

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 27--A resolution passed last night by the City Council to ban the use of Lenin and Leningrad in any printed matter within the city limits seemed destined tonight for death in the pocket of Mayor John W. Lyons. The measure was introduced by Councilman Michael A. Sullivan.

After failing to appear in Supreme Court in connection with a libel suit brought by Joseph R. Levy, who asserts that he is her father, Paulette Goddard, motion picture access, was called upon in Supreme Court yesterday to show cause why she should not be held in contempt.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 (AP)-- Football stars of the East and West, in training for the big charity game here New Year's Day, provided two types of news for today's sports headlines.

Keeping pace with the growing popularity of skiing, New York State increased its myriad trails and open slopes in the past Summer and Autumn in an effort to make it unnecessary for its citizenry to travel to New England and Canada snow centers for sport, and ...

Denouncing the practice of discounting city employes' pay checks by as much as 25 per cent as an attempt to evade the usury laws of the State, Mayor La Guardia directed yesterday that payment by the city be refused on all checks that showed such assignments.

LONDON, Dec. 27--British bombers on patrol over the North Sea today reported they fought and beat three German Dornier bombers and bombed two German destroyers and eleven patrol vessels. A direct hit was scored on a patrol boat, and one enemy aircraft was riddled with bullets, they declared.

The American Automobile Association is aiming at a worthy objective in the campaign announced for the new year in support of legislation which will clear the roads of drivers neither legally nor financially responsible for accidents which they cause.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 27--The Chamber of Deputies this afternoon approved with few modifications a government bill for the reform of Article III of the Mexican Constitution which regulates the education of Mexican youth.
Having been forced to delay their Spring showings because of the rush of Fall and holiday business, men's shirt and pajama manufacturers are now preparing extensive campaigns for 1940.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Miss Jean Browne Wallace, daughter of the Secretary of Agriculture and Mrs. Henry A. Wallace, and Miss Mary Margaret Jackson, daughter of the Solicitor General and Mrs. Robert H. Jackson, were presented to society this afternoon at a tea given jointly by their parents at the Carlton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Breckenridge Long, former Ambassador to Italy, is to be appointed to an important foreign post soon, according to information given today at the White House and the State Department.

Shortly after 10 o'clock yesterday morning a small group of laborers pulled away the wooden barricades blocking the new section of the East River Drive between Fourteenth and Eighteenth Streets and Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan opened, the stretch by driving through it.

Leaders in finance, business and society as well as outstanding figures in the medical profession were among the several hundred persons who attended funeral services for Dr. George Emerson Brewer, noted surgeon, anatomist and anthropologist, yesterday morning in St. George's Church, 207 East Sixteenth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27-- "White--collar criminality" was sharply attacked by the retiring president of the American Sociological Society, Dr. Edwin H. Sutherland of Indiana University, in an address tonight which discarded accepted conceptions and explanations of crime.

More than 1,200 persons, among whom were many patrons of the opera, attended a funeral service yesterday morning in the St. Bartholomew's Church for Robert Stanton Brewster, president of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company, which owns the site ...

Red Dutton's New York Americans came from behind in their battle with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night to register a 4-to-2 triumph, and by so doing moved from a lone place in the National Hockey League cellar to joint occupancy of sixth place with the Detroit Red Wings, who were idle.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec.27--Southern California's high-geared basketball team closed its Eastern tour by defeating Temple University, 46--30, at Convention Hall tonight in the first game of a double-header before 5,500 fans. In the second game the University of Colorado conquered St. Joseph's College, 49 to 25.
Properties in the Tremont, Pelham Bay and the northern sections of the borough figured in Bronx realty transactions announced yesterday.
From a national survey made by the American Library Association and the answers of 1,000 children to a Chicago questionnaire, some interesting and rather unexpected conclusions are derived.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 (AP)--Henry G. Dalton, chairman of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and head of the nation's second largest iron ore shipping company, died here tonight at the age of 77.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 27--Ken Jolly played strong basketball for Cornell tonight as the Ithacans opened their midwinter invasion of the West, but he alone could not turn the tide against the powerful University of Toledo combination and Cornell was defeated, 45 to 29, as the Rockets scored their tenth victory in eleven starts.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 27-- An opinion handed down in the Federal District Court today by Judge John P. Nields dismissed the suit of Samuel Goldwyn for a declaratory judgment which would have released him from his contract with United Artists Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The Securities and Exchange Commission refused today to permit a declaration of General Public Utilities, Inc., to become effective because it could not find that the proposed nopar common stock issue covered by the declaration represented "an urgent or even necessary corporate purpose." It was the first ruling of its kind.
Brokers are inclined to believe that the influence of tax selling on the stock market has been small this year, certainly nothing like that at the end of 1938.

WITH THE FRENCH ARMIES, in the Field, Dec. 27--The French are still working on the Maginot Line. That is the first fact standing out from a visit of several days that this correspondent has been privileged to make along virtually the entire line from the Alps to the North Sea.
East of Salla, where the Soviet border is nearest to the Russian railroad to Murmansk, the Finns were reported yesterday to have made their second crossing of the frontier.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,867,900 barrels, an increase of 2,150 over the 3,865,750 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 27--Mayor Bryce B. Smith resigned today after a sudden switch by five members of the City Council returned the Tom Pendergast faction to control of the city government.

A communication containing a six-point agreement designed to curb sub-standard production in the millinery industry was sent yesterday to 150 resident buyers and manufacturers' sales representatives by Nathaniel Spector, manager of the joint board of the Millinery Workers Union.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 27--An icy cold in the last couple of days has settled over the Finnish-Russian fronts. From Petsamo, high in the north, down to the Karelian Isthmus the biting frost is so hard on the Russians that several times they have attacked simply to keep warm, an officer tells me. These attacks were weak and easily beaten off, with great Russian losses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Means of restoring peace to the world were discussed today at the White House by President Roosevelt and leaders of the Protestant and Jewish faiths, who said afterward that "We are all in agreement."

The State Industrial Union Council, representing unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations in New York State, put itself on record yesterday as "unqualifiedly opposed" to any amendments to the State Labor Relations Act.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 (AP)--Demand for repeal of New York's cigarette tax came to the fore today as leaders of both major parties worked in conference for agreement on a 1940-1941 State budget before its submission to the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--A vital need of the Finnish Army in its struggle against invading Soviet armies is modern anti-aircraft and anti-tank artillery and Finland has appealed to the United States to let her have sizable numbers of the latest American types of these weapons.

REMARKABLE discovery was made twenty years ago when three trunks full of letters, some dating back a century or so, were found in a farmhouse in Northeastern Oklahoma. A selection of 200 letters from the mass of 2,000-odd has been edited by Edward Everett Dale, Pro- ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP)-- Fortification of Puerto Rico has progressed so rapidly that the island "Gibraltar" already can meet any attack on the Panama Canal from the Atlantic side, War Department sources reported tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 27--Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jane Hawley Hawker, daughter of Dr. Edward Zeh Hawkes of Newark and the late Mrs. Hawker, to Donald Macy Liddell Jr., son of Colonel and Mrs. Liddell of Elizabeth, N.J., and New York. The announcement was made today at a luncheon given in the Hawkes home.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP)-- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg accused Secretary Hull today of tossing a "red herring" into the dispute over the Administration's reciprocal trade treaty program.

LONDON, Dec. 27--Government sources today credited the crew of the 7,397-ton British tanker San Alberto with an heroic attempt to steam half their ship to port after the remainder had been blown away by a torpedo.
The midweek matinee immediately following Christmas Day is generally second only to Washington's Birthday in volume of business along the Rialto, and yesterday was no exception.

THE American Football Coaches Association will convene in Los Angeles today and at the appointed stage in the three-day session Mr. Louis Little, whom Californians will remember from six years back, will rap for order with his gavel and give the floor to the gentleman from Michigan, Mr. Herbert Orrin Crisler.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--Now that men close to the President are successively publishing the opinion that he will not seek a third nomination ("unless a grave emergency has intervened," etc.) the aspirants in both major parties are emerging from their conditional storm-cellars and taking heart to make positive plans.

Nicholas Dozenberg, who dropped from sight after helping to organize the Communist party in this country, has served until recently as a member of the intelligence unit of the Soviet Russian Army, it was learned yesterday. His statement that he quit all Communist activity long ago was flatly contradicted by Federal authorities following Dozenberg's indictment yesterday on charges of passport fraud.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--President Roosevelt received today a foretaste of Congressional resistance to drastic curtailment of some Federal expenditures as reports of budgetary reductions, which he is expected to send to the Capitol next week, increased on every hand.

The supply of tickets for twenty theatre brokers was cut off entirely yesterday by the Broadway producers and managers in a drastic step to force compliance with the new code designed to curb speculation in the sale of choice seats for plays and musical comedies.

W. Alton Jones, first vice president of the Cities Service Company, will be elected chief executive of the billion-dollar oil and utility system to succeed Henry L. Doherty, it was predicted in well-informed circles yesterday.

The New York World's Fair Corporation announced yesterday that the Chrysler Corporation would again be one of the major exhibitors at the Fair next year. Under a new contract signed by K.T. Keller, president of Chrysler, and Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the Fair's board of directors, plans are being made for the 1940 exhibit.

With the local hunting and fishing rather on the inactive side, a number of sportsmen seem to devote a part of the time ordinarily spent afield in writing letters to this column. Some of them are taken up by inquiries on just about every angle of hunting and fishing, others offer information.

The 1939 Neediest Cases Fund received $5,091.99 yesterday from 336 contributors who realized that it is not yet too late to assist the suffering men, women and children who have been adjudged the most needy persons in New York.

LONDON, Dec. 27--The stock markets today wasted little time getting back into stride after the holiday. Confidence, which appeared last week, was maintained and business was fairly brisk for a year-end.
Three new securities issues have been authorized for listing on the New York Stock Exchange, but will not be admitted to dealings until further notice, according to an announcement made yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that Myles A. Paige, New York's first Negro Magistrate, would be elevated to the Court of Special Sessions on Jan. 1, to become the first member of his race to sit in any part of Special Sessions in the city.

About 2,000 youthful scientists, eager to follow in the footsteps of such pioneers as Albert Einstein, Thomas Edison and Mme. Curie, gathered yesterday in the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park ...

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 27--Fresh shocks added tonight to the terror and destruction in the regions of Eastern and Northern Anatolia, where seven earthquake shocks in quick succession today took a heavy toll of life and property.

Billy Rose, showman, has purchased the Jackson E. Reynolds residence at 33 Beekman Place, a modern five-story brick house which is one of a group of private dwellings in the fashionable Upper East Side neighborhood.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27--A new attitude of modern anthropology toward social evolution, which amounts to a gradual revolution, was explained today by Dr. Alexander Lesser of the Department of Anthropology of Brooklyn College at the opening session of the American Anthropological Association.
With trading the lightest of the month, prices on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to fluctuate within narrow limits and ended 6 points higher to 3 points lower.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 27-- Heavy fighting continued today on land, while in the air Soviet planes went on with their bombing offensive.

About 2,000 youthful scientists, eager to follow in the footsteps of such pioneers as Albert Einstein, Thomas Edison and Mme. Curie, gathered yesterday in the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park ...

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec 27 (UP)--Dispatches from Helsinki reported that during an air raid today Russian planes dropped leaflets calling on the Finns to "rebel, cease resistance and join your Russian friends."

Razing of the Sixth Avenue elevated structure was a factor in the purchase yesterday by Columbia University of a parcel which gives the buyer control of one of the largest realty holdings in the Washington Square-Greenwich Village section.

Raw silk bourses at Yokohama and Kobe were closed yesterday at "the suggestion" of the Japanese Government and, despite advances in spot prices there, the New York futures market dropped the trading limit of 15 cents a pound on all months except January which is exempt from the limit and declined 19 cents.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 27--Professor Wesley C. Mitchell of Columbia University, in delivering the keynote address tonight as retiring president at the opening general session of the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, called for "an organization that would bring into focus all the intelligence available in the community."
Selling for year-end tax adjustment purposes lowered the stock market yesterday but also produced increased activity which raised the volume on the Stock Exchange above the million-share mark.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey announced yesterday that its construction budget for next year would amount to approximately $17,500,000. Of this sum, it was stated, more than $9,000,000 is for the electric department of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27--A theory that business cycles were caused by alternating, wave-like expansions and contractions of the inflow of new capital into business enterprises was put before a meeting of the American Statistical Association today by Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27--The two big mail order houses here cut prices as usual in their midwinter bargain flyer catalogues sent out today to several million customers, but the rising trend of materials prices and other costs was reflected in smaller reductions than a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--President Roosevelt today received a "declaration of loyalty" from 11,825 civil employes of the Philadelphia Navy Yard in which they promised "to report any instance of subversive attitude or action that comes to our notice."

WASHINGTON, Dee. 27--Imports of gold into the United States in the week ended on Dec. 20 amounted to $193,666,769, the largest figure in the last month, although two weeks ago imports were $141,996,834, mostly from ,the British Empire, the Department of Commerce reported today.

David J. McLean, publisher of The Brooklyn Citizen, has leased a furnished apartment in the Buchanan at 160 East Forty-eighth Street through the MorgenthauSeixas Company, Inc., brokers, who also rented a furnished suite in 1 Fifth Avenue to James A. Farrell, attorney.

A widespread drive to encourage private industry, particularly savings banks, to enter the housing field for the income group that can afford to pay from $8 to $18 a room a month was launched yesterday by the Citizens Housing Council at a meeting in the State Chamber of Commerce Building.
After wrestling with their collective conscience until a late hour of the night, the New York Film Critics yesterday announced their selections of the cinema's "bests" for 1939.

By way of concluding the transaction which will bring Mickey Witek to the Polo Grounds next year as New York's newest second baseman, the Giants announced yesterday they had assigned two players to the Newark Bears.

In a battle between four bandits and fifteen customers in Grossman's Billiard Parlor, 212 West Forty-second Street, shortly before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Michael Grossman, 30 years old, one of the proprietors, was critically wounded in the chest.
Returns to date indicate that the combined net income of the Class I railroads in November was $22,000,000, against $7,422,137 in No- ...

WITH THE FINNISH ARMY, at Viborg, Dec. 27--Finnish artillery blasting huge holes in the ice of frozen lakes and machine guns were reported today to have repulsed with heavy losses Russian forces attempting new tactics in their drive against Mannerheim Line defenses.

Heavier trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange reflected for the most part year-end transactions in corporate issues for tax purposes. Several wide price swings were scattered in the list, while the main body of representative issues drifted irregularly lower.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27-- "The Bat," mystery-thriller of the early Twenties, which twice has reached the screen, will be the first offering of James Roosevelt's recently formed Globe Productions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)--General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, declared today that "the army machine is probably less than 25 per cent ready for immediate action."

PORT WASHINGTOI, L.I., Dec. 28--The departure of the Yankee Clipper, scheduled for this afternoon from the Pan American Airways base here, was postponed until tomorrow morning and it will be made from Baltimore, instead of from Port Washington.

Infuriated at the pointblank refusal of his estranged family to allow him to return to them, according to the police, Aaron M. Solovieff, 41 years old, a San Francisco cantor, shot and wounded his wife and one of his daughters and then killed himself at 6 o'clock last evening.

Despite the limitations imposed by war in Europe, the American shipping industry must "insist upon the free privilege" of maintaining its commercial contacts with foreign nations that are the country's best customers, Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared in a survey of the shipping outlook for 1940, made public yesterday.

Yesterday afternoon at the Anglers Club, where the dry fly is king and Dana Lamb the prime minister, we spent an unusually happy hour and a half at a preview of the color movies on Newfoundland hunting and fishing taken last Summer and and Fall by Lee Wulff.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)-- The Dies committee made public tonight a confidential report saying that the Communist Party in California sought the defeat of the Republican administration in that State last year with a $250,000 campaign fund and an organization campaign in mass industries.

BERLIN, Dec. 28--A plan for the exchange of interned civilians has been arranged between Germany, France and Britain through the mediation of the United States, Switzerland and Sweden, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--The twenty-fifth annual report of the Federal Trade Commission, made public today, was highlighted by claims of greater consumer protection afforded through enforcement of the acts administered by the commission, and by a record of victory in twenty-seven out of thirty cases in the District and Circuit Courts.

CALLANDER, Ont., Dec. 28 (UP) --Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe has agreed to resign as a guardian of the Dionne quintuplets and will present his resignation personally to Premier Mitchell Hepburn, it was learned today.

Stanley Pearson Jr. of Princeton, holder of the national intercollegiate title, gained the final of the University Club's intercollegiate invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday at the club's courts.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 (AP)--Mounting demand for tax reduction and discussion of the controversial sales tax and relief issues offered a new threat today to leaders' hopes for a brief 1940 legislative session.

The former William B. Leeds mansion at 987 Fifth Avenue, a sixstory fireproof residence with a striking bicolored stone facade has joined the long list of fine old Manhattan homes which are marked for early demolition.

With five straight matches and a total of 16 points out of a possible 18 to its credit, Brooklyn College held a long lead at the conclusion of play in the fifth round of the Intercollegiate Chess League championship at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday. As only the sixth round remains to be contested today, the champion City College team has a difficult task ahead of it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--Finland is preparing to use an amplified mosquito fleet in the Spring to battle the vastly superior Russian Navy in Finnish waters.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28--Edward F. Beale of Deepdale, Strafford, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Mrs. Hope Truxtun Beale of Haverford, to John Bromley of Chestnut Hill.

On the basis of the latest Federal Reserve figures the excess reserves of member banks of the system jumped $150,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $5,050,000,000, the widest gain of any week since that ended on Sept. 13. At the beginning of December, ...

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary schools and in high schools, recommends as suitable for children a group of pictures to be shown today through Monday, unless otherwise specified.

Miss Senta De Wanger, a leading witness in the German spy case of 1938, disclosed yesterday that the Gestapo, Germany's secret police, had been inordinately curious about her affairs and had subjected her to a questioning that amounted to an ordeal during a recent visit in Germany.

The labor movement, whose ranks have long been divided by factional strife, formed a solid front yesterday on the issue of Finnish war refugee relief as former President Herbert Hoover sent $100,000 more to Finland.

The Murray Corporation of America, manufacturer of automotive equipment, reported yesterday for the three months ended on Nov. 30, the first quarter of its fiscal year, net profit of $203,069 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges. This was equal to 21 cents each on 950,615 shares of $10-par capital stock.

The Federal budget is a mess, and probably it will continue to be throughout this administration. The fault by no means rests wholly on the Executive; Congress has a great share of responsibility, as the events of the forthcoming session will illustrate again. Also, the budget is a paradox...

Twenty-three brokers who on Wednesday were barred from further theatre ticket buying by the Broadway producers because of their refusal to sign the new antispeculation code, agreed last night to charge only a 50-cent premium for tickets sold for cash in their offices.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28--The administrations of five universities and colleges were put on the censured list of the American Association of University Professors today at the annual convention here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today public hearings on applications by the New York Stock Exchange for delisting of bonds of the National Railways of Mexico (Ferrocarriles Nacionales de Mexico) and by the New York Curb...

LONDON, Dec. 28 (UP)--British experts studying Italian press reports that Russia was massing hundreds of thousands of troops along the Afghanistan frontier were inclined today to discount the possibility of any early Soviet thrust along any part of Russia's southern border.

LONDON, Dec. 28 (Canadian Press)--A police constable tonight telephoned the adjutant of a Royal Air Force fighter command station to say that a balloon was down in a field and ask him to do something about it.

The government ended its presentation of evidence against the New York Title and Mortgage Company, four of its officers and five subsidiaries, on trial under an indictment alleging mail fraud and conspiracy, in Federal court yesterday afternoon. The trial began before Judge Henry W. Goddard and a jury on Nov. 16.

An all-Beethoven program was presented by the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, last night in Carnegie Hall, with Yehudi Menuhin as soloist. It goes without saying, that Mr. Menuhin was heard in the Bonn master's violin concerto. The remainder of the program was given over to the "Eroica" symphony and the overture to "Egmont."

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 28 (AP)--Foreign Minister Halvdan Koht said in a radio address today that Norway under no circumstances could give military aid to Finland. Norway's attitude, as he outlined it, was one of readiness to lend moral or material help but no soldiers.

The annual science congress of the American Institute Science and Engineering Clubs, which this year attracted nearly 2,000 young scientists to the American Museum of Natural History, closed yesterday with the announcement of prizes for outstanding demonstrations.
Purchases of Home Owners Loan Corporation properties by investors featured the Brooklyn realty trading reported yesterday.

Directors of the Cooper Bessemer Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share on the prior preference stock, payable on Jan. 24 to apply on accrued dividends. B.B. Williams, president, said the company's unfilled orders now exceeded $2,000,000, against $700,000 at the beginning of the year, and that its business had required opening of its plant at Mount Vernon, Ohio.

Sharp-eyed shoppers have noticed that labels on packaged foods are changing rapidly, that full lists of contents appear on some packages. That is because food manufacturers are already beginning to comply with the labeling requirements of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act that go into effect on New Year's Day.

Professor John Dewey heard his own philosophy critically examined yesterday at a special session of the American Philosophical Association at Columbia University to honor him on passing his eightieth birthday last October.

Mrs. Edward Martin Stout gave a large reception with dancing yesterday afternoon in her maisonette at 666 Park Avenue to introduce to society her niece, Miss Patricia Green, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kneeland L'Amoureux Green of 1,170 Fifth Avenue.

Rear Admiral Julius C. Townsend, commandant of the Fourth Naval District, with headquarters at the Philadelphia Navy Yard, died yesterday at the United States Naval Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 58 years old.
Paul Felix Warburg will become a general partner in J.S. Bache Co. on Jan. 1, according to an official announcement to be issued today by the firm.
LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP)--The Press Bureau announced today that the Home Minister of Northern Ireland had banned circulation during 1940 of five newspapers published across the border in Ireland [Eire].
DALLAS, Dec. 28 (AP)--Boston College's ponderous footballers arrived today and were awed by the reception accorded them by booted Texans who split the chilly atmosphere with yells.

Among the interesting points developed by Benjamin M. Anderson in a speech last night before the American Economic Association is the close connection between economic planning and international trade barriers.

A shrinkage in many items characterized the combined statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City for the week ended on Wednesday. Total loans and investments fell $316,000,000 in the week to $8,840,000,000, the lowest ...

An end to the "insanity" of intercollegiate athletics and increased standards for the physical education departments of American colleges were recomemnded yesterday by Professor. L.C. Boles of the College of Wooster in Ohio.
MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 29--Soviet Russia today put its military hero of the 1938 Far Eastern "vest pocket war" in charge of the invasion of Finland.
A man we know left an American Airlines plane in Chicago the other day and forgot his copy of "The Memoirs of Marshal Foch." He notified the company. A few days later he got a letter.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28--Field goal kicking, somewhat of a lost art in football, will be encouraged in 1940 if a proposal made by a country-wide committee of coaches is adopted by the national rules body.

The French Line passenger and freight motor ship Oregon arrived from Havre yesterday with a general cargo and nine passengers among whom were five French technicians coming to join the French purchasing commission with headquarters at 15 Broad Street. They declined to comment upon their errand.

Judge Cornelius F. Collins, after a career of half a century in the city's service, most of it on the bench, presided for the last time yesterday in his part of General Sessions, although he will not reach the end of his judgship until the close of the year, when he retires because of the 70-year age limit.
HELSINKI, Finland, Friday, Dec. 29--Finnish troops were reported officially today to be pressing deeper into Russian territory toward the Soviet's important Repola base.

BERLIN, Dec. 28--As the result of experiences during four months of war, the administrative apparatus of German war economy is again being reorganized in such a way that the decisive influence of initiative is being taken out of the hands of respective Cabinet Ministers and is being concentrated in an economic general staff under Field Marshal Hermann Goering as head of the Cabinet Council for the Defense of the Reich.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP) --Southern California's football aggregation is believed to be stronger than Tennessee in reserves, but it remains to be seen whether the mighty Trojans can make this advantage pay dividends in the Rose Bowl on Monday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 (UP) Tatsuo Kawai, Japan's new Minister-at-Large, today said the United States' attempts to unify the Western Hemisphere were parallel to Japan's drive to unite the Orient.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 (AP)--New York's Court of Appeals, convening for the last time with its present membership, today upheld the validity of the State Mortgage Tax Law bringing the State more than $3,000,000 annually.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--A letter supporting President Roosevelt's program for peace but disapproving the appointment of a personal representative of the Chief Executive at the Vatican will be delivered to the White House tomorrow morning on behalf of 10,250,000 Baptists in the United States, the Rev. Dr. Rufus W. Weaver, chairman of the...

CHICAGO, Dec. 28--Prices of wheat fluctuated today in an erratic manner within a range of about 2 cents a bushel. Trading was largely of a professional character and the market was influenced easily by relatively small buying or selling orders. Houses with Eastern connections were good sellers of the...
