PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28--With New Deal spokesmen on opposing sides the question of "trust busting" was threshed out today at the annual meeting of the American Economic Association, but not before economists themselves were chided for "glibness in assuming facts" and "arrogance about their own astigmatism."

Leaders in the nation's business, industrial and political life will serve as honorary pall bearers at funeral services for Henry L. Doherty at 2 P.M. today in St. Bartholemew's Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street. The service will be conducted by the Rev. George Paull T. Sargent, rector.

James Wheeler-Hill, the 34-yearold $30-a-week national secretary of the German-American Bund, was arrested yesterday after a grand jury had handed up an information charging him with three counts of second degree perjury.
LONDON, Dec. 28--The Admiralty announced tonight that the trawler Loch Doon was overdue and must be presumed lost with her captain and crew of fourteen.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28-- Sol Lesser has opened negotiations with Oscar Serlin, Broadway producer, for the film rights to "Life With Father." While the deal is in a nebulous state, Lesser plans on putting the picture on the screen with the Broadway cast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--Changing modern conditions must be accompanied by shifting national policies to meet them, whether the changed conditions be caused by war abroad or by the growth of the United States to maturity, Secretary Wallace said tonight in a...
WITH THE FINNISH ARCTIC ARMY, near Kemijaervi, Dec. 28-- For two days the writer has been at the front with an advance post of the Finnish Arctic Army.

After shaking off the effects of considerable tax selling in early dealings, bonds rallied and moved upward over a broad front yesterday in fairly active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. All major classifications participated in the improvement.

R. Henry Norweb, United States Minister to the Dominican Republic, sails today on the Grace liner Santa Lucia, heading the United States delegation to the Inter-American Radio Communications Conference to be held in Santiago, Chile, the last week in January. He will be accompanied by his wife.

The steel industry looks forward to the new year encouraged by the substantial improvement which it has shown during the past four months, E.R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, says in his year-end statement.

DELAWARE, Ohio; Dec. 28-- Studies of the meteorite which fell near Dresden, Ont., Canada, on July 11, strongly indicate that it came from beyond our own solar system, Dr. P.M. Millman of the David Dunlap Observatory in Toronto told the annual meeting of the American Astronomical Society, at the Perkins Observatory of Ohio Wesleyan and Ohio State Universities.

In one of the most thrilling matches seen on the courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory in a long time, 16-year-old Jimmy Evert of Chicago came from behind to defeat Allen McDonald of Kenyon College, Gambier, Ohio, in the annual national junior tennis championship yesterday. Evert triumphed by 4--6, 6-3, 7-5 to reach the quarter-finals.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 28-- Fire-scarred ruins uncovered in Greece last Spring have been identified as those of the Palace of Nestor, ancient Hellenic sage and King, a Cincinnati archaeologist announced today.

Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, in commenting last night on the decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the Consumers Power Company's financing program, indicated strongly that the extensive 1940 ...

Contributions amounting to $5,661.29 reached the 1939 Neediest Cases Fund from 268 donors yesterday, bringing the total that has been received in this twenty-eighth annual appeal for the sick, the destitute and the homeless to $224,892.69.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28--Denial that industrial concentration had decreased competition was made tonight by Rufus S. Tucker of the General Motors Corporation in an address before the annual meeting of the American Marketing Association.

Breezing along on the crest of a superb record that has seen them go undefeated in their last twelve outings, the Rangers will cross sticks with their arch-rivals, the Bruins, at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Woodrow Wilson's ideal of the "right of self-determination of nations" still prevails in Poland and Czecho-Slovakia, and attacks against it, if other means fail, will be "crushed by force," the Polish and Czech envoys to this country declared here yesterday.

The water consumption of New York City will surpass "the safe yield" of its water supply system this year, Leonard P. Wood, engineer of the New York City Board of Water Supply, declared yesterday at the annual Winter meeting of the New York section of the American Water Works Association at the Hotel Commodore.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28--Large plans of Yale's Institute of Human Relations to set up a clearing house, or "bank," of all known anthropological facts relating to human culture, were revealed today by Dr. George P. Murdock, chairman of the Department of Anthropology, at a session of the American Anthropological Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28--Columbia lost a spectacular game to California, 43--36, tonight in the second part of a basketball doubleheader at Penn's Palestra after Stanford paraded to a 55-29 decision over Dartmouth.

TOKYO, Dec. 28--The Japanese Cabinet will not resign but will meet Parliament and continue its policies directed toward a settlement of the "China incident" and toward adjustment of Japan's relations with foreign powers.

After a day of charge and counter-charge between the New York Film Critics and the National Broadcasting Company, the issue of whether--and what--Mayor La Guardia shall be permitted to broadcast at the critics' annual party for the award of the year's movie "bests" was settled amicably last night.
ROME, Dec. 28--Pope Pius XII returned the visit of the King Victor Emmanuel of Italy this morning in a solemn and gorgeous ceremony that set a precedent for this era of papal history.
TEANECK, N.J. (Friday), Dec. 29--Bergen County Common Pleas Judge Howard Mackay died shortly after midnight today in his home here. He was 51 years old.

Two men connected with the F.W. Woolworth Company were called as rebuttal witnesses for the government yesterday at the trial of Miss Catherine McNelis and two others on charges of mail fraud in Federal court.
MOSCOW, Dec. 28--Foreign correspondents here were informed tonight that from tomorrow a censorship would be imposed upon all dispatches to be sent out of the Soviet Union.

WITH FRENCH ARMIES, in the Field, Dec. 28--If in normal life the mark of genius is an infinite capacity for taking pains, it is more so in war and still more so in this period of "temporary inaction." The pains have multiplied since by force of circumstances the French armies went into Winter quarters.

Advices from the Autonomous Institute for the Amortization of the Public Debt of the Republic of Chile report that under Article 6 of the law of Jan. 31, 1935, receipts of the institute in 1939 available for ...

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. won the award yesterday in an auction sale of $1,314,000 of refunding, highway, bridge and public works bonds of Albany County, N.Y., on a bid of 100.35 for 1.60s. The bonds, dated Dec. 1, will mature serially on Dec. 1, 1940 to 1958.

Once more a great disaster has visited a country, caused this time not by man's inhumanity to man, but by a gigantic force of nature. The estimates of dead and injured from the Turkish earthquakes run high into the thousands.
The first volume of the Universal Jewish Encyclopedia will be published today, according to an announcement yesterday by Rabbi Isaac Landman, editor of the tenvolume work in English.

An agreement for a compromise plan of reorganization for the Erie Railroad has been reached by bondholders headed by Wilfred Kurth, chairman of the Home Insurance Company; the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, which controls the Erie, and the Erie itself, it was announced yesterday. It was outlined in a letter to Claude R. Porter of the Interstate Commerce Commission from counsel for the three interests.

An August heat wave that broke all records for that month kept since the Weather Bureau started in 1871 and last Summer's drought were the outstanding features recorded this year by the Weather Bureau, according to preliminary data on 1939 weather furnished yesterday by the local Weather Bureau.
Tenement houses on the East Side attracted buyers in transactions announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--The Consumers Power Company may market $18,594,000 of its proposed issue of $28,594,000 of first mortgage 3 per cent bonds and may sell 125,000 shares of its common stock at $28.25 a share to its parent, the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, ...

Efforts now under way to break down State barriers to trade will be supported by national advertisers, many of whom have been forced to curtail their advertising in certain States, because of local restrictions, it was pointed out here yesterday. While the general impression has been that agricultural products have been most affected by these restrictive laws, several manufactured products have come under State bans.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28--A charge that "society powerfully discourages advanced learning very far outside its frameworks" was made before a meeting of the American Sociological Society today by Dr. Robert E.L. Faris of McGill University.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)-- Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, told the United States Rubber Company today that its proposed purchase of the Fisk Rubber Company "may violate the Federal anti-trust laws." Mr. Arnold did not, however, advise against consummation of the merger, upon which stockholders of Fisk Rubber are to vote tomorrow.

Frank A. Eri kson, one of the country's largest bookmakers, who was denounced by Mayor La Guardia as an "undesirable" resident of the city, was convicted of second-degree perjury by the Justices of the Court of Special Sessions in Queens yesterday after his attorney rested his case without offering testimony. He faces a possible sentence of up to one year in the penitentiary.
THERE are several books we'd like to commend to you before saying farewell to the year and--as a belated vacation in certain islands begins--three cheers for old Nassau.

An underwriting syndicate of seventy-seven members headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., will offer today to the public $60,000,000 of collateral trust bonds of the Louisville Nashville Railroad Company.
Johnny Mize, batting champion of the National League for 1939, was also his circuit's leading slugger last Summer, according to the official averages announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)--The European conflict has created again a danger that American natural resources will be raided for war profits, said Secretary Ickes in his annual report issued today.
Lillian Gish, who appeared last season in "Dear Octopus," will have the Dorothy Stickney role in the touring company of "Life With Father," the current comedy success at the Empire.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--Reinforcement of the air defenses of the nation by the creation of fifty-two new Army Air Corps squadrons has been ordered by the War Department. The squadrons are to report at stations in the continental United...

Fresh from his "conquest" of John L. Lewis on the Chicago theatrical stage, James C. Petrillo, president of the Chicago Federation of Musicians, came to New York yesterday to help speed lagging negotiations between the American Federation of Musicians and representatives of radio networks and independent broadcasting stations.

For the three weeks ended Dec. 23 total sales of the reporting department stores in this district on a day-for-day basis were about 5 per cent higher than in the corresponding period of 1938, and the daily rate of sales for this portion of December showed about the usual seasonal advance from November, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Apparently believing in the maxim "better late than never," Santa Claus put in a belated appearance yesterday at the annual Christmas party of the Republican Club of the Fifteenth Assembly District, 122 East Eighty-third Street, and handed out presents right and left to a host of children who did not seem to care whether Christmas had passed or not.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 28--The discovery of a hitherto unsuspected mechanism in the bodies of mature animals that enables the animal to resist infection by viruses which attack the nervous system, such as infantile paralysis and sleeping sickness, was reported here today...

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28-- Mar Le, who finished last in the Inaugural Purse, had his running shoes on today and easily accounted for the Naples Purse, a six-furlong event that topped the Tropical Park program. The Lemar Stock Farm's 4-year-old was confidently backed, the return being $4.80 for $2.

Preceded into Madison Square Garden by the reputation of being the slickest and best of the metropolitan quintets, N.Y.U. gave evidence to a gathering of 14,282 last night that perhaps this claim is not exaggerated. The Violet, which has not been under 60 points in any game this year, routed Missouri, 68 to 47.
Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe of Planting Fields, Oyster Bay, L.I., have left for Cherokee Plantation, their Winter home in Yemassee, S.C., where they will have a house party over New Year's.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--Newton C. Parke, newspaper man and foreign correspondent, plunged to his death today from his ninth floor room at the Annapolis Hotel, leaving a note saying that his wife, Mrs. N.C. Parke, would take care of his bill. He was 51 years old.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 28--Attacking one of China's overland supply routes, more than 100 Japanese army and navy planes completed today three consecutive days of intensive bombing of the city of Lanchow, Kansu Province, which is rated the most important point on the so-called Red route over which military supplies from Soviet Russia reach Chungking.

MOSCOW Dec. 28--The Russian silence concerning the war in Finland deepens. Tonight's communique consisted of one perfunctory sentence to the effect that "no events of importance" had occurred during the day.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 28--The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, commonly called ASCAP, was upheld today in its attempt to enjoin operation of the Nebraska statute to outlaw that organization, which is said to control 85 to 90 per cent of popular music essential for the operation of radio stations, dance halls, hotels and theatres.

Frederic Anson Burlingame, lawyer, died here yesterday at Doctors Hospital, after a short illness. He was 66 years old and lived at the Berkshire Hotel, 21 East Fiftysecond Street. He had a country home at West Redding, Conn.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28--A national conference in an as yet undisclosed city will be held in mid-January to fight the growing ownership of manufacturing facilities by distributors, J. Frank Grimes, president of the Independent Grocers Alliance of America said today.

LONDON, Dec. 28.--Under the lead of the war loan, which reached its highest level since the war began, gilt-edge securities continued to rise today, absorbing practically all interest in the stock markets. Other sections relapsed into idleness usually associated with the last day of the year. Prices were well maintained, but actual business was small.

Failure of war risk insurance underwriters to offer coverage against capture and seizure by Allied naval vessels for cargoes traveling routes similar to those on which protection will be available on imports after Jan. 1 was criticized by exporters here yesterday.

Frederic Anson Burlingame, lawyer, died here yesterday at Doctors Hospital, after a short illness. He was 66 years old and lived at the Berkshire Hotel, 21 East Fiftysecond Street. He had a country home at West Redding, Conn.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 28-- Mr. and Mrs. Aksel C.P. Wichfeld entertained tonight with a dinner for their house guest, Mrs. Lewis Bell Whelen of Philadelphia.

The new Anglo-Swedish war-trade agreement is the fruit of a number of motives. It represents, in the first place, an attempt to maintain so far as possible British trade with Sweden, as part of the wider effort to preserve British export trade in general.
Mayor La Guardia certified the city's 1940 capital outlay budget of $109,018,335 yesterday without making any objection to the cuts amounting to $3,267,800 made in the budget by the City Council.

Luis Philip Senarens, who died Tuesday at the age of 76, was one of the old race of dime novelists. The term is more comprehensive than exact, for the "nickel libraries" were famous. The Tip Top Weekly, Old Sleuth, Diamond Dick had a wide circulation.

Detlef Frederick De Otte, who retired in 1931 as a rear admiral of the United States Coast Guard after forty-five years' service, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived at 41 Fifth Avenue.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28--Reports were circulating in Russian circles today that the United States Government, as a political move designed to show further its disapproval of the Russian invasion of Finland, was forcing the return to the United States of a number of American engineers engaged on work for the Soviet Union.

PARIS, Dec. 28--France's 80,000,000,000-franc budget was passed unanimously through the Senate this afternoon in a manner thatwas at the same time a triumph for Finance Minister Paul Reynaud and a guarantee that France has started on the enormous task of paying for the war.

The hat and the coiffure will be wedded in perfect amity this season--such is the New Year's message expressed yesterday at a weekly showing in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton Hotel. A luncheon was given under the auspices of Lilly Dache and Charley of the Ritz.

Reports of apartment rentals received yesterday from brokers and agents evidenced a sustained demand for residential quarters in many sections of the city, with both West and East Sides sharing largely in the activity.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 28-- Princeton's fighting hockey team beat Harvard, 6 to 3, tonight in the first contest of their annual threegame series, which is part of the nineteenth annual college week competition at the Lake Placid Club.
Miss Elizabeth Shackford made her debut last night at a dance given by her mother, Mrs. William Moore Shackford, on the St. Regis Roof. The walls of the ballroom...

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Friday, Dec. 29--Approximately 70 per cent of the population of Erzingan Province were killed or injured in Wednesday's earthquake, an official inquiry committee sent to the area reported today.

The performance of "Die Walkuere" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House was attended by an audience which taxed the capacity of the theatre, and an immense ovation was extended Helen Traubel of St. Louis, who made her first appearance in a Metropolitan Winter season in the role of Sieglinde.

On Jan. 1 the Federal old-age insurance plan, for which the country has been paying taxes for three years, will go at last into full effect. As of that day the Government will begin paying benefits under the plan.

Although lower quotations for cotton prevailed in Liverpool and Alexandria, an early setback on the Cotton Exchange here proved short lived and a steady recovery yesterday left the list 1 to 8 points higher than on Wednesday.

LONDON, Dec. 28--The war came a little closer to housewives of Great Britain today when the Ministry of Food announced that Jan. 8 was not only the date when rationing of sugar, bacon and butter would become effective but also the date for beginning registration for meat rationing.

With activity on the New York Stock Exchange containuing above the million-share mark, mainly because of year-end tax adjustment trades, stocks managed yesterday to move out of their eight-day stalemate and, after recovering the losses of Wednesday, finished with ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--Democratic leaders, hoping to eliminate the Wagner act as an issue in the 1940 Presidential campaign, will present to President Roosevelt within the next few days definite suggestions for amending that much criticized law.
Sai Shoki presented a program of Korean dances last night in the Holiday Dance Festival at the St. James Theatre, and succeeded in making a most engaging evening of it.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 28-- A campaign against "relief floaters," who have migrated from distant cities into Westchester County because of the more generous relief provided here, was begun today by...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--James L. Houghteling, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, acting with the advice and approval of Secretary Perkins, tonight notified Jan A. Bata, head of the ...

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 28--The Rev. James J. McCann, pastor of the St. Paul of the Cross Catholic Church in Dayton, N.Y., in the Diocese of Buffalo, died here today at his family home after a long illness. He was 47 years old and had been a priest for twenty years.

LONDON, Dec. 29--While survivors of German submarine and airplane attacks came ashore today with thrilling tales of their escapes, the Nazis' relentless mine warfare claimed one more British victim, the Grimsby trawler Resercho, of 258 tons.

The Longhorn probably came to Meuco with or soon after Cortez. Anyhow, he had Spanish blood in him. Like other Europeans, he adapted himself to his new environment, apparently learning a good deal from the buffalo.

The report of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months to Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $13,232,865. This was equal, after preferred dividend...

Martha Graham made her second appearance in the Holiday Dance Festival at the St. James last night in a brilliant program consisting of the two new works presented for the first time earlier in the week, and a revival of several older compositions that have not been seen for several seasons.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 29--Henry A. Bellows, director of public relations for General Mills, Inc., since 1936, a writer, an original member of the Federal Radio Commission and a former vice president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died here today at his home at the age of 54.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 29 (AP)--Jon Olof Soederblom, son-inlaw of Premier Per Albin Hansson, left today with the fourth contingent of Swedish volunteers to fight in Finland.

The Neediest Cases Fund received $3,357.13 yesterday from 161 contributors, whose joint efforts to aid the most desperately needy persons in New York brought the total that has been realized in this twenty-eighth annual appeal to $228,239.82.

BERLIN, Dec. 29--German bakers are now facing the problem of presenting to the German people pastry that is tasty but does not contain too much sugar, fat and butter. Rations of these products to bakers are to be further curtailed.

LONDON, Dec. 29--Details of how the British public's money is being spent on war supplies and how the government is rapidly "quickening the pace" of the war effort were explained today by Edward Leslie Burgin, Minister of Supply, in an impressive account of the production of guns, shells and general war equipment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--James M. Landis, Harvard Law School dean acting as a special Labor Department examiner, submitted to Secretary Perkins today a finding that Harry Bridges, West Coast C.I.O. leader, is neither a member of nor affiliated with the Communist party.

Aldous Huxley, whose new novel, "After Many a Summer Dies the Swan," will be published Jan. 26 by Harper's, reports from California, where he has made his home for the last two years, that the book was written in the intervals of re-educating his sight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)-- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and his wife, the former Ethel du Pont, arrived at the White House at 4 o'clock this afternoon, bearing marks of an automobile accident which sent them to a Winchester (Va.) hospital for treatment before dawn today.

Bernard J. Rigney, 57 years old, a former employe of the city's Independent Subway, who was to be tried in General Sessions on Tuesday for the alleged theft of $25,000 in nickels from station turnstiles between 1934 and 1937, obtained a show-cause order yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Steuer in a demand for a change of venue for the trial.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 29--Common Pleas Judge Richard Hartshorne, presiding at the land conspiracy retrial of Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein and eight co-defendants, ordered a verdict of acquittal for Reginald C.S. Parnell, former City Commissioner of Newark, at today's session.

Legal action to oust Simon W. Gerson, Communist aide to Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, will be started by the American Legion soon, it was announced yesterday following a refusal by Mr. Isaacs yesterday to accede to a new Legion demand for the dismissal of Mr. Gerson.

An approach to a new system of philosophy was presented in a three-day course of lectures completed yesterday before a general meeting of the American Philosophical Association assembled at Columbia University for the purpose of hearing them.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29--Three members of the Silver Shirt League of America, anti-Semitic and antiCommunist organization, were sentenced to one to ten years in the penitentiary by Judge John S.B. Arbaro in the Criminal Court today.

John F. Walah, head gardener for the Park Department and a gardener for the city for thirty-six years, died yesterday at his home, 5,731 Faraday Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, of a heart ailment after an illness of a month. He was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--Roundlot trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Dec. 9 was 4,217,560 shares, compared with 3,936,700 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Tammany Hall lost six of the nine clerical positions it has held in the City Council, yesterday, when the fourteen Democrats in the new Council decided to apportion these posts among the boroughs outside Manhattan.

Mrs. John Chichester Collingwood of Dongan Hills, S.I., and Beaverkill, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Pelton Collingwood, to Henry S. Haskell 2d, son of Mrs. Clayton K. Haskell of Washington and of the late Dr. Haskell. The couple plan to be married in St. Andrew's Church in Dongan Hills on Jan. 26.

Simplicity of ritual in a bower of hundreds of richly colored floral tributes marked the funeral service yesterday afternoon for Henry L. Doherty in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street.
The joyous cry of "Ski Heil" and yodeling that would make an Alpine veteran turn green with envy resounded throughout the Grand Central Terminal last night.

Twenty-nine girls employed in the basement of May's Fur and Ready to Wear, Inc., 510 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, were made ill yesterday by gas seeping into the building from a leak in a main in Hanover Place near by. The police reported that none of the victims was badly affected.

A jury of ten men and two women began yesterday their deliberations in the case of Catherine McNelis and her brother, John McNelis; Joseph E. Flynn and Tower Magazines, Inc. The group were tried in Federal Court before Judge Clarence Galston on charges of mail fraud in connection with the group of magazines formerly published by the company.
Many changes in brokerage firms were announced yesterday. Selma Ungerleider, a general partner of E.J. Roth Co., became a special partner on Dec. 28.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP)--While the Missouri football squad enjoyed a day off after ending serious training, Georgia Tech worked on the practice field today to reach fighting trim for Monday's Orange Bowl game.

Dudley David Sicher, secretary and former president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and a leading manufacturer who retired from business to devote his full time to philanthropy, died last night at his home at 15 East Eightieth Street. He was 63 years old.

Features of the seventh week of the Metropolitan Opera season, beginning Monday night, Jan. 8, will include the first appearances this Winter of Bidu Sayao and Douglas Beattie and the first performance by Herbert Janssen of the title role in Wagner's "The Flying Dutchman."
The cost of government aid to unemployed and needy persons in New York City declined by $43,674,434 during 1939, a survey among Federal, State and municipal agencies disclosed yesterday.

Much is being done to extend our cultural relations with the Latin-American republics, a national purpose now stimulated by the war in Europe. About twelve new accountantinvestigators will join the staff of the New York regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission early in January, it was announced yesterday. ST. PAUL, Dec. 29--The Minnesota State Supreme Court upheld today the right of the United States Steel Corporation to file a single consolidated income tax return for all subsidiaries in Minnesota in which it owns or controls 90 per cent of the voting stock.

Miss Peggy Carpenter of New Rochelle made an impressive showing yesterday at the thirteenth horse show of the Metropolitan Equestriaa Club. The exhibition in the arena of the Riding and Polo Club was held for the benefit of the new building fund of Lebanon Hospital.

A Federal census of business and manufacturing concerns in the New York area will begin on Tuesday, simultaneously with that of the remaining 90 per cent of similar firms, together with mines and quarries, throughout the United States. This is the first part of the sixteenth decennial Federal census.

One young gunman was critically wounded and his three confederates were routed yesterday when the manager of an East Side wholesale tobacco and candy store "beat them to the draw," during a holdup. ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP)--Three upState Republican jurists and one Democrat won promotion to the Appellate Division, Fourth Department, today to fill vacancies caused by elevation of two Republicans to the Court of Appeals.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 29-- Ogden Phipps, national champion, appeared to have little difficulty in winning his match in the opening round of the annual Tuxedo Gold Racquet court tennis championship as play started today at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club. He defeated Dr. J.L. Millen of New Yorh, 6--1, 6--3.

Form again prevailed as the first four seeded contenders reached the semi-finals of the twenty-fifth annual national junior tennis championship on the courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.

Bert L. Feibleman, retired theatrical manager, who had been associated with George M. Cohan and Sam Harris and with David Belasco for many years, died Thursday night at Polyclinic Hospital after an illness of six weeks. Mr. Feibleman, who was 64 years old, resided at the Lambs Club.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 29--Raymond J. Whitney, Village Manager of Mamaroneck, will be appointed City Manager of Yonkers at a salary of $12,000 yearly on Jan. 1, it was announced tonight by the City Council-elect after an executive session in City Hall.

The outlook for the railroads in 1940 was described yesterday as "encouraging" by J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads. He pointed out that the current level of freight traffic was higher than in any year since 1936 and that earnings therefore had improved.

The two principal factors which are retarding business recovery are taxation and a "complete lack of confidence in the future," W.E. McKell, retiring president of the New York Board of Trade and its chairman-elect of the board, said yesterday in his report for 1939.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 29--More than 30,000 casualties, mostly killed, is today's minimum estimate of the havoc wrought in the great Anatolian earthquake. First reports from the stricken zone say that the area of 60,000 square miles that took the full force of the shocks resembles a huge open-air hospital and grotesque cemetery.

Many retailers were obliged during the week to find bargain offerings quickly for January clearances, since stocks in most stores were at a lower level than at the end of 1938, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for the first week of 1940 by twenty-eight municipalities aggregates $7,257,444 as compared with $7,701,574 for this week. The weekly average for the entire year of 1939 totals $24,647,393, slightly less than last years average of $26,057,275.

Ten police captains in charge of the various departmental divisions in Brooklyn were closeted for several hours yesterday in Manhattan headquarters with Inspector Michael J. Murphy, in charge of Commissioner Valentine's confidential squad.

Eight square miles of Raritan Bay off the Staten Island shore, said to contain the richest clam beds in New York State and which have been untouched for nearly sixteen years, will be opened to public use next Monday, it was announced yesterday by the State Department of Conservation.

VIENNA, Dec. 29--The latest reliable report received here indicated that Count Andreas Szeptycki, Metropolitan of the Catholic Church of the Ruthenian Rite in Galicia, was alive and in good health approximately three weeks ago.

The American Metal Company, Ltd., authorized yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Feb. 1. During 1939 the company paid four dividends of 25 cents each.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29-- Middlebury College of Vermont led the way tonight after the first day's competition in the nineteenth annual college men's ski meet of the Lake Placid Club. Through a still, ideal Winter day, with a light snow falling, the skiers of twelve colleges completed the twelve-kilometer cross-country run this morning and the slalom this afternoon.

Garvin, president of the board of trustees of the Brooklyn Public Library, has won the gold medal awarded annually by the Downtown Brooklyn Association to the citizen who, during the last year, has rendered the "most distinguished service for Brooklyn," Henry J. Davenport, president of the association, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The American Federation of Labor today called for "a conference of responsible representatives from business, labor, farmers and consumers to lay the basis for cooperation to increase production and thus to give more assurance as to the future than could otherwise be possible."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--President Roosevelt determined finally today upon the budget figure for the fiscal year beginning next July 1, and set himself to work in earnest preparing two messages, one of which he plans to deliver personally to a joint session of Congress next Wednesday afternoon.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP)--The State Racing Commission recommended today a "take" of 9 per cent on bets placed under the pari-mutuel system scheduled to become effective on New York tracks next year.

The State Employment Service cannot ignore the qualifications specified by private employers to give preference to job-seekers from the WPA or home relief rolls, Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, declared yesterday.

The appointment of Mr. Daniel W. Bell as Under-Secretary of the Treasury is more than a well-deserved promotion. It is an instance of a remarkable trained non-political talent making its way quietly in the civil service to a high office in the Treasury.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 29-- Six valuable horses were suffocated and two stable boys who went to their aid were badly burned tonight in a fire at the Bronxville Riding Club.
